As with past issues, Other Magic #3: The Ancient World will be a 5.5” x 8.5” stapled ("saddle stitched") monochromatic booklet, per ZineQuest 2021 rules.   I anticipate it being roughly 40 pages long, not counting the cover.
Since past issues of the zine are provided for free at every pledge level, I am not doing any add-ons or stretch goals for this campaign.  I would rather just give backers everything up front.  
I will not be reprinting either of the past issues for this Kickstarter, but will provide free copies of the PDFs at every pledge level.  Backers are free to make print copies of any of the issues for personal use.
The first edition of Other Magic (ZineQuest 2019) focused on real world folk magic traditions, with an emphasis on those of the United States and Mexico.  It included spells and rituals from Pennsylvania Dutch braucherei/powwowing, brujeria / hechiceria / curanderismo, hoodoo / rootwork / conjure, and Ozark magic traditions.   A description of Russian Slavic zagovory was included to show some of the differences between New World and Old World magic.
Other Magic #2: Monsters of the Americas (ZineQuest 2020) was a bestiary of the more obscure legendary creatures of the United States, Central America, South America, and Caribbean.
I will be using a printing company to produce the zine this year, rather than producing it at home.  
US BACKERS
I will use First Class Mail to deliver print copies of the zine to backers in the United States.  Shipping is included in the price of the pledge.
INTERNATIONAL BACKERS
Shipping to international backers will cost an additional $5.00, which is included in the price of the international pledge backing levels.  It does not need to be paid separately.  Backers will need to pay any applicable VAT, import duties, or taxes, if required.  I will be shipping the zines in envelopes using First Class Mail International postage, marked as books on the custom forms. If you are unsure whether your country accepts First Class Mail International postage, please check the applicable information on the USPS International Country Listing page.  If your country does not accept First Class Mail International postage, I won’t be able to send you a print copy.
I used First Class Mail International shipping with the first two issues of the zine.  It is the most affordable way to send zines to other countries, by a wide margin.  There is a drawback to it, though.  First Class Mail International envelopes have to be able to bend an inch.  If they aren't, they get reclassified as "retail packages" and postage costs triple.  Given that, I can't put anything in the envelopes to make them stiffer, which means that they are more vulnerable to being folded or creased.  After going through the mail services of two or more countries without a rigid backing, they may arrive with some bumps and creases.  I haven't had much of an issue with that in the past, but it is a possibility.  I will happily replace anything that is severely damaged, of course, but if you need the zine to be in pristine condition, it might be better for you to back at the PDF-only level and print your own copy locally.  Caveat emptor.
Between issues related to Covid and Brexit, international mail is more unpredictable than usual.  I will make sure to let international backers know when their zines are mailed, but I can’t predict how long it may take them to arrive after that point.   In the past two ZineQuest campaigns I ran, the longest it took an international backer to receive their print copy after I mailed it was two weeks.  I honestly don’t know what to expect this year, but hopefully things won’t be delayed by too much.
Remember, all backers who receive a PDF of any issue of the zine may opt to print their own copy for personal use. Backing at a PDF-only level and printing your own copy may be a better option if you are in a country that is experiencing issues with international mail.
Once upon a time I was a cultural anthropology grad student.  I did a little pre-dissertation research in Romania, hoping to teach at a university one day.  The bottom fell out of the university teaching market before I reached that point, though, so I ended up switching gears and becoming a programmer / developer, working on large corporate websites during the dotcom era.  After doing that for a long time, I eventually decided to switch gears again, returning to grad school to pick up a degree in Library Science.  Since then, I have been (at various time) a youth services librarian, a reference librarian, and a library director.  As a librarian, I have spent a lot of time as a storyteller, for audiences of all ages.  
I have a wide range of interests and hobbies, and love doing research.  I started playing tabletop roleplaying games back during the days of the Holmes edition of D&D and 1st edition AD&D. Over the past 40+ years I have GMed and played in a lot of different rpgs, in many different genres.  In addition to local weekly D&D games, I enjoy GMing Call of Cthulhu, OpenD6, and other games at various conventions throughout Texas. 
Real world magic systems - particularly folk magic - are a part of my ongoing research interests.  I have incorporated realistic folk magic in a variety of games I have run, from Call of Cthulhu to OpenD6 to D&D 5E.  

I put out Other Magic under the company name Woodcut Games.  I'm the sum total of Woodcut Games, but it is a lot easier for people to pronounce than my last name.  If you are interested in reading more about using real world magic in roleplaying games, please visit my new blog at woodcutgames.com.  I will be posting interesting things that didn't make it into my zine, links to useful resources, and whatever other gaming stuff I find useful.

Risks and challenges
I would say that this is a fairly low-risk campaign. This is the third issue of the zine I have put out via Kickstarter, so I have a pretty good idea of what to expect.

I finished the research and a large part of the writing before launching the campaign. I have the art in hand and paid for, and have done the initial layout. At this point I am mainly working on finalizing the layout and doing several more editorial passes. Once that is done, I will send everything to the printer, get some samples made, make any necessary changes, and then order the final print run.

Given all the issues surrounding the effect of the pandemic on businesses, I have built a little extra time into the fulfillment schedule to account for any unforeseen delays in getting samples and the final print run.

This is a just a brief update to let everyone know that we are still on track to deliver Other Magic #3: The Ancient World at some point next month (June).
As is usual for my projects, I ended up with a lot more information (and writing) than I can fit in the somewhat limited space of a zine, so my focus has been on selecting the most interesting and useful stuff and condensing it, all while still retaining the relevant cultural contexts. Since I find ALL of it interesting, that can be more of a challenge than it might seem. My wife is always good about reminding me that I am writing a gaming zine, not a book, and that the parts I don't include can be put out in other formats, including blog posts (which I fully intend to do) and additional PDF downloads.

I accidentally made that last update viewable for everyone, not just backers, so please ignore it!  I have removed that download directory, and will send everyone a new link with the updated one.  Sorry about that, and thank you to those who alerted me to my mistake!

campaign.story:
Apothecaria is a solo journalling RPG in which you take the role of a village witch creating potions for the unfortunate villagers, adventurers, and monsters that come to you for help. The potions you create and the stories that unfold come together to create a beautiful journal that is unique and personal to you. Fill pages with drawings of ingredients, stories of run-ins with thieving fairies and sleeping giants, and recipes for the potions you have created to keep you right in the future.
With loads of unique ailments like Fairy Fever, Candlesick, and Yeti Chest, Apothecaria aims to capture the humour and feel of games like Theme Hospital and Stardew Valley with the cosiness and wonder of Studio Ghibli films.

Backing at the Physical level gets you:
A beautiful A5 copper-foil titled 56 page zine
5 thematic postcards featuring art by Adam "Forange" Törn 
2 postcard minigames about the secret life of Familiars and making Wands
3 A6 expansions featuring Ailments and Reagents by Chris Bissette (The Wretched, D36), Matt Sanders (Sealed Library), and Jack Harrisson (Artefact, Bucket of Bolts)
A potion sticker
And we've unlocked a 9 track OST which will have a track for each of the foraging locales!
Each new patient brings a new ailment that you will have to find a way to cure. Hover Hives, Partial Petrification, or even just a Hangover, you will have to make up a potion to cure them. Check the tags for each ailment and write them in your journal. Then, check through the regeant's list to find what plants, fungi, or animal bits you need to set them right. Once you've made your list, its time to go foraging.
There are 9 unique locales in Apothecaria where regeants can be found but it isn't a matter of just choosing the right one, you'll also have to deal with the random events found within. Sail with ghost pirates, stroll with druids, climb precarious cliff faces and trudge through magical swamps. 
Once you've managed to find your regeants, it's time to make the potion, noting down the recipe as you go. If you make it in time, the patient pays and is cured of their ailment. Use that money to upgrade your cottage with regeant farms and better tools.
If you're too slow... well, hopefully it wasn't too serious.
As you progress, you'll unlock new locales and more challenging ailments which will see you grow from Novice to Expert Witch over time.
As the seasons change, you'll also have the opportunity to go to Celebrations in the village. Go to the festive dances with an NPC of your choice, take part in sled races, baking contests, rowboat races, and even chat with old ghosts.
The changing seasons also mean that certain reagents become easier or harder to find, changing up the best recipes for potions and keeping things fresh.
Advanced Ailments (pre-playtest, not final layout)
56 pages packed full of Ailments to cure, Reagents to find, Tools to use, and Locales to explore. 
I'm going for a found journal style of thing so Apothecaria will be full of field sketches and notes from the previous witch, giving you an insight into who they were and why they disappeared. The sketches you see in the banners are the sort of things you can expect to see throughout the book.
To play you'll need: 
- A deck of playing cards
- A journal
- Something to write with
And that's it.
£2000 - Extra Art - Unlocked!
If we get this much I will commission Adam ''Forange'' Törn to create another beautiful postcard like the one being used as the cover image. The initial postcard serves as the introduction to the setting and explains more about how you've ended up the witch of High Rannoc.
£2200 - Familiar Tales & Wandcraft Postcard Games - Unlocked!
As a witch, the two most important things in your life are your familiar and your wand. These A6 size mini-games let you explore the secret life of your familiar and give you a way to create, use, and sell wands.
£2500 | £2800 | £3000 - More Art! - Unlocked!
If we get through these stretch goals I will comission more postcards that show off the special locales such as Dreamwater Depths, Blastfire Bog, The Cloud Isles, and The Strange.
£3200 - Papercraft Golem and Mimic - Unlocked!
Fold Up Toys have created an awesome papercraft of the Moonstone Crystal but there are other unique tools that I'd love to see brought to life.
£4000 - Guest Designers - Unlocked!
Once we reach this goal I will pay a few of my designer friends to write up some new ailments and reagents that expand upon the world outside of High Rannoc. The designers who have agreed to help are:
Jack Harrison - Mousehole Press
Creator of Artefact, Orbital, and Buckets of Bolts (which is on Kickstarter right now). 
Matt Sanders - Sealed Library
Creator of The Sealed Library, Glittering Hoards, Dead Emperors, and much more
Chris Bissette - Loot The Room
Creator of Wretched & Alone, Under The Floorboards, Dice Souls, and more
These guest expansions will take the form of A6 postcards with a few new ailments and reagents on each.
Hot damn those went quick.
Alright, last one.
£8000 - Unlocked! - Soundtrack by Christopher Michael Roberts
Christopher did the amazing soundtrack for Artefact and if we can get to this level, we'll be able to put together a 9 track OST with a beautiful ambient song for each locale. 
Digital Only - £6 (RRP £9)
A PDF copy of Apothecaria and a Digital Postcard welcoming you to High Rannoc as well as a print file for an awesome papercraft of the purifying Moonstone by Fold Up Toys as pictured below.

Print+ PDF Bundle - £12 (RRP £15)
An A5 saddlestich print copy of Apothecaria with a copper foil cover and a Physical Postcard welcoming you to High Rannoc as well as the rewards from the Digital Only tier. You will also get a potion sticker and a 150gsm A5 printed papercraft of the purifying Moonstone by Fold Up Toys for you to cut out and put together. (You will also get the print file.

Double Trouble - £24
Everything from the Print + PDF Bundle x 2. Two print copies filled with all the juicy stretch goals we've unlocked along the way.

Blackwell Games Bundle - £30 (RRP £36)
Get print and PDF copies of Apothecaria as well as my solo map drawing games DELVE, RISE, and UMBRA. Like the Print + PDF bundle, you'll also get a Physical Postcard, potion sticker, and a 150gsm A5 printed papercraft of the purifying Moonstone by Fold Up Toys for you to cut out and put together. (You will also get the print file.

DELIVERY

WHO AM I?
Last year I created the wildly successful DELVE which spawned two sister games RISE and UMBRA. Thanks to the support I got for those games, I've been pushing forward with game design in every way I can from designing the Staff Playbook for Artefact to publishing one page games in the Monthly Microgame Feature for Tabletop Gaming Magazine.

Hey Everyone,

For some reason, even though I re-uploaded, the new files don't seem to be appearing yet. Not sure why.

Kickstarter is acting a little weird today but hopefully this update goes out alright cause its an important one :) 
Apothecaria has finished brewing and has been poured into your emails via Backerkit! It might take a few hours to send it out to everyone who backed so don't worry if it doesn't show up immediately.
Things are so nearly finished. Just a little tweaking of the Guest Designer Postcards and the Wandcraft and Familiar Tales Postcards before they're ready for print.
I'll be getting the first proper demo print of Apothecaria tomorrow and if there are no issues with it, then we'll be going straight to print and shipping as soon as possible.

The first demo proof came through the post last week so that I could check out how some of the pages looked and my word is it beautiful... and still in need of some work. I forgot that the printed version would cut off a bit of space so I'm having to move some of the headings to make them look right.
Once I've went through this final layout pass, I'll be ordering a full proof copy and if everything looks right, I'll be ordering the print run immediately after that.

It's been a few weeks since my last update and I've discovered that I work in strange ways. Lets take May as the focus:
At the start of May, Apothecaria was handed over to the editors and I was encouraged to keep my hands off of it until editing was finished. So, to occupy myself while I'm still obsessed with Apothecaria, I put up a Patreon poll to let people vote on what the first Locale Expansion would be. The result was a close victory for Shimmersnow Valley, a once idyllic snowy valley where humans and yetis lived in peace until an Ice Queen took over with her army of snow monsters.

Good job everyone, 75% of surveys have already been filled out in just a couple of days. 
Thank you all so much.
If you're seeing this and haven't had a chance yet, why not pop over and fill out now? :)

It's been a quiet month in terms of updates. This month I've mostly been working on the cover, testing, and working out a deal with the editors (who are now working their way through Apothecaria as we speak).
I've also been doing the mind numbing and soul crushing work of setting up Backerkit and after putting everything in, I discovered that I need to contact Backerkit in order to get access to Whole Order Shipping. So hopefully they get back to me quickly and I can get it opened up by the end of the week.

So it's been a bit over a month since the Apothecaria Kickstarter wrapped so where are we at?
Done

Apothecaria is content complete but after the first round of playtesting I've gone back in to tweak and test and clarify things. As the game has this whole emergent narrative to it, it's important that the story can easily flow from event to event, preferably without each event feeling solitary and like it doesn't exist outside of itself.

Thank you all so very very very much. I am absolutely blown away by the support you've all shown for Apothecaria. I actually went away and did a happy dance which is why this update hasn't came out at the stroke of 12!

campaign.story:
BAD DECISIONS is a GM-less, horror-themed, story-telling RPG for 3-6 players. During play you become the hapless characters the audience shouts “NO! DON’T GO IN THERE!” to.

In traditional role-playing games, you often want to do the smartest, safest thing to survive. But here at Arbitrio Games we like our heroes curious, irresponsible, and extremely mortal. The whole point of BAD DECISIONS is to get yourselves killed doing something terribly idiotic.

Over the course of a couple hours, our ill-fated characters are placed in a situation rife for foolishness, such as ghost hunters exploring Colonial Williamsburg or teens trespassing at a dinosaur mini-golf. In this rules-light game, players take turns narrating, rolling dice, and making BAD DECISIONS until you are no longer just hinting at danger: danger is chasing you through a cornfield with a machete.
  From there things start to move fast. We shift our focus from narration to a modified version of Liar's Dice, where anyone who gets eliminated gets...err...eliminated. Soon it’s head-to-head and there’s just two of you left. That's when we answer the question:

Are you the Final Girl or were you the Secret Mastermind all along?
draft version of cover
 BAD DECISIONS will be a 5.5" x 8.5", full-color, saddle-stitched zine.
We plan to ship via the USPS, media or First-Class mail for the US and First-Class Mail International for all other countries.
Shipping charges will be handled through Kickstarter. Shipping will be collected alongside your pledge. International orders may encounter additional duties and taxes.
Feel free to reach-out with any shipping questions!
Arbitrio Games is Michael Faulk, Jeff Mitchell, and Scott Slater. We are three friends who have fun making up games and adventure ideas. Our designs (Ghost Room, Wizard Student Council) have been featured in the ENnie nominated “Traged13s of Middle School”. 
An early version of “BAD DECISIONS” was recently featured in the Free RPG Day “Level 1” Collection, a showcase for Indie RPGs. For this product, we have expanded the game with art, rules enhancements, a variant ending, and random tables to help you create your own horror story.
 Project / Cover Image by Daniel Jensen on Unsplash

updates.update_userinfo: Update for April 2021 - The Decisions Just Keep on Coming!
updates.update_content:
Like a hapless teen squeezing through a rapidly closing door in the hopes that they can escape the haunted manor, we come to you at the very end of April to give you our monthly update.  Have we made it outside? Maybe not ALL the way (the haunted manor is large, and growing larger by the hour), but we are making progress. Here's where we're at:
Postcard Stories - Drafted!  We are very happy with how our weird little microfiction exercises have gone, and we're excited to write each individualized story on postcards and inflict them upon you (and only you).  
Bad Decision Imagery - We have wandered the bleak landscape of New England taking grim photographs that we plan to use both for the postcards we send out to you, and to supplement the images we have in the zine already.

Time flies when you’re running down an ever-elongating hallway with a knife enthusiast in hot pursuit. It’s hard to believe a month has gone by already!  We have been hard at work drafting postcards and working on rules clarifications based on some variant play sessions.  We’re also working on making sure that the PDF fulfillment will be as smooth and easy as possible. Still very much on target for that September 2021 fulfillment. When we are happy with the layout and ready to send out the backer survey, we will send out a notice. In the meantime, if you have any questions, please feel free to send a message over.  You guys are the best!

We have done it!  Our gratitude is as deep as the yawning chasm we found at an abandoned carnival. We set a small, attainable goal that we felt good about achieving - the fact that we are over 600% funded certainly changes the scale of the printing, but not the timeline. As this was our first Kickstarter, we wanted to avoid the potential pitfalls of stretch goals etc. That said, we really do want to make this the best product we can, and so we are expanding content as we go along (which changes our layout a little bit, but that was going to happen anyway).

With the inevitability of a Johnny Cash murder ballad, our campaign draws to a close. The murderer crashes through the wall, the spider prince cackles as he releases his minions into the mineshaft, the ghostly little girl begins to sing that all too familiar lullaby. Although our stories have a messy and complicated ending, we are very happy with the outcome of this phase in our project.

We are ready and excited for what comes next - beginning the process of getting this zine into your hands. As we go, we look forward to providing you updates with our timeline and tell the not-so-bad-decisions tale of three friends who made a game and put it into the world. And despite sounding repetitive, the sentiment remains - Thank you to all of our backers, both old friends and new! We are incredibly grateful to share this game with as many people as possible. Your support is invaluable!

One week down and wowzers, have our expectations been exceeded! This is the magic of ZineQuest. We know it’s really hard for a company without an established following to get a product looked at - let alone funded. But the ZineQuest community wants to find something new. It wants to be surprised and this event shines a light on surprises.

We’re beyond excited to get this game in your hands. I’ve loved horror movies since forever. I remember my dad letting me watch Cujo when I was way too young. I remember going to the video store and picking out a couple spooky VHS tapes with my best friend and him falling asleep 20 minutes into the first one, so I was watching it alone. These days, there’s a lot of schlock out there, but there’s always a chance of finding something different, unique.

Today was a rollercoaster. At the time of this writing we are at 229% - full funding and then some! (I have had to update this statistic literally four times already.) We are beyond excited to have reached our goal; it means that we will be able to print and distribute our cathartic little horror RPG. And we couldn’t have done it without the help of our backers! We are humbled to have experienced such generosity, and we promise to deliver the best product that we can to you. For your support, for your likes and shares, and for your encouraging comments, thank you, thank you, thank you!

campaign.story:
The Sun's Ransom is a poetic, tragic RPG where you play vampires determined to bring back the sun.
PREMISE
The world has gone dark and the mortals are consumed by the need for warmth, light and power. It is up to you, who do not need life or warmth or light or power, to ransom the sun, despite the cost. You must go against your vampiric nature and remember what brought Light and Joy to your mortal self. That is the blood-price for the sun.

MECHANICS
The Sun's Ransom is a GMless roleplaying game (or RPG) where you take the role of vampires. You will roll large dice pools and do no more complex maths than counting sixes. You begin by collaboratively creating your world and the kinds of beings, mortal and vampire, fill it. Then you create your character by deciding who they were in life and who they have become in undeath. Narrative play proceeds in rounds, where one player is the active player and the rest help to construct and obstruct the vampire's efforts to complete a task that once brought them Light and Joy. Resolution is via a simple dice pool: beginning with as many dice as can cover the sun on the cover. As play continues and vampires succeed in their Light and Joy tasks, dice are removed from the face of the sun, diminishing the vampires' power. The game is over when all the dice are removed, leaving the vampires vulnerable and scorched.
Black and White mock-up of The Sun's Ransom
REWARDS
The Sun's Ransom has both physical and digital versions. The physical version will be risograph printed. Riso is a lovely printing method with a very distinctive aesthetic and as a result the digital copy will have a scanned PDF of a risograph print copy, as well as designed-for-PDF versions. The zine will be 16 pages and A6, which is almost pocket- or purse-sized! As with fitting with ZineQuest's rules, we will only be using one ink colour (red). There is both international and domestic (I'm based in Australia) shipping for physical editions, which will be paid for through Kickstarter's shipping functions. Expect $4 AUD for international shipping and $2 AUD for shipping within Australia.

STRETCH GOALS
At the moment, we have no stretch goals planned. This is to prevent project creep and to make sure that the zine is completed well.
The entire team is based on Whadjuk Noongar land, in Western Australia.

PIDJ SORENSEN
I'm Pidj, the writer, designer and project manager. I have done a number of my own TTRPG projects, including being one of 40 designers published in The Ultimate Micro-RPG Book. You can find me talking about my ZineQuest project on twitter @PidjSorensen.

TARA WILLOW
"I’m Tara, my traditional works feature natural subjects with an illusive twist."
Tara is working on the cover illustration, as in the preview image. Instagram: @twillow_artist

GRIM
"I’m Grim, primarily a digital illustrator who specializes in the macabre and creepy."
Grim will be doing some internal art for The Sun's Ransom. Instagram: @GrimCorvid

NEIGHBOURHOOD PRESS
Based in Fremantle,  Neighbourhood Press is a Risograph printing press and creative studio run by Nora Mironov and Scott Alexander. Neighbourhood Press work to serve small businesses and creatives across all disciplines to produce quality Risograph reproductions, from prepress illustration and design assistance through to production and finishing. They can be found on instagram @NeighbourhoodPress.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Any project involved with physical production and distribution is subject to potential risks. Neighbourhood Press, the risograph press, have done many projects before and have no worries regarding this one, but COVID and lockdowns remain a factor that could possibility cause delays. Delays in art or editing are more likely, and would have a flow-on effect in delaying printing and fulfilment. However, we have plans in place to avert this, and any delays will result in no extra costs. Due to the small scope of the project, we're confident that we will be able to get it to you without significant delays! Postage is all done by us, so will be slower than through a fulfilment company, but we've factored that in. We have no stretch goals, which will prevent project creep.

campaign.env:
Environmental commitments
Visit our Environmental Resources Center to learn how Kickstarter encourages sustainable practices.
Sustainable materials
The risograph-printed zines use soy-based inks and 100% recycled, uncoated paper.
Environmentally friendly factories
Neighbourhood Press says with regards to sustainable production: 

"The print method is highly energy efficient, with it being an entirely cold process consuming 95% less energy than toner based printers and emitting zero greenhouse gasses. As well as this the inks used in the process are all soy-based and non-toxic which make them easily recyclable and free from nasty by-products. 

The printing process uses stencils (or masters) that are made from a thermal sensitive biodegradable banana fibre sheet and unlike offset printing it only takes a single print for the screen to be fully inked and ready to print thousands of copies.

campaign.story:
Tales of the Glass Gnomes is a journey inside the mythical mineshaft of the Glass Gnomes, a recluse community of glassblowers hidden in the desert. Presented as a lore zine / journal, the publication contains the story of this unique gnome society, many drawings and descriptions of their inventions, an insider's look of their mine and even a few of their secret glass formulas. All of this seen through the joyful perspective of the famous bard Nolet Coudfoudre. 
Tales of the Glass Gnomes is a guide for storytellers who want to include this peculiar community in their existing TTRPG game, make an exciting one-shot inspired by the mine's events or include a quest to retrieve a long lost artifact of the forgotten race. This being said, anyone who enjoys reading fantasy short stories, D&D / TTRPG books, myths, esoteric or alchemical volumes should enjoy it, I'm quite sure.
This zine is written with a world building focus first and game compatibility second. The publication itself isn't tied to any TTRPG system, but aims to be compatible with OSR, 5E and Troika through stretch goals.  
Includes The Salamander and the Genie, the myth behind the ascent of the Glass Gnomes.
An insider's look of the mineshaft, with details on their mighty glass forge, the magnificent lantern hall, their advance astronomy lab and the dangerous black jade vein.
Presentations of the most illustrious gnomes that lived within the settlement.
 12 unconventional inventions and legendary artifacts with their descriptions.
 5 glass formulas that infuse magical or optical properties to their objects.
A table of hooks and stories to guide your player on a journey down the mine
Many threats and wildlife beasts living around the clan's den.
between 24-32 pages.
 A5 size, folded and stapled with a gorgeous cardboard cover.
all physical copies come with a printer friendly PDF version.
hand drawn, journal style sketches along with eerie art by the wonderful Perplexing Ruins.  
Illustration by Perplexing Ruins
PDF Version : You will receive Tales of the Glass Gnomes in a handy digital (and printer friendly) PDF version.
Physical Version : You will receive Tales of the Glass Gnomes as a printed zine! A real tome that you can read with a glass of whiskey and display in your library! .. and you get the previous reward as well!
Deluxe Version : You receive all of the above AND a beautiful 16"x20" print of the mineshaft's plan, ready for your next adventure! 
Lantern Edition: You are now part of the Glass Gnomes legacy! Your name is immortalized in the zine's as you are now the maker of a lamp on display in the Lantern Hall. And of course you get the digital + physical version AND the mineshaft plan! 
 + 300$ : 5 Troika backgrounds with inspiring portraits.
 + 650$ : A complete one-shot guide happening within the Glass Gnome settlement! Will come with an adventure map detailing each room, encounters, traps and treasure. (Compatible with Troika, easily adaptable with OSR and 5E)
We might add more stretch goals based on the campaign success and the comments from our backers.
This publication is inspired in part by Nathan Harrison's Forking Paths, Cavern of heresy's Rogueland, Troika! and other beautiful TTRPG publications. I very much like their straightforward approach with beautiful, simple writing that will spark the flame in just about any storyteller or game master. I'm also a big fan of Fiddler's Green, a periodical magazine about magic, folk legends, esoteric and art topics.
The prices cover the shipping fees and the mailing enveloppe required for each zine.

campaign.story:
I couldn't stay away.
ZineQuest is a really cool initiative, and I've never participated.
So, I made a zine. Not fancy. It's all very DIY and all the work is done by me. I've been noodling on hacking up a d100 OGL system for a while, and I'd been tinkering with the ruleset during down hours. So I sat down and finished it, did some layout stuff on it, and built this Kickstarter page, all in six hours. 
Short of drawing all the art myself, it doesn't get more DIY than that. (I debated drawing the art myself, but I figured I'd spare you.)
So. Swordpoint is a d100 swashbuckling-themed zine using the Legend OGL (from Mongoose Publishing). The tone and theme is inspired by Musketeers, Captain Alatriste, and European Continent around the 1600s, as well as older games like En Garde, Flashing Blades, and more.
The rules are condensed to about 60 pages in a 5"x8" landscape format. I always wanted to try a landscape book, and I like how they read on tablets and phones, so I figured why not.
I did all the layout myself, so it's not super fancy, but I tried to keep it simple and functional. 
What it has:
The rules you need to play. A hacked d100 system (it'll feel familiar if you know d100 RPGs.)
New rules for this iteration of the d100 RPG: Style points. Streamlined combat. A lightweight magic system. 
Genre rules for grudges, revenge, rank, duels, and some enemies (not many enemies though. Like 3.)
A planned compatibility license.
 PDF bookmarks. I just learned how to do that this morning!
Character sheet mock-up I made. We'll see.
What it doesn't have:
Lots of rules.
Lots of art. Most of the art is from Shutterstock or public domain. There's only like 5-6 pieces in the book total, just to fill white space.
Fancy layout. Remember: DIY and I am not a layout artist. It should be pretty straightforward and easy to read though.
Stretch goals (at least right now.)
The writing is probably kinda dry. I wrote in very technical style, 'cause I was inspired by older RPGs (one of my proof-readers even commented on that, so I figure I'll warn you.)
Layout Sample

The Plan
Once we close, I'll send the PDF out to backers to submit feedback. I think we got most of the errors, but I've learned not to count on that. I'll incorporate the feedback. Then we'll go to print and delivery. No muss, no fuss. 
Shipping
Physical is shipping to the US only. Sorry. It sucks and I hate having to restrict it but it's too easy to lose money or get caught unawares by shipping changes (hey Brexit.) 
Extra will be available via the GKG webstore after the campaign though, so if you want, you can get it then and we'll try to give you the best rate possible. 
GKG has shipped thousands of packages, so it should be pretty straightforward.

We want to help everyone to spend more time playing and have less time preparing!

Ramp & Winch Accessible Ship

campaign.story:
I remember the 1990s in Eugene, Oregon. For some reason, there were a lot of punks whipping up zines at Kinko's on Willamette Street. They always seemed to congregate around 3:00am, arriving like a murder of crows to the 24 hour copy shop and public bathroom.
Between cheap cigarettes and even cheaper mini-cigars, these night time characters would print off a dozen copies of their topical zine. "The Alamo" was a popular punk show spot, or the vaguely infamous "Icky's Tea House."
I'm old now, and have achy knees, and definitely go to bed before 3:00am. But I'm still game for Zinequest 3, so here we are.

Roll Them Bones
Roll Them Bones are a set of two postzines. They're postcards, they're zines, they have mini-games for your maxi-games. Each postzine has two mini-games based on dice. Give me $3 + shipping, I'll send you either the "Criminal" or "Wreckers" themed postzine. Give me $5 + shipping and I'll send ya both.

Listen Up, Chummer
There's a really important thing here, and you need to listen. These are postcards. They are not arriving in a padded envelope, I'm not carefully packaging them for later viewing. I'd honestly be surprised if any of these things still exist in 20 years.

How Does This Work?
I'm slapping a stamp on each of your postcards and sending them out as soon as the Kickstarter finishes, and then in a week or whatever your mini-game postzine shows up in your mailbox.

campaign.story:
The Year is 2069...
The setting is Great Britain. The Tories have been in power since 2010. 
Due to National Health Service cuts, trans healthcare has become increasingly hard to access. The waiting list for a first appointment at a gender identity clinic is now 300 years. They don’t want to outright refuse you; that would imply that the health service is over capacity or underfunded. Instead they will simply add you to the end of the list and wait for you to die. 
But they are fools. For you have learned the secrets of immortality. And you will get to the end of that waiting list, even if it means waiting another millennium.

cover image


The Game
Lichcraft is a rules-light tabletop RPG set up to be played with 2 or more players. The play is inspired by Forged in the Dark systems, with a simple D6-pool resolution mechanic. Instead of choosing classes or players, characters begin by choosing their politics, hobby, day job, and magical source, and use attributes from these to add to their dice rolls. 
Give this game a try if you like dystopian settings, collaborative world-building and play,  magic wielding queer characters,  interesting and individualistic ways of spellcasting, and undeath as a metaphor for... something.

Premise
In this game, you play trans characters in dystopian Britain,  50 years in the future.  You have been trapped at the bottom of a waiting list for vital gender affirming healthcare. The list is far longer than a mortal human lifespan. 
As a result you have decided to pursue lichdom. Over the course of the game you will gather all the components for the ritual necessary to become an undead creature of great arcane power, at which point you may either transform yourselves however you choose, or wait things out in your new immortal bodies- you have all the time in the world.
This is a game about spite, necromancy, being trans, and a 300 year long NHS waiting list. Although the game itself deals with serious themes, it is set up to be tongue-in-cheek, satirical, super queer, and intimate. 
a basic character sheet
What You're Backing
The core game has already been written and is available to download on itch.io. Backers will all get access to the digital PDF, available as soon as I can send you a backer email. This kickstarter will enable new layout and art for the current game, as well as the printing of a physical zine for #zinequest3. 

The zine itself will be printed on A5, with one colour (neon pink) and interior and exterior illustrations.  It includes core rules, play examples, safety tools, a character sheet, and adventure generation tables, as well a a set of rituals to help with your ascent into lichdom. 

You are also backing a cool project produced by  a trans writer and contributed to by trans and disabled artists and writers. That's it. 

Stretch Goals
£900 : More art! Interior illustrations for Lichcraft will be added to by Ema (@spookymeal) Ema is an amazing trans artist and game writer who draws beautiful characters. You can check out her work here: https://spookymeal.tumblr.com/ 

£1000: Expanded Rituals page by Sam D (@sdunnewold) Sam is the  writer of Doskvol Breathes, and their writing is incredibly thoughtful, emotional, and reflective. The ritual pages for Lichcraft already offer a chance for players and characters to reflect on the game, their own identities, and their experiences in the process of lich ascension. An additional rituals page from Sam would expand this and give more options for the game's conclusion. You can find Sam's work at https://stone-arch-bridge-troll.itch.io/ 

£1,600: More art by Kristen (@KristenChin8) Kristen is the cover artist and, if we meet this stretch goal, I'll be able to pay her to illustrate each title section of the zine. Any more money raised after this will just go towards paying everyone involved in the project more.  

And our new 10k stretch goal: 4 alternate quarter page settings for th game!
At £10,000, the final zine will include four quarter page alternate settings for lichcraft- each with their own unique vibe and one additional d6 table. Lichcraft 4069: a Wargamepunk alternate Britain, featuring an immortal queen ruling with an iron fist, and many, many trans orcs. LICHCRAFT IMPERIUM: The Year is 269 AD. Long have the romans held dominion over your province. But you and your super queer gang of raiders are going to change all that. And also become liches. Lichcraft 1869: A Western version of lichcraft, trans cowboys* robbing trains and taking names. Lichcraft 200069: Trans space pirates taking on the space tories. It’ll work, I promise .
Spotlights
One of the amazing things about Zinequest are all the fantastic creators and projects involved. I want to take a second to highlight some of them: go check out, and back, these pages. I'm gonna be adding more to this list throughout ZQ: please send me your recs!

Crescent Moon  is an adventure RPG about brave children and their dreams, shadows, and discoveries.
This Night on the Rooftops is a game about gazing out over the smokestacks after dark, with the wind in your hair and a friend at your side and a thousand lights of progress on the streets below.
Tomb of Immolation is an exploration of an ancient prison-tomb that has been partially flooded with lava.
External Containment Bureau is a tabletop roleplaying game of paranormal investigation and bureaucracy.
High Speed Low Drag is a solo journalling TTRPG that follows the career of an elite soldier on and off the battlefield.

campaign.story:
Nagara is old, the city is dying, and you are the only one who can ward off the Doom.
City of Flesh is a tarot-based roleplay game where you play one of the Midwives, a person imbued with primordial energy, tasked with staving off the end of the world as you know it. Together with your fellow players and GM, you create the city of Nagara and its unique locations using a tarot deck. Each session your characters inch ever closer to a Doom they’re working tirelessly to prevent, but must inevitably face as the chronicle ends.
The game has the dark horror feeling of a dungeon crawl, while focusing on mechanics that drive in-game drama and push personal stories. You’ll get embroiled in the various wars raging between guilds in the city and try to secure a bit of personal peace, before all your efforts crumble around you. You’ll strive to survive in a city that is literally trying to eat you, and siphon off its power to keep the ones you love safe.
City of Flesh takes inspiration from grimdark fantasy combining it with a feminine aesthetic to create an immersive gore-splattered roleplay experience where you delve into the dreams of a sleeping colossus and tear through fleshy reality to make your own fate.
What You’ll Get

City of Flesh is an A5 sized, 50+ page, soft cover zine. We've paid attention to paper quality and the zine will have a glorious hand-feel. PDFs will be distributed through DriveThruRPG and physical zines will be sent through the Dutch national mail service. 
Shipping is free, we've calculated the costs into our funding goal.
Within the zine is:
A complete grimdark femmecore setting for you and your friends to build upon
A full set of unique tarot-based mechanics to run your game
A guide on how to interpret the cards for your game
An immersive safety mechanic to keep the game safe and fun for everyone at the table
If you'd like additional physical copies of the game add €15 to your pledge for each additional copy. We'll send PDF codes along with the additional copies ordered.
Take a look at the stretch goals we unlocked!
2,500: UNLOCKED - Monster generator 
3,500: UNLOCKED - Encounter generator
5,000: UNLOCKED - All Stretch Goals printed and added to physical pledges
 6,500: UNLOCKED - Proofing
  Welcome to Nagara
Nagara, the City of Flesh, dominates the Plains of Bone. The world is young, the Age of Titans draws to a close, but the city is ancient. Built in the womb of the slain Colossus, Nagara is both rich and powerful—and already past its prime. A Doom approaches Nagara, as the world rebirths itself into a new, more rational form in which there’s place for neither Titans, nor cities built atop their rotting remains. To facilitate this transition, the city’s dreams birthed the Midwives—people imbued with some of the city’s primordial energy who must guide it to whatever comes next.
The Colossus is dead by any measure of human life, and yet she isn’t— she still undulates with primordial creation, heaving and oozing to form a protective shell around Nagara. The magic of the Sovereigns keeps her dormant, as does the life-leeching magic of lesser citizens and their efforts to keep flesh at bay with fire and blade. Entire city blocks still live under overhangs of flesh as a result of the Years of Suffering, with some citizens carving houses into the red tissue.
The need to drive back the Colossus’ flesh becomes more dire as Nagara expands. Sovereign Nemaida offers rewards to explorers who venture in the necrotic parts of the city to slay monsters and burn away the flesh. The Midwives often find themselves called to the danger the endeavor promises, for there is plenty that can go wrong.
How It's Played
Nagara is dying and will be reborn. At the start of the game you map the city by performing a three-card reading for each location in the city. You’ll map seven locations and then place a single card on the Blooded Sanctum, the Doom—the end of your story. Each location represents one session (roughly four hours) of your game, therefore you’ll play seven sessions before the eighth final session where you encounter the city’s Doom.
At the start of every session players pick a location focus—this is the location the game session is crafted around. The GM crafts the plot of the session based around the conflict and threat of the location.
During the game players perform more readings, drawing a tarot card from the deck, to modify the scenes based on how characters act. Readings help facilitate the drama in your character’s life. Depending on how your Reading turns out, you and/or the GM ascribe meaning to the card drawn.
Example of Play
The Midwives are caught in a waking nightmare of terror and blood where an unhinged Relic stalks and murders people in their sleep. Steffie’s character Torga realizes maybe the Relic can be reasoned with, she asks the Relic if they can help it in some way. Liz, the GM, asks Steffie to make a Pacify reading, because Torga is trying to connect with the Relic.
Steffie draws the Five of Swords. 
The Relic explains that it's enraged, not because it can’t fulfill its destiny, but more because it loved Hydrassa deeply and hates seeing her body so defiled.  Torga reveals she knows the sting of unrequited love too and swears to help. Seeing another being who knows its pain, the Relic asks Torga to take action by returning Hydrassa’s body to her burial tomb. 
Nice to meet you!
Steffie de Vaan is a Dutch author and developer of role playing games and short stories. She developed the Legendlore RPG and V5: Fall of London, and has written for many other settings including Vampire the Masquerade, Changeling the Lost, Exalted, and Harlem Unbound. She loves horror, fantasy, sci-fi stories, and their cross genres in any medium; watching short films and tutorials on YouTube; and inclusive feminism.
Elizabeth Chaipraditkul is the owner of Angry Hamster Publishing and her new game Afterlife: Wandering Souls won an Indie Groundbreaker Award for best setting in 2020. She was the lead developer of the Crescent Empire book for 7th Sea by John Wick Presents, and has written for companies such as Onyx Path Publishing, Chaosium, and Modiphius Entertainment. When not in her own imaginary world Liz keeps busy with crafting and walking her dog. You can find out more about her games at angryhamsterpublishing.com and follow her on Twitter @angryhamsterrpg.
We both live in the Netherlands and met during a freelance writing project for the same company. Together we have a Patreon that supports the game design work we produce together and last year we ran a successful Make/100 Kickstarter that raised over $9,000 and was fulfilled by Liz’s company - Angry Hamster Publishing.

campaign.story:
What is This?
The Tower & The Garden is a 44 page roleplaying game for zine quest about struggling and surviving in a city (The Garden) grown from the refuse of a fortress of opulence and exclusion (The Tower). You’ll play as cyborgs, mech pilots, magic wielders, and rabble rousers pitted against varied factions who are all vying for control over the Garden: demon lords, criminal enterprises, cultists, and a corporate-sponsored fascist state.
The Cover
Setting
Ravenous supernatural beasts roam the streets at night and cruel imperial soldiers march in the light of the day. Infrastructure and utilities are controlled by wealthy corporations based in the Tower, and the promise of admittance is used to exploit the masses who live in the Garden.
No one remembers how the world ended, but it did. Generations ago. The Tower was built before then. Back then it served as a testament to humanity’s innovative engineering capabilities. When all of the cities were destroyed, it remained standing, and was a beacon of hope, offering its strength and shelter to travelers from near and far. But then the doors slammed shut and the refugee camps surrounding it grew and grew. They grew so large that they merged together into a sprawling city now known as The Garden.
Last year, the self-coronated Emperor of the Iron Tower took a portion of their advanced military machine and went on a pointless crusade against a distant demon lord. Corporations have exerted their control and use the remaining military forces to quell uprisings and protect the exposed people of the Garden from demon attacks, while ignoring the basic human needs of the populace. The scene is set for guardians defenders to rise and protect the populace, or at the very least get what’s coming to them.
The Enhanced Character Class
The Rules
The Tower & The Garden is based on a highly modified, somewhat simplified Forged in the Dark SRD. There is no system for reducing stress, thus characters who are pushed to their limits must change, and bear the scars of their experiences.
The Armored player class, illustrated by Galen Pejeau
Stretch Goals
We have some incredible stretch goals!
$2250 - Demon lord descriptions written by Jordan Shiveley! Jordan is well known for his evocative writing for the Dread Singles (@hottestsingles) twitter account, and has written for many games including The Spire, Emberwind, and City of Mist. His upcoming book of fictions, Hot Singles In Your Area, will be published later this year.
$2350 - Monster descriptions written by P.A. Wikoff! P.A. Wikoff is the author of the Tarnished Lands series of novellas, Feylin Lore: Reflections, and the Imprisoned Online LitRPG series. His stories exude humor and darkness.
$3500 - A one-shot actual play stream will be organized and run by Levon Jihanian! Players will be paid and production quality will be sought out!

campaign.story:
They are so proud, as they build, swarming ever higher and further in pursuit of the prize they call "progress"! Up, into the thick clouds of smog their own machines spew over the dissolute, willfully wasteful city. Outward, across orderly farms and ruined forests and stripped earth, long since plundered, the robbery boasted of as innovation. 
But never down, for below the city, the catacombs wait, the bones within of ancestors and older things, the creatures that slip through the shadows between the infrequent torches the fading remnants of the days before electricity, before newspapers and printing presses and steam-powered engines.
And one shadow, ancient and cold, watches for the venal cracks in fragile souls eager to secure their fortunes for the meager price of their own damnation. An ancient mystery, who calls to the weak-willed and to those willing to bargain, beckoning ever deeper into the dark.
Can you hear it? 
Where Mystery Dwells is a darkly whimsical catacomb crawl through a candlelit world of stone and bones beneath a fantastical-industrial city, one where eccentric patrons demand their apprentices shine the heavy, noxious electric arc lamps of progress on ancient mysteries at any cost, and where those mysteries retaliate with obsession and madness.
It features a high-stakes cyclic solo and duet system, partly inspired by Blades in the Dark and The Skeletons, where you play a troupe of apprentices balancing their own survival and sanity against the need to curry favor with their patron. It also has system-agnostic tools for procedurally generating vaguely disturbing catacombs, creating the colorful city, and populating both with a cast of empathetic and engaging characters.
This kickstarter is to fund a printed-and-shipped version, possibly through Mixam or a local printer, but I'm also considering rolling up my sleeves and digging into my stash of FSC-certified coverstock, mixed media, and that really nice copy paper I accidentally bought way too much of to prepare for sudden home schooling. And I have some limited stocks of the really good stuff (think "French Paper Co.") for the "one of a kind" copies.
Note: "hand-embellished" means splashes of watercolor, mixed media, hand-made stamps, and enthusiasm! Only choose the "one of a kind" option if you want a truly limited edition, one of a kind version.
Stretch goals include hiring artists, custom character sheets, more community copies, more of the limited tier options, and (out there) a custom oracle deck.

updates.update_content:
Hi everybody! Just wanted to touch in and let you know the PDF is lookin' sharp. And lookin' quirky. Just waiting on the bespoke art at this point, and squashing typos, and then it's time to manifest some physical goodness. This'll be my first time navigating the choppy seas of printing-a-bunch-at-once, and of DIY zine-ness, but we're a bit ahead of schedule (famous last words?) and I'm confident!
Oh, and for our overseas friends, I do plan on putting the files up on Lulu, which still offers saddlestitch, after the KS is fully settled.
Happy summer-is-coming!!!

Now that things have died down a bit after ZQ's wrapped, I just wanted to check in to let you all know I'm still hard at work! Art and text are in, pdf is being edited, and I'm negotiating the new-to-me waters of finding the best method of printing I can for the mailed-out copies. 
And the initial print & foil prototypes of the white cover on black French Paper Co paper look fabulous! My camera doesn't do it justice.

Thank you! Thanks so much for supporting this project, and believing in it, and supporting and enjoying Zinequest3 and small indie designers like me! Big round of high-fives!
I'll be updating often, as I keep working and get the physical end of things organized. I can't wait to get these all polished up and in the mail!
Stay safe and warm out there!

An early thanks to everyone! This has been such a great experience, and I'm looking forward to bringing this project to physical reality!
I'm hard at work on layout, writing content, and preparing more art from public domain sources, as well as putting feelers out for some bespoke pieces. We're sitting at 44 or so sleek pages, a bit under half devoted to "the game" and the necessary bits, and the rest system-agnostic tables, setting generators, and monsters. I am packing those tables in!

Thank you, everyone! What a thrilling process this has been so far! I am so excited to bring this project to life with you all! I'll look at getting some stretch goals up, and some previews out soon. Have a great weekend!

campaign.story:
If you're anything like me, you're trans as hell and thrice as furious. 
These zines are for you. 
The Trans Rage Trilogy
The Trans Rage Trilogy is a group of three zines written and produced by me, Lara Turner of Glaive Guisarme Games. 
 Let's Rob RJ McElhenny and Steal Her Golden Quill: A wish-fulfillment heist that pits  wizards against a young-adult fantasy author.
 Penis 2.0.77 -or- A Genital Customization Game Roughly a Billion Times more Cyberpunk Than That Other One, Written by an Honest-to-Goodness Trans Woman Who Didn't Even Work Weekends: Exactly what it sounds like.
 To Stand Before the Dragon's Wrath: A quick, narrative story game that pits you (yes, you!) against the dragon who has been forcing you to live under their regime. 
I'm celebrating ZineQuest by releasing physical copies of my angriest, transiest games, and (because it's ZineQuest 3, baybee!) adding in a revised and updated zine-formed version of a game I wrote back when I thought I was a boy, and have only now recognized the Big Trans Energy coming from. 
Look at these furious zines!
Heck yeah! There's more details about the individual games below, but first let's talk about the broad details.
My goal is to take three games that bring me great joy, and send as many copies as possible out into the world. Maybe they'll get played? Maybe they'll change lives? Or maybe they'll get picked up by another trans person who will have a little chuckle about the shared understanding of it all. These are all great outcomes! 
As a backer at the $10 level, you will get digital copies of all three zines; each is sixteen-pages, black and white, and set up for both A4 and 8.5"x11" paper, sent straight to your digital doorstep at the end of the campaign, along with screen-readable copies. In addition, you will get immediate access to the betas of all three zines! These are 99% done, but may be subject to final layout and word tweaking. 
At the $20 level you get the good stuff: a physical copy of any zine! Choose whichever one makes you feel most euphoric. And hey, you still get the digital copies immediately, so you can read them all and pick your favorite at the end of the campaign when I send out the surveys. 
And if you pledge $40, you get the entire trilogy. That's right, if you're going to buy two, you get the third one for free, whether you want it or not! This is my real goal here, getting you wonderful folks out there get a full triple-barreled blast of my Feelings. 
This is a strictly one-woman affair, so that means I will be printing these out on my very own home laser printer, stapling them with my very own longarm stapler, and sending them to you through the United States Postal Service, First Class Mail. 
I'm Lara! This is the fourth time I've launched a Kickstarter, but the first time I've done so as an out-and-proud transgirl (with the previous three having been run in states of "completely in the closet," "completely in denial," and "completely oblivious"). There's a fun rule-of-3 going on here, isn't there? I kickstarted 3 games as Ed, and now I'm doing 3 more as Lara, right here on ZineQuest 3! 
ANYWAY. In addition to being trans, I'm a professional tabletop game developer; I've published a bunch of indies as Glaive Guisarme Games, but also worked professionally on a number of games, including Acute Paranoia for Mongoose Publishing, Eldritch Century for Draco Studios, and bunch of games for Evil Hat Productions who were the first to put my real name on a game, Fate Condensed. 
I came out six months ago. It was very dramatic. It's been a rough six months in a lot of ways, but on the whole, even when I'm miserable, I've never been happier. Highly recommended. 
Okay, okay, let's take a look at the three games that make up the Trans Rage Trilogy.
You have, for some time, had a bone to pick with RJ McElhenny, author of a series of extremely popular young-adult fantasy novels, but lately she's been saying extremely reductive things about who she thinks deserves to be called a wizard. So, as a bunch of magic-users who she would describe as "it's okay for them to call themselves wizards but they're not really wizards," you're going to heist the hell out of her mansion. 
Let's Rob RJ McElhenny and Steal Her Golden Quill is the "angry" part of trans rage. Fuck politeness, let's smash some shit.
Inspired by an author whose name I currently forget, this here is a wish-fulfillment magic heist. Move through the randomly-generated rooms of McElhenny Manor and confront the obstacles she's thrown in your way with your awesome magic powers (which is to say, describe how cool you are and chuck some dice to see if it's cool enough or if you have to describe an even more awesome spell). If you start running low on magic energy, talk about how mad you are at McElhenny and you'll be ready to take on another room. 
This game was originally released in July of 2020, because That Author was in the public sphere for some reason or another and I was full of feelings that I wasn't quite sure how to express. It would be nice if this game were to stop being relevant, but I just learned she's going to be drawing paychecks for a TV show that's gonna keep her in the public sphere and frankly it looks like "getting mad at That Author" is a pretty evergreen situation. Blech. Anyway. This re-release includes:
Revised rules, including replacing "flashbacks" with a simpler, quicker method of regaining Action dice
Cleaned-up layout and a prettier cover 
My actual name on it because when I first released it I wasn't out yet and didn't know whaaaaat to put on it
This is a handsome sixteen-page zine, black ink on off-white paper (the most maaaaagical color of paper), folded, stapled, and delivered to your door so you can perform your own magic revenge. 
Get this one if you want to feel like a real cool wizard doing some cool crimes with your wizard buddies.
Welcome to the cyber-future, chummer. Is it everything you wanted it to be? Has all the hype really given way to a fully-realized universe with acceptable levels of optimization and a minimum of crashes? The streets are lawless, the corps own your soul, and "hope" has lost all meaning, but it's a sweet-ass transhumanist future so even if you don't have control of your life, you still have control of your sex and gender. Probably got a hell of a menu to choose from, right?
Penis 2.0.77 is the "manic" part of trans rage. Nothing makes sense, so make it your own and giggle at the absurdity.
Inspired by a popular AAA video game that had (and let us be extremely generous here) mixed results in its depictions of trans people. This is as far as I can tell, the most complex and full-featured series of crotch-related tables ever put into a zine. There's no other "game" here, but there are lots of bad jokes about wobbly bits. Written in a fugue state late in 2020, I have a few regrets about the initial presentation. Most notably, I accidentally aped the last few centuries of male-dominated medical research by almost totally discounting the clitoris. This revision remedies that, and includes:
More genital variables, taking us up to approximately 4 trillion different configurations
Parts synergies, which will make random crotches hew slightly closer to "expected" without hampering custom design potential
Re-balanced parts costs, to prevent you from accruing too much MegaCorp MegaDebt
For the purposes of transparency, especially with respect to "what you can and cannot launch a Kickstarter for," let me be clear: there is no pornography here. There are no photos or drawings of nude people or anatomical features, nor anything that could be considered "erotica." It's charts with crotch jokes, and RPG jokes, and cyberpunk jokes. You can create a character (sort of) but the real goal here is cathartic giggling about the inherent strangeness of the human underwear-zone. 
This is a totally cyber sixteen-page zine, printed in black on light blue paper (the color of the digital cyberscape here in Byte City). Finally, you can create those aspirational genitals you've been dreaming of.
Get this one if you want jokes on jokes on jokes, or to delight in overly-laborious random roll chargen.
One day, the dragon crawled out of myth and into the real world. Our real world. It seized control, and bent the people to its will... yourself included. But you have resisted, despite everything you've lost. And now it's time to fight back. This is a fast-paced storytelling game that puts you in the position of... yourself. Not a hero, not a warrior, but your own real-world self, using your own real-world skills to fight a seemingly unstoppable force. You might not win... you probably won't. But you have to try.
To Stand Before the Dragon's Wrath is the "resigned" part of trans rage. You probably can't fix anything, but you're going to have to try.
Way back in the forgotten history of our benighted planet, almost a decade ago, a boy named Edward wrote a game which he thought was about cool dragon fights, but which was actually about being upset at a world which was wrong in an way he wished he could put a face on. He found himself living half for reasons he didn't really understand and in his heart of hearts he wished that he had the power to take on the powers that be.
What a dipshit this boy named Ed was. How obvious in retrospect were his works. Let me guess, Edward, if you had a superpower, it would have been shapeshifting? Perhaps you don't think much of vanity and take a grim pride in not caring about your appearance? Oh who's your favorite character on this show, is it the fairly butch lady who cleans up nice? You fool, you transparent buffoon. 
AHEM. This revised and re-imagined version maintains the same broad structure as the one-page original, but includes:
Revised text to simplify and clarify the main mechanics 
Bonus content related to altering the game now included in the main text, rather than some separate pages
Subtext now more obvious, especially to me, the author
There will be a dragon making your lives miserable and you, the players portraying lightly fictionalized versions of yourself, will talk about how it's made you miserable, and then attempt to take out that dragon with your own unique skills. In other words, you'll give the aspects of society that make you miserable a big scaly face, and then punch it. You're likely to get horribly defeated in the process, but, and this is important, you might not! 
The storytelling system uses simple card draws and light risk-reward mechanisms to tell grandiose stories of epic battles, and the whole thing is being released for the first time as a sixteen-page zine, black ink on pink paper (the color of fierceness, flames, and blood, but without getting so dark that it would be hard to read), complete with additional information on how to adapt and modify the core engine to your own ends. 
Get this one if you want a light-but-robust storytelling engine about confronting enormous odds.
Bonus Content
It's like stretch goals, but I was always going to do them anyway. It's just nice to announce them at the same time as some major monetary milestone. 
Each zine comes with its own special single-sheet bonus, delivered with every physical copy. Get the three-pack, get three bonuses! 
To Stand Before the Dragon's Wrath (Pocket Edition) - Included with the full Wrath, it's an especially tiny version of the basic game. No frills, no variants, just a small package which you can easily tuck into a pocket and take with you to conventions (when conventions exist again).
Anthony Charterstone and the Unwelcome Intruder dust jacket - The cover of RJ McElhenny's most recent novel. If you aren't quite mad enough at her to steal her golden quill, then you can simply read through her works and allow the rage to bubble up within. 
Penis 2.0.77 Genital Customization Form - A closed envelope containing a character sheet filled out with my own personal genital information, as accurately reflected as I could make it. Importantly, you have no right to this information, but I won't stop you from opening it. Do you respect trans people enough to not give in to prurient curiosity about their genitalia? 
Interview with PlusOneExp
If you want to hear me talk a little bit more about this campaign, why I made it, and what I'm hoping to get out of it, check out my interview with Tony of PlusOneExp!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This will be my fourth Kickstarter; each of the previous ones was successfully funded and delivered to backers. In particular, this is the second time I will be running a ZineQuest Kickstarter. As was the case then, the games are already feature-complete; the only thing I need to do is a final revision pass and a layout that fits A4 paper. The printing and shipping will be entirely under my control: these games are getting printed on my home printer, folded by my exquisitely-manicured hands, and handed off to the folks at my local post office.

Last time I said that the only conceivable delay would come from a complete breakdown of the postal service. Ha hah, how I laughed to think of the solid, dependable USPS coming to harm. And then COVID happened and the postal service ground to a halt. I am not tempting fate this time! It turns out, large scale disasters can and do happen.

That being said, the risks associated with this project are the ones that apply to all projects: illness or injury, major disaster. It's ZineQuest; the stakes are purposefully quite low.

updates.update_userinfo: Spreading the Love on Valentine's Day!
updates.update_content:
Valentine’s Day can be a daunting proposition for folks who have a, shall we say, complicated history of loving their bodies and themselves. I hope all y'all are keeping yourselves well today. 
Happy V, everyone. So it should go without saying that my valentine is all of the wonderful little goofs who backed me. You are the collective winds beneath my wings. I thought one thing I could do to celebrate is to spread the love around a bit; instead of talking about myself ad infinitum, I could share some of the other Zine Quest games that I’m currently excited about.

CDProjekt Red’s Cyberpunk 2077. Sort of a big deal in video games! I had zero interest in playing it as we approached its release. Too big, too violent, too overhyped, and yeah, its trans representation thus far had been… well. There are plenty of places you can read about Cyberpunk 2077’s, shall we say, problematic take on trans issues. More eloquent minds than mine have talked about the Chromanticore controversy, where CP77’s marketing featured an in-universe ad that heavily-sexualized a trans woman with a huge dick.
Some folks were concerned with what that imagery said about the game’s broader treatment of trans people and trans identities. Other people, including the folks who spoke on behalf of , were big old “fuck your feelings, snowflake” edgelords about it.

Friends! You have had a day’s respite from my Emotional Ramblings, but now I’m back to ask the question that’s on all of our minds: just what popular children’s fantasy author is RJ McElhenny meant to be a parody of, anyway?
… what you really don't know? Gotta say, that leaves me Just Kinda Reeling from surprise. Well, I don't want dirty my fingertips by taping her name (and also who wants to risk attracting the attention of fans and defenders) so I'll just call her That Author for the time being.

I cannot believe that the penis game didn’t win the poll. I’m not complaining, mind, I guess I just assumed my followers were a bunch of puerile goobers, when in fact, as the numbers have it, they’re dragon fans. OH NO does this mean I'm the puerile goober? 
... no. No that can't be. 
ANYWAY as promised, it's the first of three Self-Indulgent Mini-Essays. Stick around for (or skip to) the end when I reveal a piece of Bonus Content for this campaign! 
To Stand Before the Dragon’s Wrath

So I was GONNA do a thing where I posted a screenshot where I was all like "OMG I'm almost at a thousand! You all rock!" and then a Mysterious Benefactor emerged from the faewilds to tip me over the edge. So... woo! Thanks mysterious benefactor, whoe'er you might be...
