FINAL TWO HOURS! ENDS 10:26am CST!
Hurry up & back it before its gone!
We love retailers!!!
As of March 4th there is a Retailer tier! Get 10 pairs of zines for your Friendly Local Gaming Store (FLGS) at 50% list price AND be listed as an official Sponsor of the project!
Non-Retailers! If you talk your FLGS into picking up a Retailer bundle, let me know via Twitter (@LeviathanFiles) or email (Taylor@RiverhouseGames.com) and you will receive some secret special additions to your backer copy!
A banner with a wizard and a smiling sword. The text reads "Oh heck we funded in 5 hours! Stay tuned for stretch goal announcements 3/3! Also thank you everyone for your energy & support! Wooooo! I can't wait to yell about stretch goals."
STRETCH GOAL ANNOUNCEMENTS!!!
We will release the already finished core game as a standalone zine, and then collect the Stretch Goals into their own volume, tentatively titled "Kaleidoscope"! Every single backer at the PDF level or higher will receive a PDF copy of Kaleidoscope, and there is an additional tier for those who would like to get a physical copy added to their pledge.
For every $500 we achieve we'll unlock a new Stretch Goal! This money will help cover the cost of adding contributors to the project at a rate of $0.40/word. Additionally, Each stretch goal will fund $100 to sponsor Session Zero, a Phillipines based RPG convention! Whatever funds are left over after paying contributors, sponsoring Session Zero, and printing/shipping will go to helping me pay off things like student loans, car payments, and credit debt.
STRETCH GOAL - $1,000: (UNLOCKED!) Riley Rethal!
Riley Rethal is a game designer, biology student, and camp counselor who writes rpgs that encourage collaboration and introspection. Her games can be found at http://metagame.itch.io and her twitter is @jaceaddax
Room: The Reflecting Pool - There is something familiar about this room. It is a lost and found of sorts. Do we still remember who we were outside of this dungeon?
Self: The Ancient - You have been in this dungeon longer than anyone else, and you know your fate. You have secret agendas in this dungeon.
STRETCH GOAL - $1,500: (UNLOCKED!) Brandon Leon-Gambetta
Brandon Leon-Gambetta (Pasión de las Pasiones) is the screaming voice from deeper down down ever deeper down. Each discarded skull in this dungeon rattles with his podcasts' names, dreadful names that hiss Stop, Hack, & Roll Network & Protean City Comics. If he were to be found and he won't be found so lost is he, it would be at @bleongambetta.
Room: The Maw - They feed this dungeon with offerings. You travel ever tiring the sound of your breath heavy. They feed this dungeon with offerings. You know you've lost companions and you aren't the only ones to do so. They feed this dungeon with offerings. Where do the bodies go and why do they feed this dungeon with offerings? The maw takes the offerings.
Self: The Hound - They brought you into this dungeon because you can always find things and they thought you could find the exit of this dungeon. You tell them you can but you can never know if you are truly  smelling a trace of clean air in the rot or if you are chasing a trail long gone cold.
STRETCH GOAL - $2,000: (UNLOCKED!) Mahar Abrera Mangahas!
Mahar is a queer game designer from the Philippines who currently lives and works in Hong Kong. He tries to make games that are meaningful tools that reflect his cultures and background in music, theatre, and psychology.  He specialises in dramaturgy, or someone who looks at the theory and practice behind a dramatic composition or narrative. When not being a nerd he's otherwise asking people to support Session Zero or crying over people's beautiful games. Mahar's games can be found on http://maharhar.itch.io.
Room: The Hearth - Every dungeon has a place that feels warm and safe. That is a lie. Even a dungeon has its respite. That is a lie. Every sanctuary, every campfire, every place you caught your breath; that is a lie.
STRETCH GOAL - $2,500: (UNLOCKED!) Samantha Day!
Samantha Day is a writer and designer from upstate New York. You can find her on Twitter @passerines, and you can find the things she makes at http://passerines.itch.io. She is a threat to her environment and she refuses to go extinct.
Room: The Crucible - You may not have done terrible things outside of this dungeon but you have almost certainly done terrible things inside this dungeon to survive this dungeon and before you can escape this dungeon your deeds must be tallied and accounted for. Your soul will be weighed. Will it be found wanting? Does it even matter?
Self: The Saint - You came to this dungeon to hear the voice of your Divine in the quiet hollow space of the world. You came to this dungeon to bring a light into dark places and a darkness into the light. You came to this dungeon. You came to this dungeon. There is no escape from this dungeon.
STRETCH GOAL - $3,000: (UNLOCKED!) Pamela Punzalan!
Pamela Punzalan (aka Pammu) grew up rolling dice and wanting to design video games, went for teaching and the academe instead, left those fields, stumbled into the legal practices behind real estate brokerage, occupied herself with pushing community spaces for women and LGBTQIA+ folks in her locale, then stumbled into tabletop game design. She's currently based in Manila, and loves to design things that look at the strange, the intimate, and the queer. You can follow her on Twitter @TheDovetailor.
Room: The Altar - After a small eternity of deep shadows, terrible odds, and grueling fights, stumbling upon a spot of quiet unspoiled by monsters can be jarring. But this is not a place where mortals can walk free. This is a god's hallow, a resting place of an Other. They watch. They listen. They demand supplication.
Self: The Gravedigger - Nothing stays buried for too long in a dungeon that never ends. Bones, bodies, treasure, love and memories are only as heavy as their attachments. You're comfortable in the in-between space of clinging hard to what seems ready to pass, and letting go of that which has no desire to leave.
STRETCH GOAL - $3,500: (UNLOCKED!) Natalie The Knife
Natalie (she/her) is a trans game designer from Minneapolis, Minnesota. She designs and publishes roleplaying games with a focus on novel mechanics and player support. Natalie's other games can be found at rpgnatalie.itch.io.
Room: The Mirror - What lives here is a reflection of you yourselves. Perhaps twisted; perhaps true. Whatever it is, watch out.
Self: The Naturalist -Everything has a self, but only you know how to speak the hidden tongues.
STRETCH GOAL - $4,000: (UNLOCKED!) Jay Dragon
Jay Dragon (Ask me about my pronouns!) is a young queer game designer and summer camp counselor. She writes lyrical games about feelings, friendship, community, and horror.
Room: The Meadow - The walls of the room fall away into fields of flowers and a brilliant constant sunrise. The dew is everywhere, and crickets thrive in the grass. You could spend forever here. But where is the door? And why are you so, so tired?
Self: The Mote - We all need a light in the darkness, to navigate this Dungeon. It doesn't feel good to be told that that's all we're good for, a whisp on the wind or a lantern hung in the air. But, let's be honest. That's all the Mote really is. A discardable torch.
STRETCH GOAL - $4,500: (UNLOCKED!) Viditya Voleti
Viditya Voleti is an interactive artist and game designer who makes great stuff. He’s been described as Prolific, Awe-inspiring, Has Great Hair, Exudes Pure Goblin Energy, and much more. His work and design reflects these, as Viditya has made straight bangers like Space Goblins!, Spellchitects, Space Between Stars, and Apprentice Quest. You can find his work on vidityavoleti.itch.io and follow him on Twitter @vidityavoleti.
Room: The Stars - This room tells of legends, long gone. Stories familiar and guiding, tragic and harrowing. What is learned will stick with you.
Self: The Goblin - You come from this dungeon, or one just like it. Others do not understand how you work, or are often quick to dismiss or suspect your actions. Only you understand your rules and the rules of this dungeon, because what will kill you is not this dungeon but those you travel with to seek an exit.
STRETCH GOAL - $5,000: (UNLOCKED!) Aaron King
Aaron King lives in Minneapolis, petsitting and making zines. They try to stay technically unemployed as much as possible.
Room: The Sporatorium - The fungi here want to communicate, but their spore talk hurts those who are unlike them. One of us is harmed on entering. We must decide who. Each painful inhalation brings us closer to understanding. We must decide whether to keep trying or to fight our way free.
Self: The Automaton - You awaken. Good. You were created by another. You are filled with coldly distributed elements and magic devices. This is your programming, and we are speaking to you now. D O   N O T   M A K E   M O R E   A U T O M A T O N S .
STRETCH GOAL - $5,500: CROWS DANGER
CROWS DANGER is a swarm of birds haunting downtown Minneapolis. She is the author of Fight Truck and Petals, or when you fall for her, and seeks to create works that celebrate passionate imperfection.
Room: The Ceremony - The dungeon demands blood and wine, ash and soil. Follow the patterns on the walls, perform the rituals with your hands, and you will be different. You will leave someone behind, in this dungeon. You will find someone, in this dungeon. You will not be the same and you will be different.
Self: The Witch - You came to this dungeon because your skills are desired. You came to this dungeon because your skills are reviled. In this dungeon, you will do the workings no one else will. In this dungeon, you will do the workings you know in your heart. You stand at the edge of rejection and scorn, at the edge of isolation and outrage; they call you wicked, and you laugh.
The Treasure At The End Of This Dungeon Is An Escape From This Dungeon And We Will Never Escape From This Dungeon
We are bone and feathers and we will never escape and we want to escape. We want to fly. The treasure at the end of the dungeon is an escape from this dungeon. We will never escape from this dungeon. We are bones and feathers and hope and magic and we will never escape from this dungeon. We want to fly out of here on our busted wings and feel the air on our faces turned up towards the sun, but each room of the dungeon is the same and each room of the dungeon brings something new and we will never escape from this dungeon.
Each room of this dungeon unlocks more of this dungeon. There are five rooms in this dungeon, and there are many rooms more than five in this dungeon. We have each died in one of the rooms in this dungeon, and we will each die many times more in each of the rooms of this dungeon. Each room of this dungeon is different but each room of this dungeon is the same, only growing larger with each time we enter each room of this dungeon. As we crawl we repeat, the cycle is always the same and we have different faces, the guardians are different beasts, the traps are different traps, the deaths are different deaths, and the treasure is always the same. The treasure at the end of this dungeon is an escape from this dungeon and we will never escape from this dungeon.
An image of a circus ticket written "What is this dungeon? It is a kaleidoscopic roguelike dungeon crawl created by Riverhouse Games. There is no way out of here."
"some of the most beautiful, poetic game design you can get, a super fun looking story game of a roguelike, AND it's freaking gorgeous." - Brandon Leon-Gambetta, game designer & podcaster.
This is a roleplaying game for four players and no GM. Each room of this dungeon is different and has its own rules. Each of us crawling this dungeon is different and has our own rules. This is a kaleidoscopic game of an increasingly complicated dungeon from which there is no escape, and what happens to us as we die within its walls.
The game is meant for one to four players, each playing a Self, representing the four archetypes of dungeon crawl games: The Muscle, The Thief, The Mage, and The Healer. Each Self has special rules that will alter the play of This Dungeon.
A screenshot of The Mage Self, with rules about how to cast spells, and how your magic becomes more entangled the more you die.
As the Selves crawl through This Dungeon, they enter one of five rooms, and one of an infinite number of rooms. Each Room follows a different dungeon crawl trope, like a Gatekeeper, a Trap, a Puzzle, or a Fight. Pretty straightforward, right?
A screenshot of The Battle Room, with instructions on how to play out the fights that will happen in this Room.
The doors to the Rooms are incredibly heavy. So much so that opening more than one takes all your life from you. Your Self will die, and will change, and as you change so will This Dungeon. You will open the doors to each Room many times, each time spiraling off the Room into a kaleidoscope fractal of evolving Dungeon. 
This is a Dungeon Crawl Horror Game where the monster is the Dungeon Crawl Genre.
A fantasy ticket with two wood-cut style knights. The text reads "What is being funded? A print run of zines and shipping to backers plus any back-stock to sell at conventions. The game is finished already, totally done!"
The game is completely finished! The funds from the Kickstarter will go to producing the copies that will be sent to backers, and cover the shipping costs. Any left over funds will help me pay off student loans, car payments, and credit debt. 
A spread of printed zines, looking gorgeous and ready to ship

updates.update_content:
Hello friends!
It's January 2021. We're still in a pandemic, yay!
I wanted to post an update about the status of the project, as well as give folks a WIP copy of Fractals (link to come tonight for those who backed at that level).

Before I do that, I just wanted to chime in again on something that I talked about in my last update. This project is still moving, but it's moving at a pace that not everyone is happy with. Please think twice about hitting that request update button or making comments that assume you have an eye or ear in the production of this project. These are valid concerns and please trust me that, having backed 224 kickstarters over the years, I've been on the customer end of a Kickstarter that has been delayed significantly (and even a few that have never fulfilled). That said, please think twice about why an individual creator, with a full time job in a pandemic and trying to manage his mental health, might not be posting updates religiously and take that into consideration reading the frequent posts questioning the status of this project, or my character as a creator.

campaign.story:
UPDATE: Holy Guacamole, this dumb fucking thing might actually get made! You folks are the finest pondscum and gentle deviants a crackpot like me could ask for. Expect some stretch goals to trickle in as the hours of my Kickstarter dwindle~
GFDP is a zine about living in sea caves, escaping social confines, and slaying the shit out of monsters! Join oyster cults, smoke various cave flora, wrestle boneless sea pigs, or completely fuck off straight down to the center of the world. GFDP  is built with the framework of  the amazing Troika - and while the  settings are quite different, they  revel in a weird and uncanny science  fantasy that I think is  compatible. GFDP is about heroes that love their  strangeness and  embrace the darkness away from the points of light.  They are grungy,  malcontent, dangerous, cave-dwelling punks living on  the fringe of  society at the edge of the world.
Pages comes lovingly stained in household fluids
The zine will be a booklet with AT LEAST 40 pages of trashy nasty filth. With all the rules needed to play the game, the zine has room for some grungy stained tables, sample adventures, and other various junkerie we can cram into the margins. Stretch goals will include building out the classes from the fantasy triad (fighter, thief, wizard) to the punk bullshit version of the other tropes and archetypes your favorite fantasy games love (five or six additional classes), as well as a fully written adventure for your punks to ruin, and a setting where all of this idiocy actually happens.
 Something  I love and admire from  Troika (itself a hack of an 80s game called  Fighting Fantasy) is how  limber and lightweight the rules are, to make  room for some really  heavy, clunky, crunchy ideas without being  overwhelming. Troika  brilliantly chooses where to zig and where to zag  and I love what they  came up with. rolling 2d6 instead of a d20 creates a  bell curve rather  than a flat percent chance; combat is chaotic and  unpredictable,  initiative is randomized and damage is rolled on a  matrix, allowing  more nuanced spreads from weapons than just the SIZE of  the dice they  get to roll. Everything else should feel familiar to your  lightweight  OSR-likes like Black Hack or Knave.
We've all made out with a goblin for their black spit, right? ...right?
Unlike   Troika, GFDP uses 3 stats not just the 1 and is slightly more familiar   (to the RPG oeuvre) which should make it more playable with your   favorite modules and supplements. One of the most magical part of the   OSR is all the disparate cores, settings, adventures, bestiaries etc. -   as well as all the work of current material being made - and I wanted  to  keep it something that works well with the other great work  happening  in the scene. GFDP, mechanically, is a bridge between Troika  and the OSR  at large, adapting material for/to either should be  manageable without  much re-tooling of stat blocks or matrices.
The   zine gives you all the rules needed to run a campaign for GFDP,   spelunkers and troublemakers, in  surviving (or not) the cold, wet,   dark, dungeons. A primer on what the dungeon punk is to me and while I   will never play "adventurers" again. You're also going to have OSR   compatible rules for running campaigns in the freezing darkness, a   system neutral adventure(ish, Troika is a very different engine than   you may be used to, but you'll find under the hood its still doing all   the things you expect an old school RPG to do). You may find the   classes, equipment, RANDOM TABLES, monsters, or adventure works in your   games, and are encouraged to scrap GFDP for parts if you're not into   playing pierced, patched, scarred, angry dungeon punks.
Skulls are hand-drawl for extra angst
This is a bare bones budget that includes basically nothing except the costs for printing and shipping the physical copies. The quality and time-frame of the art will be quite dependent on the success of the project - my own chickenscratch or doodles from fiverr are not out of the question. Profit isn't the name of the game for this project, I would love to fund continued efforts in zines and RPG content, which may include factoring in the costs of feeding a human to write stupid zines.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Like most people writing zines for zine quest - this is my first time publishing a printed kickstarter project, and so that is obviously a challenge. I've decided to charge a few dollars more than the bare minimum for printing and shipping, as they are not my expertise, this will buffer any complications that might arise from trying to fulfill my commitments with the absolute minimum budget. updates.update_content:
Hey everybody - because of Covid-19 I wanted to let everybody know what's going on with GFDP and myself. Goddamn Fucking Dungeon Punks is still on target for its July release, and as I finalize the writing and the layout I will start posting some updates to it here. In Washington State, many non-essential businesses are closed and there is no known date that things are going to be back to normal. It is my expectation that the quarantine will not prevent printing the zine in July, but I'm obviously the writer of silly games and no Dr. Fauci. on the bright side, if the non essential businesses aren't up and running long before we might all just turn into dungeon punks using clam shells for money and joining subterranean sex cults.
So, as for me, I'm under quarantine and have a lot of free time to do art. Because of this unforeseen increase in lots of time and little to do with it - and because I'm already going to be shopping around for printing the zine - I've decided to add a project on top of GFDP to print and ship in July: Delta Gamma vs. Draculas - a game about playing sorority girls who have to keep Draculas from taking over their university during Rush Week. This is a shorter zine, with a target page count of about 28 pages. On its own, DGVD promises to be fully playable in its own right, but in the interest of not putting the same text and rules into both zines, DGVD by itself is more of a lightweight game akin to some of those one page RPG's you might find floating around the internet, like or . Or, you can combine it with the rules from GFDP for a totally play experience.

campaign.story:
It's been growing for a few years now. It has all those small-town amenities you love: the Old Town, the local branch of Halmart, a Drive-In Theater, a little State Park, and even a bustling industrial chicken farm called Miller's Chickens. It's been great for the humans of Smalltown. 
Unfortunately, the town's growth hasn't been as kind to the local fauna. The expansion of Smalltown has taken over much of the habitat of the local critters. So to survive they have turned to theft. Their target? The great treasure chests full of smelly, delicious, some-what rotten (but it's fine) garbage that those big dumb humans leave outside. Though recently the humans have been making it harder to get to that slimey gold. So you've gotten a little group of specialists together and you're gonna make sure you and yours get fed or die trying.
 Eat Trash. Be Free. Play as a gang of animals stealing food and garbage from humans in a small town. 
You have a gang that must procure grub in any way they can to survive. This typically involves heists that target small family garbage cans and garage fridges, but the boldest of the critters in Smalltown always have their eyes set on the big scores. Like the local chicken farm, the Halmart grocery store, and the local Farmer's Market. 
Unfortunately, it's a rough town out there and you aren't the only critters hunting for something to munch on. So you'll have to make friends and enemies of these other factions that roam the streets of Smalltown at night to survive.
Think a Banjo-punk  Woody Guthrie plus the Fantastic Mr. Fox and you are on the right track.
 A bunch of new and reworked playbooks to make being a critter a bit more evocative. Choose the playbook that suits how you want to help out in a heist. Will you be a Tinker, Sneaker, Builder, Seeker, Climber, or Scrapper. 
 A ton of factions. Meet the United Scavengers Union, a mostly kindly group of scavengers who just wanna share their dinner. They definitely don't help the sickly along to the great plate in the sky. Cyrus Jugs and Manitoba Long-Legs, of the Fleet of Lake Lenoir, are a relatively kindly group of animal pirates stealing fish off the line of fisherman and sabotaging their motorboats. Make sure you watch out for the Pack, a group of feral dogs that want nothing more than to get in the humans' good graces. Their zealous quest regularly puts them at odds with the common critters of the town.
 Grub. Scores bring in grub. You need to have it or your family/gang start to starve. Starving is bad. If you have some grub to spare you can trade with other factions to get useful stuff for your furry little band.
 Smalltown. A fully fleshed-out town for you to play in with a shiny new map for all of your illicit animal activity.
 Seasonal Play. Rules for tracking the seasons and how those affect the critters that live in Smalltown.
What won't be in the zine?
 The Blades SRD. You need the SRD to play it. So make sure you have access to it. It's free and available to anyone on their site. I highly recommend you buy Blades in the Dark too, it's a fantastic game and could tide you over until Eat Trash. Be Free. is out.
 Stretch Goals. If you were a part of A Rasp of Sand's campaign you know that I take extra funds an invest in art and pay the team more. So I'll be doing that again.
I'm glad you asked! Some of this grub is pretty ripe so you always need that special sauce to make it really pop in your mouth. I have a TON of guest writers lined up for this project all of them are involved in the tabletop RPG scene in some way or another, and all of them will be writing at least one faction for the game. Ya see I wanted to make a fictional community of furry little rebels and hooligans and the best way I thought to do that was to get our little community involved. Some of those writers are:
Dave Cox (Me!) Last year I wrote A Rasp of Sand. It did pretty darn well. I'm a UX/UI designer by day and write silly elf games at night.
Adam Vass is a professional musician and art director in Southern  California. Since 2017, heHe writes and publishes RPGs as World Champ  Game Co, including Babes in the Wood, zinequest’s Wish You Were Here,  and the recently kickstarted conspiracy game Cobwebs. His catalog is available at worldchampgame.co.
Kira is a tabletop roleplaying game designer, queer nonbinary cyborg, and snake friend living in Columbus, Ohio. The creator of A Cozy Den (about lesbisnakes in winter time) and  Something Is Wrong Here (an uncanny emotional love letter to David Lynch's work), Kira also has a Patreon and YouTube vlog that elaborate on game design process. Kira organizes #Aprilttrpgmaker every year and collaborates on the biweekly More Seats at the Table which is a newsletter featuring marginalized game makers. Follow current projects at @Kiranansi on twitter.
Linda Codega (@_linfinn) is a queer, nonbinary speculative fiction author and narrative game designer living by a mountain in the Hudson Valley. Their work has appeared in various anthologies, magazines, and blogs, and you can find a  selection of their games here: lhcodega.itch.io.
Cecil Howe is the author and illustrator of The Forest Hymn & Picnic and Do Not Let Us Die In The Dark Night Of This Cold Winter, and the illustrator and co-designer of Hex Kit.
Pam Punzalan, aka Pammu/The Dovetailor, is an independent game designer based in Manila. She's a queer femme who likes to create things that are strange, intimate, and punchy.
Charlie Ferguson-Avery is an illustrator and game-designer based out of rural Pennsylvania and co-founder of Feral Indie Studio ( https://feral-indie-studios.itch.io ). Currently the lead artist for World War Occult and creator of Into the Wyrd and Wild he spends a majority of his time making art, visiting the woods, and throwing sand in the gears of capitalism.
Joe DeSimone is the Co-Founder and Lead Game Design Instructor at The Academy of Games, a games-based learning center in Austin, Texas. In a previous life, he was an organizational development consultant and created learning and training games for corporate clients. He’s sad a lot but games make that better.
Ben Chong, also known as Flowers, is a non-binary, bi Malaysian-Chinese tabletop game designer making games about intimacy, relationships, tough conversations, and everyday magic. Their works are inspired by romance, surrealism, and horror with a South East Asian bent. Ben imagines deep, emotional worlds to touch the hearts of players. As Swords and Flowers, Ben self-publishes, runs workshops, mentorship programmes, community events, and collaborates on international projects. They currently lecture for game design in UOW Malaysia’s Bachelors of Game Development (Hons).
Cass Reyfield is the official Twitter biographer of her pets' lives and game designer, sometimes in that order. She is known for designing  Forged in the Dark games, cultural consultation on TTRPGs, and breaking tension with animal memes.
David Schirduan is the head of Technical Grimoire, founded the 200 Word RPG Challenge, and designed a few games that his mom really likes. He is obsessed with cool websites and weird mechanics.
Mary Georgescu holds an MFA in Visual Narrative and soon an MFA in Game Design. A 1st generation American-Romanian, she is an IGDA scholarship winning game designer, author, and artist who freelances in a variety of roles and consults on narrative projects. She can be found at @maryageorgescu.
JR Goldberg (He/Him) is a writer and game designer living in Philadelphia. He is probably best known for putting together Doikayt: A Jewish TTRPG Anthology. He writes a lot about professional wrestling. He still listens to folk-punk even though he's in his mid-thirties.
Frankie Larson is a tabletop gamer, writer, and mental health advocate. You can find them on twitter @humanhouseplant and at their art portfolio www.behance.net/frankielarson. You can also listen to them playing Adelaide the half-elf Warlock on the D&D 5th edition podcast, Hit Dice!
Richard Ruane (He/Him)  is a Brooklyn-based game designer, occasional grad student, and educational technology professional. A former freelance editor for White  Wolf Game Studio, he's the founder of R. Rook Studio and the creator of Dark Designs in Verdigris, Moonlight on Roseville Beach, Chronicles of the Spacejammer, and Barrow Keep. Find him at r-rook.itch.io or @arr_roo on Twitter.
Chris Wolf is a web developer and RPG designer in Brooklyn, NY. He released his first game Offworlders in late 2018 and swears something else is on its way soon.
Alisha Bhagat is a futurist who focuses her work on the creative use of tools such as scenarios, games, and simulations to help people and organizations think strategically and long term. When not at work Alisha is a fan of board games and TTRPGs, especially those that involve dragons. She is also the president of the board of BitchMedia, a  feminist media organization. You can find her @alishabhagat.
Ryan Spargo is a child of the hills and a lover of the fantasy of said hills. He hails from Seymour, TN, with a rich history of climbing over rocks and trees in the Great Smoky Mountains. This love of nature and excitement has given him the necessary tools to bring life to gremlin critters in perhaps even your own backyard! His novel, Schmuck, was a  2013 labor of love and sold well for an independent publishing effort.  He spends his days exploring experimental narrative games and chasing stories of any and all kinds.

campaign.story:
Български език надолу ↓ 
There was a land in which magic beings were still walking among people and even some humans still held magic within themselves.
In these times the spirits of the mountains and the forests were already running away from the increasing roar of engines and banging of guns, but in the forgotten lands, which this story is about, magic was still strong: Samodivas walked the woods; Zmeys stalked the caves; and Karakondjuls hid in the abandoned houses.
What awaits you over the next lines is a forgotten tale. This is the last tale…
In these times so difficult for magic, an evil awoke in a last attempt to impose its dark power and forever rule the world -- this was the evil sorcerer Myrylielie, who dwelled in the Black Mirror Land!
The Lost Tale is a tabletop role-playing game, including rules-light system, a magical setting, a handful of classes, and a sample hexcrawl adventure for you to explore. And it's all within a single zine! The rules are simple enough to be understood even by kids (+-<>), and are loosely based on Tunnel Goons by Nate Treme. All you need to play is the zine, two 6-sided dice (2d6) and pencils!
Oh, the setting! My primary inspiration fоr the game is the dark and, often strange, folk and fairy tales of the East European people (sometimes called "Slavs"). As an east European myself, I've grown up with the tales of "The three brothers and the Golden Apple", "Neznaen Yunak (Unknown Hero)" and, of course - "Baba Yaga"! And with time my love for (role-playing) games led me to think - what if we combined the two? 
Sample Cover (work in progress)
The Story takes place in an unnamed corner of the world, 'Тhrough nine mountains', where magic and myth still live, despite the rising industrialization and urbanization in the West. People mostly live in small villages in accordance with the land. The forests, fields and mountains are home to various creatures, including talking animals and evil spirits. It's a complicated relationship, sometimes beneficial, sometimes - not!
This game would not have been finished if not for the impetus provided by Kickstarter's Zine Quest 2. Check out and support the incredible work of other Zine Quest creators here!  
Sample Spread (work in progress)
The Zine will be A5 size, 24+ pages, black & white colour, printed on 150g paper, with card stock cover. I am using my own, as well as public domain art for this project.
Heroes' Journals (work in progress)
Who are you?
My name is Dimitar Georgiev and I am a graphic designer & artist based in Sofia, Bulgaria. Here you can see some of the projects I worked on, and a preview of my upcoming board game "The Fifth Element", which I want to kickstart as well.
Myrylielie [mirilaɪlaɪ] is a fictional character from Elin Pelin's novel 'Yan Bibiyan. The Incredible Adventures of One Kid', an evil wizard dwelling in the Black Mirror Land.
Draft Heroes (work in progress)
Timeline
I have set May 2020 as the delivery date for the PDF, but I expect to deliver it earlier. You can print it locally, but if you fancy the paper zine I expect it to deliver up until June.
Budget
The bulk of the funds raised will be spent on printing and mailing costs. A portion will be used to pay RadostinGeorgiev to clearly translate and proofread the book (as I am more comfortable writing in my native language for this project) and a portion will go on fees etc. I am doing all the illustrations, writing and editing myself. Any profits I make will most likely be spent on survival in order to make more nice stuff!

[UNLOCKED] £600: Will add two more types of Heroes (classes) - The Beast and The Guardian!
[UNLOCKED] £800: Will expand more on the lore, add (at least) one more location, more monsters and items!
[UNLOCKED] £1000: Will add colour covers!
[UNLOCKED] £1200: I will record a video of me playing a folk song on guitar, as my personal "Thank You!"
Имало едно време…
Една земя, в която магическите същества все още се разхождали сред хората и дори някои хора все още носели магията в себе си.
В тия времена духовете от планините и горите вече бягаха от все по-силния шум на мотори и гърмеж на пушки, но в потулените земи, за които е тая приказка магията още беше силна - самодиви обитаваха горите, Змейове се криеха по пещерите, а караконджули - по изоставените къщи.
На следващите редове те очаква една забравена приказка. Това е последната приказка...
В тия трудни за вълшебството времена, едно зло се събуди в последен опит да наложи тъмната си сила и завинаги да царства над земята - това бе злият магьосник Мирлайлай, който обитаваше Черната Огледална Земя.
Какво представлява?
Изгубената Приказка е настолна, ролева игра. Включва лека система, магическа история, типажи за герои и основите на приключение, което да изследвате! И всичко това е побрано в една-единствена книжка! Правилата са прости и разбираеми дори за деца (+-<>).Всичко което ви е необходимо са тази книжка, два 6-стенни зара, моливи и няколко приятели.
Основното ми вдъхновение за тази игра са тъмните, геройски народни приказки на Балканските Народи. Израсли сме с приказките за "Тримата братя и златната ябълка", "Незнаен Юнак" и, разбира се - "Баба Яга"! И с времето юбовта ми към игрите и приказките ме доведе до въпроса - какво ако смесим двете?
Историята се развива в неназовано кътче на света, "През девет планини", където магията и митът са все още живи, въпреки индутриализацията и урбанизацията на Запада. Хората живеят в малки селца, в разбирателство със земята. Горите, полята и планините са дом на различни същества, включително говорещи животни и зли духове! Това поражда сложни отношения, понякога ползотворни, понякога - не!
Книжката ще бъде А5 размер, 24+ страници, черно-бял печат на 150 г. хартия и картoнена корица. Използвам мои рисунки, както и такива за свободно ползване от интернет.

campaign.story:
Ever want to learn how to play tabletop RPGs but weren't sure where to start? Understand the basics of one but aren't sure how to apply them in a real game? Or just want a fun time rolling dice? Then Command? is here for you! 
The cover for Command? Dungeon World, designed by Paul Coy with art by Cloe Ashton!
Command? is a solo, gamemaster-less game in a zine built to teach you how to play tabletop RPGs! This campaign is for Command? Dungeon World, and is designed to take you through Sage LaTorra and Adam Koebel's RPG of classic fantasy, giving you a taste of what the game can offer budding roleplayers! With mechanics similar to the old Fighting Fantasy books of eld, all you need is the zine, a character sheet, and dice! Or a notepad and a dice rolling app! Or a text file and a random number generator! Or...
A sample page from Command? Dungeon World
Tabletop RPGs offer a huge amount of freedom that can be daunting for new players, so we're making Command? as an entertaining way to ease you in to the role-playing experience. Think of it as a guided tour of what you can expect to find in a tabletop RPG!
The excellent Command? Dungeon World cover art by Cloe Ashton!
The goal of this campaign is to develop a limited print run of the Command? zine (or zines! See the stretch goals below). In addition, we'll be creating a digital PDF version that will be for sale, as well as a free, text-only Twine game that will be put online for anyone to enjoy.
A second sample page from Command? Dungeon World
Once Command? Dungeon World has been funded, what's next? I'm glad you asked!
$2,000: MORE ART
If we hit this goal, more art will be added to Command? Dungeon World to pepper into its pages. In addition, the cover will now be in glorious color!
$3,500: THE SPRAWL
Fantasy not your thing? Well, if we reach this goal, we'll start work on Command? The Sprawl, exploring Hamish Cameron's roleplaying game of cyberpunk corporate espionage! That's right, a second whole zine for you, which digital and physical zinester pledges will get for free!
$4,000: MORE ART FOR THE SPRAWL
While a cover will be drawn for Command? The Sprawl, with this stretch goal even more art will be added, and the cover will be now be colored in genuine cyberpunk colors!
$6,500: BLADES IN THE DARK
If we hit this goal, then a third zine will be added to our repertoire! This time, we'll explore John Harper's tabletop RPG Blades in the Dark, a game of fantasy heists and daring scoundrels!
$7,000: MORE ART FOR BLADES IN THE DARK
Finally, if we hit this goal, then we'll smuggle even more art into the Blades in the Dark zine, and the cover will now be in color!
Bryce Duzan is a writer and game designer who has mainly worked on visual novels and Twine games before. For Command? he'll be doing the bulk of the writing. In the past, he's made the visual novel Who We Are Now, the Twine games Summonr and In Darkness, Dreaming, and the tabletop RPG Plight of the Cursed. You can find him on Twitter at @Spincut 
Ruben Ferdinand is on the crew! He's going to be helping with planning the campaigns and editing it for maximum fun/pathos. You can read all of the published fun/pathos so far at www.thefriendden.net and you can find him on Twitter at @urbanfriendden
Cloe Ashton is the artist behind the amazing cover for Command? Dungeon World. You can find her at http://obviouslycloe.org, on Twitter at @Obviously_Cloe, or on Instagram at @obviouslycloe

campaign.story:
What is "Dark Path"?
Dark Path will be a short interactive fiction zine featuring beautiful illustrations and tabletop RPG elements. It is the lovechild of two weirdos that grew up around Old-School roleplaying games and choose-your-own-adventure game books. It's writiting will conjure up weird and psychedelic imagery as the player explores corridors that are home to weird and non-human tunnel-dwellers. Oldschool-inspired art will be augmenting the game experience and let you immerse yourself into a world of caves, tunnels and mysterious pathways that just may lead to you mentally communicating with an owl or to a grisly death in the deep.
Diagram of the "Dark Path"'s story structure - Every arrow represents a choice.
The zine will utilize the classic game-book format of "To do X, turn to 32" and will come with a character sheet inside that tracks the players health, courage, skill and overall progress through their journey. Skill checks will be determined via a D20 (because of course they will).
Philipp's past sketches
Lukas (a.k.a. Geargrind) wrote the short interactive fiction story as an addition to his upcoming dungeon synth album "Dark & Twisting Path" and turned to Philipp for the zines illustration. Philipp has been drawing the scenes that play out in his roleplaying campaign live at the game table for years and his style evokes the quaint charme of oldschool roleplaying, while not using it as an excuse for a lack of eloquence. After studying illustration he now works as a tattoer and his evocative imagery with stark contrasts of light and dark fit snugly into the zine.
"Flickering amber-colored light illuminates the dark passage before you as you hold your torch high over your head, moving forward into the black. You do no longer remember if you descended into the dark corridors around you by your own volition or if you were sent here as some form of perverse punishment. You vaguely remember the idea of sunlight and the only thing keeping you from attributing its existance to one of your abstruse dreams are the moments in which, from the ceilings of tall caverns a glimmer of it has graced your vision not long ago. In moments like these thoughts of the futility of your existence as an aimless wanderer in dark tunnels, a rat in a maze, bubble up to the surface of your consciousness. Before you can reflect further on them, the floor beneath you crumbles as you are sucked into a black chasm that has opened beneath you. Flailing wildly you attempt to hold onto anything around you but to no avail. In an avalanche of rubble the ceiling spits you hard on the ground and your consciousness fades for a moment as the world turns black."
The final version of the zine will have a recycled paper cover and saddle stitching. The illustration, final tweaks to the gameplay and layouting will begin as soon as the funding goal is reached. Join us on this journey on the Dark Path!

For the past 2 years, The Sandy Pug Game Awards have upended the wild world of tabletop RPG award events. An award that anyone, even the indies, can win, the SPG awards are a phenomenon, celebrating the coolest, chillest, most inventive, and creative people in the indie TTRPG scene. campaign.story:
This is the story of Philotes, the goddess of romantic friendship, who some call the small kiss. You know Mars, and Venus. You know Pluto. Minerva. The gods you know have all had their times as the aspect of the world. Many of them more than once. And they've had their chosen mortals doing their work.
But not Philotes. Until now.
Maybe.
Those books when you were a kid that gave you choices and page numbers for each of them? This is like that. Except remember how those choices were only ever about whether you survive and about finding the path that solved the mystery? This is not like that. 
These choices are intimate, and subjective. Philotes is trying to decide about bringing her aspect of romantic friendship upon the world. Should she talk to Venus? Can anyone help her sort it out? Is she prepared to wreck a mortal if that's what it takes? Should there be a sex scene first? Should she talk to Proserpina? It's all your decision. 
I shared my first draft with a few readers. Here's a couple of their comments.
I remember a rack of zines at the record store when I was a kid. They felt powerful and self-possessed to me, like their makers had found a form of expression that wasn't beholden to anyone else but themselves. I wanted to find my own energy like that for Zinequest and make something incautiously its own. There are scenes in We're Just Friends that are shockingly erotic. It plays with the boundaries of games and stories on multiple fronts. It's revisionist myth. The decision points are nothing like the ones you've read in classic CYOA novels. Maybe you'll make a decision and then find the character doesn't agree. In one case maybe a scene doesn't go as hoped, but you get a chance to try it a different way. No sane publisher would want anything to do with it, but as a zine it's not beholden to any sane publishers.  
If you'd like to read the first scene and its choices, click through this image of its pages.
campaign.risks:

I've priced it with two print services, and calculated postage costs carefully. If those costs go up by a lot in the next few months, that would be a problem, but I've built in a cushion that could handle a small cost increase. I've made zines before, and I've given myself enough time to solve printing issues or whatever with this one.
So I really expect to be able to deliver We're Just Friends as promised.

campaign.story:
Dump Quest is a tabletop roleplaying game with simple rules. The pamphlet contains a series of pages outlining a narrative adventure through which a Game Master will guide their players. However, the construction of these pages is not set in stone! The GM must request nouns, adjectives, numbers, and more from their players to modify the contents of each encounter, ensuring that neither Player nor Game Master can be certain exactly where their story is heading.
Our first issue of Dump Quest is styled as a classic fantasy dungeon crawl, featuring (possibly) a spooky witch, a mysterious treasure, a sticky floor, a dangerous cult, a giraffe amulet, a soggy wizard, and *lots* of lava!


Characters
Each player is provided a character sheet at the beginning of the game. This provides the player with their list of special, single-use abilities. However, each ability has missing words. Players request words from their teammates to flesh out their abilities, without knowing exactly how they will be used.
The Adventure
Each page of the adventure provides the Game Master with the essential information to run the encounter, broken into the following sections:
Narration to be read aloud to the players
  Notes for the Game Master detailing hidden information about the encounter
  Tear-outs to reward your players with valuable items
  At the start of each encounter, players provide the Game Master with words to fill out the blanks on the page. These words could modify enemies, name characters, increase the value of loot, or even make the encounter more deadly.

           Players must progress through each encounter using their character’s special actions. If the player can describe how their action fits into the scene, it is considered successful. However, the Game Master is free to impose any consequences they desire based on the action they used.
Dump Quest intends, by design, to create absurd, yet whimsical, roleplaying situations. Your party’s Fighter might end up using a Tiny Cleaver to lockpick the chains off a captive Delicious Bard dangling above a pool of Lime Jell-O, and this is OK!
Throughout the game, you’ll write all over pages, modify art with your own art, and tear components out of the pamphlet as your group dredges this story out of a word salad and into reality.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
My two roommates and I have been working on Dump Quest for the for the last 2 months and we are really excited to share it with everyone. We started from the ground by building our own RPG engine. We love the versatility and goofiness that games like Lasers and Feelings and Honey Heist have, rpgs that are so light and easy that they welcome new players to improve and act. So we took what we liked about these systems and added what we felt was missing: more goofy randomness.
 
 What we came up with after several iterations was the ad-lib engine. It's an engine that every time we've play tested we've all came away laughing our asses off. Our ad-lib engine is new and unlike anything we've come across.
 
 If you decide to back Dump Quest know that this is an exciting and brand new game engine that we've put our hearts and souls into. We think it's a great system that has role play and improv built into the core of it, which is what we wanted to focus on in a rules light system. Because the system is so light its great for small sessions with people less experience in RPG's. 

On a more technical note we have 90% of the booklet done and ready to be printed. We're finishing up some of the illustration work and typesetting all the last details. For the all the standard editions you should expect your zines sometime in mid to late March. For the special edition covers and the alternate version expect a few extra months to receive your copies.

This is our first kickstarter and we hope that you enjoy Dump Quest as much as we've enjoyed play testing it.

campaign.story:
The Shrouded Lands
A glowing, magical shroud covers the mountain valley to the east. They say there was once a powerful kingdom there, full of secrets. No one alive knows the truth of it, but to this day travelers can still be seen passing through that magical barrier. What drives these adventurers to enter that mysterious place? Is it the promise of ancient secrets? The pursuit of the unknown? Or perhaps to start a new life in a new world?
Whatever the reason, it doesn’t matter, for those who pass through the shroud never return. 
What is this?
Lost in the Shrouded Lands is an open-world, map-crawl setting, detailing the long lost lands hidden from the world by a magical shroud. It is intended to be system agnostic, as the material is presented without mechanics, but the setting would suit any heroic fantasy system such as Dungeons & Dragons, or Pathfinder. There should be enough content to play 3 - 5 sessions, with suggestions for how to expand to campaign further.
The area map included in the zine.
What is a mapcrawl?
The area map is separated into pieces, with each map piece representing a distinct zone. Each zone has its own encounters, locations, and feel to it. As the party of adventurers explores the land, new map tiles are uncovered. 
The map broken into separate map tiles
This has advantages in look and feel over a hexcrawl game. Using large paper map tiles allows for recording interesting finds using stickers or illustrating and writing directly on the tile. As the players explore and uncover more of the land, they have the opportunity to name areas, pin locations for returning to, and customize other elements of the map, giving players more connection and ownership to the world.
How does it play?
Lost in the Shrouded Lands is player driven and open world, meaning the adventuring party can explore wherever they want, however they want, and aren’t railroaded into following something because the book told them to. At any point in time, the players can choose to:
Explore new regions for the sake of discovery, and choose to name them.
Visit settlements and NPCs to obtain quests, rumours, or information.
Follow rumours and hints about treasure troves, ancient ruins, or magical events.
Complete quests for rewards or to increase the party’s reputation.
Pursue the ages old mystery of what happened to the ancient kingdom at the heart of the Shrouded Lands.
Wherever players decide to go, the GM can reference the booklet to see what the players encounter, what locations they can discover, and other points of interest.
Because players drive the action, there is no requirement that every encounter ends in combat. Players can choose whether to approach situations diplomatically, with subterfuge, or with aggression, and the book supports multiple approaches and gives different consequences based on player action.
Sessions end at a good rest point, and start again when the party wakes up, meaning groups can play short or long sessions as desired. Additionally, due to the freeform nature of the game, players can swap in and out, allowing for an open gaming table from session to session.
What’s in the zine?
The physical zine itself is a 24 page booklet which contains:
A brief description on how to run the game, create characters, and start the first session.
Details on what is in each map tile, including a rough area description, notable locations, and encounters the party will run into whilst adventuring in that tile.
A village the PCs will likely enter, prominent NPCs in the village, a description of different political tensions in the village, and how the party can influence it.
Additionally, there are two, one-page dungeons, that can be played standalone, but are established in the setting with quests and story elements.
A preview of the zine layout
The digital package will include printable PDFs of the zine, dungeons, and area maps. There will also be extra digital materials that include:
Alternative maps including a map with notation for GMs, and an unlabeled map for players.
A glossary of characters, places, and terminology used in the game.
A small guide that contains tips and tricks for the GM on how to run the game as easily as possible, with minimal prep time.
More accessible versions of the zines, including a screen readable version and a large type version.
Extra content based on community requests and feedback.
Accessibility, usability, and inclusivity
As a person with a disability, I am committed to making games that are accessible, usable, and inclusive. Here’s what I’m doing to meet those goals:
Accessibility
Digital versions designed to be screen reader friendly.
Map tiles are designed to be easily identified by shape, and using 3D landmarks allows for users who are visually impaired to read the map by touch.
Typeface and sentence structure is intended to be easier to read for people with dyslexia or other reading difficulties.
Alternative PDF of the zine in larger type for printing at home.
Usability
Information is laid out in chunked paragraphs, following a hierarchy of information which presents important, direct information first, and backstory and history last.
Paragraphs that describe areas, encounters, NPCs, or quests are formatted to be easily distinguished.
Sentences are short, and written in plain english.
The zine is clearly laid out and references to map tiles follow a logical pattern.
Specialized words, names, and places in the game are bolded in text, and a glossary is provided describing every bolded term.
Inclusivity
Characters and artwork are intentionally diverse in representation of race, appearance, disability, and gender presentation.
The zine is system agnostic, so individuals can utilize their preferred system without running into roadblocks regarding mechanics written into the game. Where possible, I’ll attempt to cater to different systems that I feel suit the game in separate digital documents.
While I’ll try my best, I’m certain I can always do better, and will always be open to feedback.

This is my first ever kickstarter, so it’s possible I’ll mess something up. However, I am a professional graphic designer, and I’ve been putting together books and artwork for clients for years, so I definitely have the skills and experience to finish and launch a product.

updates.update_content: Hello everyone, today I’d like to give you insight on what the final product will be, and what I have left to work on.
Hi everyone, I hope you’re doing well, wherever you are in the world.

Part of preparing my first playtest was to establish a basic system for marking to the passage of time. Given that the Shrouded Lands are an open world, and players can take as long as they want exploring, pursuing requests, or making their own goals, there needs to be some way of tracking days that have passed.

Firstly, I’d like to apologize for being quiet recently. Covid-19 has been a factor in interrupting the lives of many people, and has definitely taken a toll of getting together with friends and playing some great tabletop games. As mentioned in the last update, my next step was going to be playtesting, but that plan has been pushed back due to current circumstances. However, an update is definitely overdue, and I’ve been lax in communication, so I hope you’ll all forgive me.
The good news is that I’ve still been working on content, and I’m confident that the foundations of the zine are all in place. The areas, factions, conflicts, and additional rules all work well enough on paper, and all that’s left is to run a private playtest to make sure there aren’t any glaring oversights. Playtesting can also help me make some higher level decisions, a good example of which is how I want to treat level scaling.

campaign.story:
While each adventure is a single page; this kit gets you the adventure, a page of character sheets to cut up, and 2 pages for gameplay rules and notes for the GM.
Lunch Break TTRPG
Pop them in a loved-one's lunch bag, or bring them along to play at the office. Keep one in your pocket for spur-of-the-moment gaming, or put a few in your gear for your next backpacking trip. This game is small, lightweight, and only requires d6 and a pencil to play.
Demo of folded adventure
These single-page adventures feature the 1930’s Rubberhose Artwork of Calamitycallie. We'll mail it to you shipped in a regular-old envelope, but sheets are designed to be folded into nine cells. Adventures are silly, and fun, with just the right amount of grit and subversive humor as you progress through the cells in a flow-chart path based on your rolls. Paths will have you turning the page around, flipping it over, and folding it up as you progress through the story.
Encounters
Dice rolling is similar to games like Yacht. You roll 6 dice and try to have matches. You earn re-rolls by roleplaying and critical successes. You describe where you want to attack and what you want to do, and the GM will tell you how many matches you'll need. Roleplay it well to earn more re-rolls for later. Once enough hits have been done to a certain part of the baddy, it can't use actions related to it. Take out enough of it, and your group succeeds! If you can't meet the dice goal you set out to accomplish, you're going to get hit and lose some of the re-roll dice you earned.
Rough draft of an enemy stat block
Exploration
Each short storyline features diverging paths that require different levels of success to access. Similar to an encounter; when a group enters a room, they'll roll for matches. The GM will tell them what they see based on it, and which paths of the story (physical and literary) are open to players. Puzzles, traps, and storyline are solved in similar ways. The game-sheet shows which cell for the GM to move to based on player actions. It's like a flowchart, but dice determine what you get to choose from.
Re-rolls and Wild Dice
The rules are simple and the encounters fairly straight forward. Players are encouraged to spin a yarn and get involved in the improv storytelling. By doing interesting things and getting in character, players will earn re-rolls. They can be used to re-roll dice during Encounters and Exploration as they see fit. Wild Dice are additional dice that can be added to the pool (your own or someone else's) to help out. These are your spells, gear, and abilities. Players are meant to tell how they use the Wild Dice in interesting ways, so it almost always results in some re-roll dice as well.
Failure/Death
You cannot die or fail in LBTTRPG. Your "health" is associated with your re-roll dice pool. Once you hit 0 re-roll dice, your character is on the ground. Players must describe how they are scraping their way back from certain death in a dramatic enough way to earn a re-roll die. Now they're at 1 "health" and are good to keep going!
Some players enjoy the risk of death, so there are some alternative rules included if you really want to make the game riskier.
Inspiration
This game was influenced by my love of Adventure Time, Over the Garden Wall, Choose Your Own Adventure books, and old cartoons. I saw the artwork of Callie and knew it had to be used for a fun romp through some dungeons.
Included Adventure
Into the Gullet was playtested at several cons and FLGS sessions under a different system while we worked out the details. It's always been a hit. The adventure starts with a fight against an enormous dragon while you're at a flea-market. You've got high-flying fun, gross bugs, an insane elf, and so many opportunities for Dad-jokes.

The mystic toads of Y'vek squabble amongst themselves, The goblins of the Verdant Limb are in uproar, the Omutii warriors cut down man and beast alike in the Igazii Ring, and the dark sorcerer Solk plots in the dank depths of the Under-Valley... 
The physical zine (appearance may change!)
Treasures of T'urokk is a zine containing all you need for you to explore the strange and dangerous valley of T'urokk! It is mostly a setting and lore guide, but will also contain a short example adventure you can run immediately! The zine will be fully illustrated, with prose of lore, a surreal setting, strange characters, and even stranger mutations!
The zine will be around 32 pages long (not including covers!), and will feature an abundance of stylised illustrations and art. It also contains all the rules, stats, items, and characters you will need to venture into this world, as well as enough lore and flavour-text to allow for the seasoned adventure to travel beyond T'urokk and into the rest of the Altered World...
This zine is a part of Zinequest 2, and is my first venture into the ttrpg world. I hope you help back this project, and I hope that you enjoy it as much as I enjoyed working on it!

campaign.story:
Face Folio is a simple project with a simple goal: to provide 100 fantasy portraits for use in your tabletop role-playing games. Referees are always on the lookout for NPC faces to show their players and players are always looking for portraits for their character sheets. This project aims to meet that need.
The portraits will be organized into the following sets:
Human NPCs/PCs
Dragon-blood
Dwarf
Elf 
Gnome
Halfling 
Orc-blood
Demon-blood 
Human nobles
Human peasants and towns folk 
Each set will contain ten portraits, half male and half female. With the exception of the human nobles and peasants, the portraits will be a spread of adventuring classes.
The Zine will have a simple elegant layout with 10 portraits per two-page spread, and organized in the above groups. There will be no blocks of text and no fluff to get in the way. That way this book can be used right at the table, as and when needed, for example when the referee suddenly needs an NPC to drop into the game. 
We are using a single artist to do all the artwork. This is because MARCINs is a wonderfully talented artist and because we want there to be a coherent and unified style to the whole project.
 1. Electronic (GBP 5.00 | about $6.50)
You will get the 24 page zine as a PDF, in addition to any electronic stretch goals. 
 2. Physical (GBP 8.00 | about $10)
You will get a hard copy of the 24 page zine mailed to you anywhere in the world, as well as all of the electronic products.   
3. Original Art (GBP 35.00 | about $45)
You will get a hard copy of the 24 page zine mailed to you anywhere in the world, as well as all of the Electronic products emailed to you.  
In addition, this limited tier offers the rare opportunity to own some original physical artwork by the super talented artist MARCINs. Simply, select the level with the set of portraits you want to own, and we will mail these to you anywhere in the world. There is only one set of each race (i.e. 2 sheets of 5 images), so when they are gone, they are gone! 
 Goal 1. Printable Initiative Tracker (GBP 500 | about $650) - UNLOCKED 
We really want these portraits to be as useful as possible. We thought one way to do this was to have the option to allow each portrait to be printed on a foldable initiative tracker card like this:
Initiative Tracker - Preprinted (top) and folded into the two conformations (bottom) - concept
The card is designed to fold in two possible shapes. The first folded shape (lower left) is designed to hang over the edge of a referee's (DM's) screen. The referee-facing side has a stat block for easy reference. The player-facing side shows the players the NPC’s portrait and has room to write a name. The second folded shape (lower right) is designed to sit on the table in a peaked fashion. The referee is also able to keep a living record of the NPCs in their campaign by building up a collection of these cards, and players are more likely to remember the NPC's face than just their name and/or verbal description.
If we hit this stretch goal, these Stat/Initiative Trackers will be provided at all tier levels, allowing for printing, cutting and folding as and when needed.
 Goal 2. Art Upgrade (GBP 750 | about $1,000) - UNLOCKED 
We really really want to produce the best 100 fantasy portraits that we can. The bigger our budget the better the art will be and the more MARCINs gets paid. Below, the lower layer is an idea of the art that we will produce if we just fund. If we hit the stretch goal we will upgrade the art e.g. to the upper layer.
Illustrative example showing potential upgrade in art quality
 Goal 3. Physical Bookmark  (GBP 1,000 | about $1,300) - !! NEW !! 
With the first 100 physical copies of the zine, a physical bookmark featuring one of the portraits from the zine. 
 To mail the Zine will cost: 
 UK  GBP 1.00
 Outside the UK  GBP 2.00 | about $3.00
To mail the original artwork will cost: 
 UK  GBP 3.00
 Outside the UK  GBP 5.00 | about $6.50
My job is the make this project happen, and to do this we have engaged the following creative individuals:
Concepts and ideas - Goblin's Henchman, who is a RPG blogger (https://goblinshenchman.wordpress.com), and possibly best known for developing and promoting the use of Hex Flower Game Engines. To find out more about Hex Flowers look out for the Hex Flower Cookbook.
Artwork - MARCINs, who has worked as an artist on a number of RPG-related projects (for example in the recently funded "Against the Darkmaster" Kickstarter; which is in no way affiliated with this Kickstarter project). Below is an example of the work MARCINs did for the upcoming procedural adventure 'Carapace', which is due to come out later this year: 
Example of MARCINs artwork from the soon to be published adventure 'Carapace'
Please note - copyright in the artwork made with the Face Folio will not be transferred with the physical artwork or with the zine. No license will be transferred with the physical artwork or with the zine.

campaign.story:
Each A6 Adventure takes the form of a single, pocket sized, zine any Dungeon Master can use to run a single session of 5th edition gaming for their party. The art is sketchy and expressive and the adventures themselves are geared towards an open and improvisational style.
The goal for this Kickstarter is to raise a budget to print and distribute the first six issues in the series.
I ultimately aim to produce a mini-library of 26 adventures, (one for each letter of the alphabet), but for now I’m a first level zine publisher so if I can get six titles out into the community and onto tables I’ll be a happy adventurer.
The Zines
So far I’ve mapped out the first six Adventures in the A6 series, (each with an alliterated title in alphabetical order). I’m in the process of finalising the layout and art for the first three zines and am looking forward to diving into adventures 4, 5 & 6. 
These are the six titles planned for the Kickstarter: 
 ISSUE ONE: AN AMBUSH IN AVENWOOD
The players are rebels racing to save their leader from the despotic Baron's clutches.
ISSUE TWO: THE BEAST OF BLEAKMARSH
The players must hunt a monster lurking in the mists surrounding a small fishing village.
 ISSUE THREE: CALL OF THE CATACOMBS
The players venture below the city to discover what is contaminating the water supply.
 ISSUE FOUR: DEAD IN DINGLEBROOK
The details remain shrouded in mystery... (work in progress).
ISSUE FIVE: ECHOES OF EBONTHUL
Things are going to get creepy... (work in progress).
 ISSUE SIX: FLAMING FANDANGO IN FARATUSA
Swash your buckles for the end of the series... (work in progress).
Each Zine is made using a single piece of A3 made into an A6 booklet through a 'Cut & Fold' method (these are test prints - the finals will have tighter positioning)
I utilize both sides of the paper with each booklet folding out to reaveal maps, monsters and more inside!
I'm really excited to be launching A6 Adventures alongside so many other great projects as part of Zinequest2!   
Why do I want to do this?
Since discovering tabletop RPG's six years ago I've fallen down a rabbit hole of creating and running adventures that threatens to consume my every waking hour. Each adventure is an experiment in how to enthrall and delight a group of friends around a table and now... I need a bigger table! I can't fit all the experiments I want to try into my home games anymore. So I want to share them with you. More importantly I want you to take the content in these zines and conduct your own experiments. I want to send these scrappy little adventures out into the world and have them level up with other people's ideas. I get a lot of joy out of making them, and I'm hoping you will get even more joy out of running them...
...and I sincerely hope none of these creations kill your party. 
A Note About Shipping.
I live in a fantastic far away land called Australia. The far away bit means that shipping to some realms can get a little pricey. This is mainly relevant for adventurers looking to receive all six issues in the mail. campaign.story:
Battle Beasts is designed to give you the framework for creating a tabletop version of much loved creature collecting and battling video games. This zine will give you a guideline for creating characters, elemental creatures, settings and plot lines for one off or long term RPGs with your friends. My aim is to supply plenty of pre-made beasts and stories for you to use, but my hope is that Battle Beasts can expand to what you want it to be. What you want to play. What you want to create. 
Vinivorous
Like most tabletop role playing games, Battle Beasts works best with a Game Master who can run the game and clarify rules, though it’s easy enough to customise your Beasts and jump straight into a battle with your friends! Beasts have suggested stats and moves, but players have control over how their Beasts behave! Using d20s and d4s, d6s and d8s, combat is grid based and pretty straight forward, with stats effecting the accuracy and damage of the various moves that Beasts can learn. 
Here is an overview of battling in Battle Beasts!
The setting is open and the way you catch or tame Beasts and how they are viewed by people can be different every time you play. Fantasy, Cyberpunk and Modern settings are all possible within the realms of Battle Beasts.
Of course, battling is not all there is to Battle Beasts, and the game is full of opportunities for role play and explore. A world full of interesting and powerful creatures is sure to rouse up chaos, danger and intrigue! It's totally up to you!  
The Core Zine is a 52 page, A5 booklet with all the details you’ll need to play Battle Beasts. It will give you information to create your own settings and plots, as well as characters and beasts. Battles, role play and how your Beasts grow are all covered as well.
There will be 24 pages printed on colour sheets, dedicated to the six base types and focusing on pre-made beasts and moves of those types. (The addition of three more types in the Core Zine is a stretch goal!)
The last 10-12 pages will include pre-made stories that you can use as examples to get your ideas flowing. Plots including tournaments, battle royales, legendary encounters, dystopian worlds and mysteries!
I’ve been working on Battle Beasts for quite some time, and I’ve made more Beasts than what I can fit in one zine! I’ve decided to include a Beasts Expansion alongside the core game that will be about 28 pages, A5 like the Core zine and full of extra beasts of all nine types for you to use!
Pagma
In Battle Beasts, I’ve attempted to simplify the elements and their strengths and weaknesses. I’ve ended up with nine types, each with an even amounts of strengths and weaknesses.
Every Beast only has one type, but there’s potential for them to learn a variety of moves. They also have an ability that gives them something special to use to their advantage.
Though plenty of Beasts are supplied, the Core Zine gives you all the information you need to implement your own creations into the game.
Stats
Every beast has a base amount of Points in three Stats: Attack, Defence (effecting damage done and taken) and Speed (effecting turn order and movement). They also have an amount of HP to start out with. As the Beasts battle and encounter situations, their Level will increase, and with that also their Stats. Players will have some control over how they distribute these Stat Points!
Chimpansea
Evolution
Beasts will either have one, two or three stages, and some may split into multiple options. Evolution occurs at similar times for all Beasts, and Evolving will give them a boost to their stat points!
Battle Beasts Type Chart
Moves
Every Beast has a pool of moves that the player gets to choose from as their Beast grows. The moves have set Damage, Range and Accuracy, and can be mastered by your Beasts as they gain more experience. There are lots of different effects moves can do too, and the ability to use them creatively is what really sets Battle Beasts apart!
Characters that keep Beasts, train them and battle are an important part of Battle Beasts. Your Player Character also has Stats and you’ll have to roll dice during encounters and role play sections of the game. These Stats are Fitness, Smarts, Charisma, Heart and Will.
Again, the role your characters play in your world is completely up to you!
Pasquerade

I'm James Kennedy (@jimmyjamjemz) and my first love is art! My second love is games! 
I'm an Aussie currently working as a freelance artist. I've been able to devote a lot of time to personal projects recently, and this is just one of the many! I also spend time working on Adventure and Animals, Pokemon Original Characters and drawing fishies!
Some of my favourite games are Tales of the Arabian Nights, Tokaido and Oceanos!
Battle Beasts started as an college art project inspired by Pokemon, but I loved my creations too much to leave alone. It took quite some time, but they're finally back in their own game.
