campaign.story:
DELVE: A Solo Game Of Digging Too Deep is a solo map drawing game that puts you in control of a dwarven hold as you discover the horrors that lurk below. This roughly 32 page A5 zine has everything you need to generate natural formations, forgotten ruins, enemies, wyrd magics, and ancient monstrosities. It has a simple turn-based combat system, rules for building your hold, and tips on how to implement your hold into your RPG world.
Inspired by games like Dwarf Fortress and Dungeon Keeper, DELVE aims to capture that feeling of building and protecting a fortress in an unforgiving subterranean world.
All you need to play is, a pencil, paper (preferably 1" grid), and a deck of playing cards. 
The Under-King has put out a bounty to all the holds demanding a Void Crystal, a rare and powerful gem found only in the deepest caverns. 
Each round your dwarves will mine another square of the grid, you draw a card from your deck of playing cards and see what they found. Hearts ♥ and Diamonds ♦ are resources and trade goods that you'll use for building and hiring units while Clubs ♣ and Spades ♠ are natural formations and forgotten ruins. From ancient libraries to goblin lairs, these subterranean locales will become part of your hold's unique layout and may provide unexpected benefits. Or you might just unleash a horde of ravenous insects in which case, you'll need to fight.
Combat in DELVE is designed to allow for forward planning and strategic thinking without weighing you down with book-keeping. Essentially, all enemies follow the same goal of trying to reach the surface by killing their way through your hold. They can move one grid space per turn, as can all of your units. Once they get into combat, check the rock-paper-scissors style chart to see which group has the advantage and reduce each side by the STR of the other. 
Once combat is over, it's time to build! As long as a room has access to the hold via a mineshaft or another room, it's good to go. Just pay the cost, and draw it in an available grid (empty or repurpose an old ♣ or ♠ grid space). At this stage, you'll also have the opportunity to build traps, reinforce, and hire units to defend your hold.
Just, be careful as you get deeper though as the black joker is waiting. Drawing this card releases an ancient monstrosity, a randomly generated beast that needs a well stocked army and hold to defeat. 
The Story of Blood Fate Hold
The hold was off to a rough start as their chosen site led straight into the lair of the mud goblin clan, Rushk. The initial group of soldiers sent with the expedition where wiped out in this surprise attack.
Deciding that bad luck doesn't just strike once, they built a spike wall to defend their stairwell. A good choice as the next pick strike revealed a hive of cave wasps. Some miners perished but the overzealous wasps dashed themselves upon the spike wall.
Finally, Blood Fate was started, a barracks built just beyond the hive. It's honey would sustain the expedition and our new soldiers would have somewhere to stay while the miners delved deeper.
A string of good luck found trade goods and resources by the plenty and so they built a stewpot kitchen to hearten the fighting spirits of the soldiers, a shrine to bless their good luck, and finally, a stairwell to descend deeper.
The old adage of "fool me once" had become mantra for Blood Fate as they focused their efforts on defence. Rock fall traps on the stairwell, and a dead dwarf alarm that would warn of any approaching threat.
Their militaristic efforts where rewarded as after ignoring a buried temple (who knows what god it was built to), they broke through to a structure. A cavernous mansion filled with chandeliers, suits of armour, and a blood stained altar. A vampire queen's coterie. Her thralls poured from the shadows, overwhelming the miners and marching through the hold at their dark mistresses behest.
The boulder trap dashed the first zealous few on the stairs, weakening their numbers. The stew heartened soldiers fought bravely, managing to strike down all but one. The vampire queen herself. One soldier swore an oath to the gods and launched himself in a frenzy of spinning axes, injuring her before having his head torn from his shoulders. His sacrifice was not in vain however as his bravery bought the reinforcements called by the dead dwarf alarm time to arrive. 
Blood Fate Hold reeks of death and garlic, they say a fool is someone who doesn't learn from past mistakes and these dwarves are no fools. Every room is decorated in holy symbols to gods old and new and once a year the dwarves let blood in a rememberance ritual called Vampik.
UNCOVERED - For passing £1200 I'll pay an artist to make a better quality cover for DELVE. I'll also be creating a printable Unit Token sheet for use during combat and have upped the paper quality of the zine.
UNCOVERED- At £2000, pledges will also get a copy of RISE: A Solo Game of Spreading Evil (PDFS for all pledges, Print for £7 and higher)
RISE takes the DELVE engine and flips it on its head, putting you in the blood encrusted boots of a dungeon keeper as you build your dungeon, summon/grow/hire minions, and dig your way to the surface and your inevitable domination. Along the way you'll be challenged by powerful adventurers, other dungeons, and more. Will you be strong enough to keep your treacherous minions under control and defeat the forces of good? Or will you be overthrown and forgotten?
You will not have to pay increased postage for a physical copy of RISE
UNCOVERED - At £2600, pledges will get a copy of UMBRA: A Solo Game of Planet Colonisation (PDFS for all pledges, Print for £7 and higher)
As a galactic war rages on, your government has tasked you with leading an expedition into the depths of an alien planet to find the source of a mysterious signal. Could this be the weapon to win the war? UMBRA comes with new features like planet generation, scanners, and above ground building. Will you find the mysterious signal before the war is lost? Will you be the last bastion of humanity? Or will you unleash something much worse on the galaxy.
UNCOVERED - At £3200, pledges will get an expansion for UMBRA focused on exploring a labrynthine space station and repurposing its rooms for your survival. (PDF for all pledges)
UNCOVERED - At £3500 I will commission an artist to create interior art for all 3 zines.
UNCOVERED - At £4000 my ragtag band of packaging minions will be rewarded with a nice dinner at a local restaurant as thanks for their dilligent efforts. (Otherwise its cold dog food and criticism).

Get DELVE: A Solo Game of Digging Too Deep, RISE: A Solo Game of Spreading Evil, and UMBRA: A Solo Game of Planet Colonisation in PDF format. Includes any digital strech goals.
Print + PDF Bundle - £7
Get DELVE: A Solo Game of Digging Too Deep, RISE: A Solo Game of Spreading Evil, and UMBRA: A Solo Game of Planet Colonisation in Print and PDF format. Includes all stretch goals. The book will be A5 and single-colour.
Retail Offer - £30
Get 10 copies of DELVE: A Solo Game of Digging Too Deep, RISE: A Solo Game of Spreading Evil, and UMBRA: A Solo Game of Planet Colonisation in Print format for wholesale price. 
Also includes a PDF copy of DELVE: A Solo Game of Digging Too Deep, RISE: A Solo Game of Spreading Evil, and UMBRA: A Solo Game of Planet Colonisation for you to enjoy.
All In - £100
Get a print and PDF copy of DELVE: A Solo Game of Digging Too Deep, RISE: A Solo Game of Spreading Evil, and UMBRA: A Solo Game of Planet Colonisation in Print and PDF formats. As well as a hand drawn poster, custom Ancient Monstrosity playing card, and all stretch goals.
I will be using Instant Print to print the physical zines and have them shipped to me in Scotland. After which it's some cottage industry packaging and posting with the help of my partner and bribed friends. Addresses will be checked and double checked by a cruel taskmaster and once everything's set, mailed out in around May (or June if all stretch goals unlocked).
SHIPPING FEES
Shipping fees are not included as part of your Kickstarter pledge. Shipping will be calculated and collected after the campaign ends (using BackerKit).

For a single print copy: £1-2

Risks and challenges
Besides the usual possibilities (missing packages, printing errors) and the possibility of my untimely demise, there's not really much risk. Once the games come to me and are checked, they get packaged and sent to you.

In fact, even if I die, my partner has my login details so rest assured, once the potential grieving period has passed, you'll still get your games.

I believe in being transparent so if anything comes up that will slow fulfillment, I will post an update as soon as possible.

updates.update_content:
Hey everyone, thanks to your amazing support last year, I've decided to come back and do Zinequest again. This time I've put together a solo journalling RPG called Apothecaria. Like DELVE my focus is on Emergent Narrative and leaving you with a physical thing that is uniquely yours. In this case, a journal full of stories and potion recipes.
If that tickles your fancy, come check it out: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/diamondblood/apothecaria

Finally, after such a difficult year, the final part of the DELVE Kickstarter has landed. You should have an email from Backerkit with your UMBRA: Stations files. This expansion brings station management, tactical ship exploration, alien merchants, and loads of new rooms to UMBRA.
As usual, if you enjoy the game, I would massively appreciate comments and ratings over at https://blackwellwriter.itch.io/umbra-stations-expansion 
And, as of Monday, everyone who responded to the Backerkit before the deadline (and even quite a few who responded afterwards) have had their orders shipped. Thank you all for your patience... I was very optimistic with my initial dates and have learned a LOT from this Kickstarter.

Hey Everyone,
As many of you will have saw, the Backerkit survey deadline was the 15th of October and we're now more than a month past it. If you're one of the people who backed for physical copies and haven't completed the survey yet, you have until the 1st of December but I won't be holding copies back and there's a chance they sell out if you leave it too long.
For everyone who got their surveys in late, I'm packing tonight and shipping in the morning.

Hey everyone,
I've just made a Facebook group for people to share their holds, dungeons, and colonies to. Come tell me the story of how you blew an ancient monstrosity to pieces with your clever cannonade or how you delved too deep and unleashed a powerful lich who crushed your defences.
Join the group here: https://www.facebook.com/groups/delvemaps

I've had a few payments get flagged as fraudlent (which refunds you and charges me £15 each time). The payment on your bill will be made to Backerkit, BlackwellWriter, or just Blackwell. Please, don't dispute that as fraudlent unless you have other reason to.
If you have disputed, then sadly it's going to be February before the banks make a decision and I can't ship your copies until then.

The plan for today is to get the rest of the envelopes counted and posted so if you got your details in for the original Backerkit cut off date, yours will be sent out pretty soon.
If you missed the Backerkit cut off date but got your info in later, don't worry I'll be making my way round and getting yours sent out later in the week.
And if you still haven't got your info in and needed to, time is running out! If you don't complete the Backerkit by the 15th of November, I'll... I'll... to be honest I don't know, probably donate them to zine libraries or convert their value into digital community copies. So hurry up or charity will be done!

Good news Sweden, I've managed to sort the address problem :) 
If you got your Backerkit survey in on time and your card was successful then your copies are packed and addressed and ready... but we have to wait until the 29th to get the money and get them shipped. Which is a pain.
But, as of now, all the people that got in on time are ready!

So, after 2 days of gruelling labour we've managed to get basically every copy packed and are currently up to the Ks.
Now for the grumble worthy news. I can't get your shipping payments until the 29th so I can't really get things out the door until then. But as soon as the money comes in on the 29th, I'll be making new friends at the post office with ~1000 envelopes to post (: 
Oh, and I will unfortunately need to contact a fair number of people to confirm addresses as the spreadsheet has taken certain characters and mangled them.

Hey everyone!
UMBRA has hit the Itch.io store page and all 3 games are now available for download through Backerkit. So you should get an email with your download link in the next few hours.
As for surveys, they are now locking, with a final notice for any last minute changes. If you haven't got your survey completed yet, please let me know ASAP.
The pledge manager will lock the orders tomorrow and charge cards the day after so if you're one of the 140 people who haven't done it yet who needs to do it, best be quick!

campaign.story:
Hi! I'm Adriel, a game designer who loves zines and making playlists. For 2019's 200 Word RPG Challenge I submitted a game called A Boi likes a Grrl in the 1980s (you can check it out here). Since writing it, I've been thinking about how to expand it beyond 200 words in ways that make sense and tell a more structured story. Monster Mix grew out of that.
A Boi Likes a Grrl focused on sharing how you feel about someone through the medium of making them a playlist. With Monster Mix I want to focus on how it feels to tell someone who you are through a playlist.
Monster Mix is a two player RPG where you will individually establish initial details about your character by answering questions and then agree on the setting and parameters of the story you want to tell together. Each player then makes the other player a playlist. After you've both had time to listen to what your companion is telling you, you'll answer some questions together and epilogue your story.
Character creation includes deciding what kind of monster you are. Are you a Werewolf? A Vampire? A Poltergiest? Monster Mix will include monster charts that you can use for random selection or inspiration.
Game play takes place through a series of questions, conversations, and listening to each other. Before you epilogue together you'll talk about what kind of monster you think the other player is. Like most other RPGs you aren't competing with one another to win, getting it right is the goal because it conveys listening and understanding. 
Example Questions:
If you could tell them anything with a song, what would that thing be? 
What kind of monsters are your heroes?
Did you grow up a monster or did you become one?
Coming out is hard, even to people you trust. When you're a monster, who knows how people will treat you? Monster Mix is a low stakes way to engage with a difficult thing.  
Monster Mix will be a 5.5" x 8.5", stapled zine.
Telling your story with poetry someone else has written is not an exact science, but it is thought provoking and rewarding. Monster Mix will include a guide to making awesome playlists!  
UNLOCKED: Snacks! - If this campaign hits $500 I will include a recipe for Werewolf Biscuits (vegetarian and safe to eat in both your human and wolf forms!) and a recipe for Spicy Blood Cakes (a Vampire and anemic human fav! Not vegetarian).
UNLOCKED: Art - If this campaign hits $700 I will be able to hire an illustrator! There will be art either way, this way there will be even better art by the wonderful Tina Bongorno!!
Cover
UNLOCKED: Sharp - At $1,000 (what?!) I will include instructions for making a kitchen athame from a silver butter knife.
My intention is to ship your zine to you via the USPS, media or First-Class mail for folks in the U.S.A. and First-Class Mail International for all other countries.
Shipping charges will be handled through Kickstarter.

campaign.story:
Vallakia is a small province, underpopulated by humans and overpopulated by monsters. An impenetrable fog has surrounded the land, stopping the people from coming or going. When people walk into it, they find themselves waking up some hours later, just on the edge of the fog. Occasionally outsiders will stumble through the fog, and arrive somewhere in the valley with no memory of how they got there.
Trapped, people have tried to move on with their lives. A feat made no less difficult by the roving bands of marauding monsters that plague the landscape, making the simple act of plowing a field a dangerous task.
Captain Rejec
In the chaos, Captain Varus Rejec has stepped up to organize and protect the people of Vallakia. He has built a garrison of soldiers in the town of Pinehall which provides protection to the whole province. Recently, though, he and a squad of troops has disappeared on an otherwise normal patrol, leading the garrison in the hands of his Lieutenant, a warrior lacking his ability of leadership.
If that wasn't bad enough, the logging camp at Priby which provided the wood that the Captain's soldiers were using to wall the settlements of Vallakia, has been shut down amid attacks by woodland monsters. And the village of Long Farm, which provided much of the food for the settlements has recently come under attack as well! Lacking in food, supplies, and leadership, the people of Vallakia need help.
A field in the town of Long Farm
That's where the adventurers come in. This is meant to a West Marches setting, one where players can drop in and out, but will always advance the goal of trying to defend and rebuild Vallakia.
The zine will contain some history of Vallakia, descriptions of the major settlements, one small adventure, as well as a d20 table for the DM to make their adventures with.
 Stretch goal #1 "Manors" - $250 - UNLOCKED!
Contained within this supplement for the Vallakia setting will be an introduction to the history and role of Manors in Vallakian culture, two examples of Vallakian Manors, tools to generate your own Manors and the Nobles contained within, and investments for Manors that may fall under the sway of player characters.
Stretch goal #2 "Villages" - $500
This supplement for the Vallakia setting dives into the details of the smaller settlements which dot the land, under constant threat of attack from the beasts of the fog, these common folk have learned to fend for themselves and not rely on others. Contained within is an introduction to Vallakian village culture, two example villages, tables to generate your own villages and villagers, and a list of possible investments for players to interact with!
 Stretch goal #3 "Items & Personalities" - $750
Suggested by our own backer, our final stretch goal will be a collection of notable NPCs as well as magical and unique mundane items to bring more texture and definition to your own personal Vallakia!

campaign.story:
our first project is the prologue to an episodic cooperative urban fantasy tabletop adventure set in seattle's capitol hill neighborhood after the sudden, localized appearance of magic. as always, with magic comes trouble - broken pacts with the fair folk, machinations of long-hibernating vampires, the ghost of bruce lee...the usual fare, really.
*familiarity with seattle is not required to play or enjoy the game, though there will be winks and nods for those who are!
scaryridge eschews dice entirely. instead, each player will keep and write on their own deck of traditional playing cards, which records game states: choices made, paths taken, secrets discovered.
players move through a neighborhood torn asunder by a devastating magic isolating them from the rest of the world, reconciling their new lives with the danger of this ancient power, trying to discover why this has happened and what it all means.
but for every door, a window: there are unseen aspects of our world to glimpse, and even a few new worlds entirely.
there are 4 character archetypes, each with a single-player solo story arc, as well as seasonal and campaign plots, and secrets that can only be unlocked by experimenting with the narrative. THE VIOLET SANCTION aims to balance hard choices with replayability, a rich world with deep characters, and topical social commentary with a touch of the dark and whimsical.
the game is zine-formatted on A5-size paper, one-color printed (violet, obviously!), and then folded and hand-stapled by me and my friends!
mockups for sampling (final version won't feature a qr code, of course!)
the game is divided into chapters, named after streets, parks, and historical landmarks of capitol hill. players explore each episode, meeting new characters, discovering secrets, tapping into magics, and then return to previous episodes armed with this knowledge able to delve further into the story.
this kickstarter unlocks the prologue episode, which begins at 3 minutes to midnight before new years, 2020. players will witness the violet sanction occur, experience the chaos, and as the story unfolds will discover their character type and the abilities that come with it.
if this kickstarter is successful, the game will then progress along the following arc:
SUMMIT - PIKE/PINE - VOLUNTEER PARK - BROADWAY - OLIVE/JOHN - ST MARK'S CATHEDRAL - EPILOGUE
this is our first project, so we want to keep our stretch goals concise while still being exciting, so we've curated a very short list that we're incredibly passionate about!
$1,000 -our first stretch goal is super simple: stickers! (exact details pending!) all physical backers will receive one and may add-on more for $2 each.
$1,500 - to keep with the theme, we'll customize violet golf pencils for marking character sheets and cards! the effect will be retro/analog and visually dramatic. these will be available to all physical backers as an add-on for $2 each, and on our online shop. limited edition backers will automatically receive 2 when unlocked.
$2,000 - if we hit this point, i'll have the funds to commission an important asset for the game from the cover's artist MATT HARVEY - a stylized map of capitol hill, depicting the violet sanction, the locations of the 6 episodes, and highlights of the neighborhood. the outline for this project is already complete, it's just a matter of funding and enthusiasm! the one-color map will automatically be included in all print and digital copies of the game, but limited edition backers will receive a signed, screen-printed copy as well! 
$3,500 - at this level of funding, i'll be able to produce a custom deck of playing cards! these will be simple, but stylized: violet card faces with white negative-space pips, and custom drawn face/court cards, readily colored in with your violet pencil! if unlocked, these will be available to all backers as an add-on for $20 each. limited edition backers will automatically receive a pack when unlocked!
who are we? scaryridge is a fledgling creative studio here to tell stories and make games. we are adult content (18+), tackling subjects such as queer studies, bodily autonomy, recreational drugs, sex work, consent, death, socialism, anarchy, capitalism, through the lens of urban fantasy. currently, we're focused on producing tabletop adventure zines sharing characters and mythology in a pacific northwest setting.
i'm cody, creative director of scaryridge. i've been fiddling around with games since forever. i started programming adventure games in qbasic before i started school, and once i discovered rpgs there was no turning back. my favorite game is THE SECRET OF MONKEY ISLAND.
matt harvey is a graphic designer living and working in seattle, wa. with an interest in screen-printing and poster design, he has worked with many venues in seattle to create designs for a wide variety of touring bands. a pnw native, reoccurring themes in his work include desolate rocky landscapes, vast forests, erosion, predatory animals, and wispy trails of smoke and fog.

Risks and challenges
there are a lot of risks associated with backing a fledgling company. this is scaryridge's first project, but i have a lot of experience with kickstarter. i have been following and backing projects for the last 7+ years, and as of 2020 curate a daily blog about game projects on kickstarter. i'm passionate about the way crowdfunding has altered the game design landscape and allowed small indie publishers to reach new audiences. i've seen a lot of successes and failures, learned a lot of valuable lessons from others, and now it's my turn to dive in!

the nature of zinequest and the episodic structure of THE VIOLET SANCTION help to minimize a lot of the potential risks. this is a straight-forward one-color printing project for just the first episode, staple-bound, with limited stretch goals. i've factored costs into funding and stretches, so every goal hit means i have the resources for fulfillment.

i've set the expected shipping date for physical rewards to july 2020 to give myself time for funds to release, to plan for any unexpected delays, to learn from the process of running my first kickstarter. if i face challenges i haven't accounted for, i will keep backers regularly updated directly through kickstarter!

if we don't reach our funding goal, that's okay! this is a passion project, and i will still release it to the world, it may just take a little longer.

last but absolutely not least, scaryridge supports KICKSTARTER UNITED and the great staff that have enabled us all to have such a wonderful platform. if they go on strike, we will support them by bringing our project offline. we wish them the best!

hey everyone! thanks for your continued patience with this first project of mine. it has been a lot of learning experiences wrapped up in a lot of unrelated learning experiences, and i haven't been prepared for most of it.

hey everyone, first off, happy halloween! it's also the 1 year anniversary of scaryridge, although it has not been the year i hoped it would be.
i'm really sorry for the lack of updates the last several months. pandemic life has been a roller coaster for my mental health, from losing employment, friends, housing stability, one of my ferrets, and most of my creative motivation, and i just haven't had anything to say. many of the things that inspired me to create this project in the first place have disappeared. had known what 2020 was going to be, i would have launched this kickstarter at a different time.
but, some good news. i recently started sessions with a new therapist, and i'm moving in a positive direction. i'm more productive and focusing only on the things i can control.

hey everyone! i've been drafting this email for a while but haven't quite had the bandwidth to get it sent, with everything going on. i'm sorry for the delay!
first and foremost, i hope everyone is safe and healthy, and managing the best they can. we are at a difficult crossroads, but i believe there is the promise of a better future if we listen to science, take the correct preventative actions, and support one another. community is, and always has been, our strength. together, we will make it through this.

well, we're down to the last 12 hours, and we've jumped quite a bit since yesterday! thanks to all the new pledges that have joined us, we've surpassed 50 backers!
now, onto some more game lore! from the four supernatural powers (described in the last update), there arise eight factions of magical beings. these entities represent the primary channel by which players will interact with the four, as those powers are largely unassailable and not strictly antagonistic.

just sending out a short update that we're in the last ~48 hours of the campaign! if you're following along and are still undecided, feel free to send me a message or drop a comment with any questions that might help you make up your mind!
i appreciate all the support so far, this has been a great success for a first project!

THE VIOLET SANCTION is heavily influenced by the tarot, which can be seen in the character archetypes and the way the game is put together. it uses a deck of traditional playing cards - mostly for ease of accessibility - but those too were inspired by tarot, drawing it all together.
the four suits of cards align with the four characters, but also with four fundamental supernatural forces of the game's universe, which i'm going to delve into today!

we're down to the final days, and almost at 50 backers! i printed up some samples of the cover for demoing, as well as some posters for some of my favorite local shops!
i also did a quick shot interview with brie beau of thoughty, it launched this morning and can be read here: http://briebeau.com/thoughty/2020/02/quick-shot-on-the-violet-sanction/

hey everyone! in the next week of the campaign, i'm going to post updates about the game play and mechanics, how i'm putting everything together, and what you can expect from the adventure!
the prologue is an introduction into the setting, the character classes, the rules, and the big mystery. magic has made a sudden appearance, and it will take the course of the adventure to discover not only why it has happened, but what it means for the future.

campaign.story:
first things first...
At the time of this campaign's launch, Kickstarter's employees were in an ongoing fight for unionization. On February 18th, part of the way through the campaign, their efforts were successful, and Kickstarter United was officially certified by the NLRB! They are currently in the process of negotiating with senior leadership.
This campaign stands with Kickstarter United's ongoing unionization efforts. For more info, head to their website or follow them on twitter. 
#RecognizeKSRU
about the game
i'm sorry did you say street magic is a citybuilding storygame, where players collaboratively explore a city that they create together. Each turn, a player adds to the city either a Neighborhood, a Landmark, or a Resident, nesting cards inside of each other to showcase and spotlight the relationship between the city's inhabitants, and the places where they live. These cards are then complicated by Events that take place in the city: festivals, elections, ceremonies, natural disasters, mysteries, or discoveries that change the flow and focus of play. As you play cards, you unearth the city's true names — quirks and qualities that make this place wholly, intrinsically unique. 
what does this game center?
 Minimal prep for GMless gaming: i'm sorry did you say street magic is easy to pick up, and easy to learn; the game can be played with as little as a copy of the rules, a few pencils, and a stack of index cards. You can play the game with a facilitator, but every participant makes equal contributions to the world. Rules-light, guided play makes it easy for veterans and newcomers alike to pick up the game and jump in quickly.
 Genre-agnostic storytelling: A game of street magic can tell the story of a classical high-fantasy kingdom, a futuristic cityship on a galaxy-spanning journey, or a fabulist facsimile of your own hometown with a magical bent. The tone, setting, and content of your city are all established by you and your fellow players!
 Episodic, vignette-based play: Unlike many other tabletop games, i'm sorry did you say street magic doesn't focus on any one specific group of characters. Players jump between the various different parts of the city, taking turns embodying a myriad of different inhabitants. These slice-of-life stories might result in overarching plotlines as the city expands, but they could just as easily be snapshots of characters who only show up once before returning back into the crowd. street magic doesn't have any single group of protagonists; the protagonist is the city itself.
 Simple campaign incorporation: The game can be played as a standalone one-shot, but it was also designed with long-form play in mind. Players can also revisit the same city multiple times, exploring it from multiple angles. A group of players could easily incorporate this game into an ongoing campaign, as a "session zero" one-shot or as an interlude between longer arcs. For Game Masters, playing i'm sorry did you say street magic as part of your campaign is a great way to lighten your session prep workload beforehand, and to help your players feel invested in the world they're going to explore.
The game supports 2 to 6 players, though it works best with four or five; a single session runs anywhere from three to five hours.
The final version of the game will include illustrations by Shannon Kao, from her art zine You Can't Get There From Here, as well as custom art commissioned specifically for the game.
A city in progress as the game unfolds!
what people are saying about the game
"This is not a mapping game, or rather, it does not conceive of the map as a hegemonic concept of spacial relationships. The city this game constructs is a shifting set of relationships and perspectives, arbitrary faces of a far larger body. The magic of the city is not a quantifiable property, but the qualitative relationships it grows between its individual pieces and residents, and how they move and react to each other." — Geostatonary, designer of Battlefield Lovers and Prayers For Wounded Metal
"I'M SORRY DID YOU SAY STREET MAGIC is for answering important questions, like 'What if Brooklyn just ... walked away?'" — Jay Dragon, designer of Sleepaway
"one time I played I'M SORRY DID YOU SAY STREET MAGIC and then we played a different game and needed to do some worldbuilding and accidentally started playing I'M SORRY DID YOU SAY STREET MAGIC again because the framework is that straightforward and intuitive" — Sasha Reneau, designer of Spindlewheel
"the game slaps" — Viditya Voleti, designer of Space Goblins! and Space Between Stars
tier rewards
Backing the campaign at the Tourist tier ($10 USD) will get you a digital edition PDF copy of the game. The final digital PDF will come in both full color and black-and-white editions for ease of legibility. I'll handle PDF distribution through itch.io.
Backing the campaign at the Resident tier ($15 USD + shipping) will get you a physical, printed zine edition of the game. The final sixty-page zine will be 6.5" x 5.5" with staple binding, a full-color cover (front and back), and black and white interior printing. I'll be printing the final zine through Mixam.
This game has been available for purchase on my itch.io page for almost a year now, and I know that many people already have copies of the PDF. For those who have already bought the game on itch.io, the $15 tier will get you a physical zine without paying extra for the digital edition (which will be released on itch when the campaign ends).
Backing the campaign at the Neighbor tier ($20 USD + shipping) will get you both the PDF of the game, and the physical zine! If you don't already have a copy of the PDF, this tier is the best way to get both the digital and physical copies of the game at once.
Please note that the physical zine tier (Resident and Neighbor) prices listed above do not include cost of shipping, which will be added onto your pledge through Kickstarter as you finish backing.
community copies!
I believe in the importance of making games accessible for people who can't afford them! In the past, I've added digital community copies of my work on itch.io so that people who can't afford the game at its current price can still have access to it.
I'm going to replenish the pool of free communal copies once this campaign ends, but I also want to make sure that as many people as possible can claim them. To that end, I'm also implementing a community copies model for this campaign: for every $10 USD you add to your pledge above the minimum pledge cost, I'll add an extra digital community copy to my itch.io page for somebody to claim down the line.
This reward will stack! For example, if you decide to back at the Neighbor + Community Copy tier ($30 USD + shipping) but you also add an extra $10 to your pledge on top of that, you'll be donating not one, but two community copies to the pool.
the campaign
My goal with this Kickstarter campaign is to make a physical print run of the game to turn it into a zine. I'm hoping to raise for $1200 to make that happen! Here's how that money breaks down:
$150 for printing
$200 for shipping and fulfillment
$150 for art (to pay Shannon for the license to use and make minor modifications to her artwork, and to commission a few new small pieces)
$250 to cover the costs of editing, revisions, and layout consultation
$200 to compensate myself for writing and layout
$100 as a buffer
$150 for fees
i'm sorry did you say street magic is proud to be a part of the Zine Quest 2020 Kickstarter Event! For more great zines and other projects, check out Kickstarter's Zine Quest 2 page.
stretch goals!
In the spirit of Zine Quest's scrappy, DIY nature, I initially planned out only one stretch goal: at $2,000, the physical zines will be printed with perfect binding instead of staple binding. [ACHIEVED!]
However, because of the overwhelming success thus far, I'm excited to announce that I'm adding extra stretch goals in the form of a bonus supplement to the game!
street magic’s core ruleset invites players to build their city entirely from scratch, and to craft the world from consensus. I love that process of creating a world entirely from nothing, but I know that it's asking a lot from your table! Sometimes you’re playing a game with folks who haven’t played a tabletop RPG before, or your co-players need a bit of guidance to find an idea that really clicks with them. Sometimes you just want to build off of a foundation that's already there!
easy streets is a supplement to the game that will be designed to help support more structured pick-up play, as an anthology of quick-start city decks! Think of each city deck like a playbook shared communally among the table: it will include some backstory and flavor text, a handful of cards, and a range of open-ended prompts intended to spark your imagination.
The easy streets supplement will be delivered as a print-and-play PDF along with the final digital zine: at the start of a session, you'll be able to just present a copy of the booklet to your co-players. If you all decide you want to use one of the quick-start decks, all you'll have to do is cut up the cards, and jump right in!
At $5,500, worldbuilding masters Takuma Okada, Viditya Voleti, Ben Roswell, and Samantha Day will each contribute a city to the supplement. [ACHIEVED!]
At $6,500, we’ll be receiving one additional city deck apiece from the inimitable Nell Raban, Amr Ammourazz, Pam Punzalan (Pammu), and Sasha Reneau. [ACHIEVED!]
At $7,500, we’ll bring the supplement up to a round dozen, with decks contributed by Ben Chong, Natalie the Knife, Abe Mendes, and myself! [ACHIEVED!]
At $8,500, we'll be adding cities by Manu, Quinn Vega, Geostatonary, and Jamila R. Nedjadi of Sword Queen Games into the mix! [ACHIEVED!]
At $10,000, and for every following stretch goal, every person contributing to this campaign (writing, editing, art) gets a pay bump. This pay raise will happen every $1,500. Pure and simple! [ACHIEVED x8!]
about the team!
Hello, my name is Caro Asercion! I'm a nonbinary, Filipino freelance tabletop game designer and theatremaker based out of the San Francisco bay area. I've been playing tabletop games off and on for several years now, both as a facilitator and a player. I've also written multiple other games that you can find on my itch.io page!
One of my favorite things about tabletop games is the communal creation process: a roleplaying game is a conversation where each person contributes to the story. By the end of a really satisfying game, everyone at the table has built a memorable, shared experience, and each participant has left their fingerprints on a world that wouldn't have existed if any one person had been absent. I designed street magic as a way of placing that ritual of communal creation front and center.
Though I'm handling the layout, distribution, and fulfillment for this campaign myself, I couldn't have gotten this far without the work of my fantastic creative support team:
 Kai Gee is a Taiwan-based editor from California. She will travel the length of the country to cuddle the sweet dog in her photo (as long as that country is under 250 miles long). As an editor and writer, she values a tight sentence, but as a player, she adores games that let her build or inhabit sprawling worlds. You can visit her website at waityouwhat.com for your professional needs, or find her as @alpha3nine on Twitter, where she rarely forgets her "no capital letters" shtick and is almost always excited about something.
Kai has already given a ton of crucial feedback, and will be doing another pass once the game's layout is finished! I couldn't have asked for a more thoughtful, precise editor during the revision process.
Shannon Kao is an artist from Seattle, WA who works in comics and illustration. She's interested in stories about how places—real & imagined—shape the people in them. You can find more of her work at shannonkao.com.
Shannon's evocative, atmospheric art style and fabulist portrayals of urban life make her work a perfect match for the street magic — she was gracious enough to let me use her art in the zine, and she'll also be contributing a few new pieces to the project as well!
Quinn Vega is a queer game designer, graphic designer, and musician based out of Portland, OR. Her games include For The Honor, Lightning Kissed, and cowriting Songs for the Dusk with Kavita Poduri. When she is not making or playing games she works making microphones and leading her band, The Variants. You can find her on twitter @Mx_quinn and her work at mxquinn.itch.io.
Quinn has already offered a ton of support in helping me refine the layout of this book! As I finalize the black-and-white print edition and shift toward making the color PDF, her artistic insight is going to improve the quality of the final digital product immensely!
Final thanks and attribution
Before I wrap this campaign pitch up, I want to give a few final thanks to some folks without whom this project wouldn't have happened:
 i'm sorry did you say street magic was originally published as a hack of Microscope by Ben Robbins.
Thanks to Ross Cowman from Heart of the Deernicorn, who offered me crucial advice on organizing and preparing for this Kickstarter.
To my friends and peers in the tabletop design community, who have offered incredible support to make this game and Kickstarter campaign the best they can be.
…And a very special thanks to you, the person reading this! If you've made it this far down the page, I hope that you'll consider backing this project. Your support means the world to me — thank you!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The text of the game is completely written, and the game's black-and-white layout and illustrations are almost entirely done as well. The black-and-white PDF of the game only needs a few more adjustments to the layout and art, at which point I'll be splitting my focus between adding color to the digital PDF, and getting the black-and-white copy ready for print.

Though I've backed a number of Kickstarter projects and am well and familiar with the process of fulfillment, this will be my first time running a Kickstarter from the production end! In preparing for this project, I've received a lot of advice from other tabletop designers who have run Kickstarter campaigns before. Between the aggregated advice I've received from these designers, and working with a reputable printing company like Mixam, I have confidence that this project will come together cleanly.

campaign.story:
You want to know why you're lucky to live here in this purgatory, in our ruin of a settlement? Because Tigernmas is out there, and oh, the horrors he would set upon you were you not kept safe behind our walls.
The Ferryman dips their oar into the stagnant water, the red algae kicks up and all in the party (save the Cultist, who cackles in mad devotion) moves to cover their mouths. You had survived life, the great dust storms that whipped black dirt against your walls, windows, and bones, the plagues that tore through what remained of your settlement after the monsters destroyed it over, and over, and over again. Nothing could have prepared you for this foul and brackish nightmare.
You glance at Loam, holding his book tight, staring out across the blood choked swamp. For the first time, you see the madman step back. Doomed hands rise up, reaching, begging, and collapsing into the damnable red sludge only to rise up and reach yet again.
The sounds, the birds screaming in parallel with the cultists who stalk the area around you, the croak of death and stink of decay, the shadow of something worse beneath your raft, this place, this place is this place is... there is no coming back from this, there can’t be. This is the end this is the end this is the trees bend under the weight of the red lichen that grows upon it, their color all but drained into a sickly pale, their branches crumbling away. The stench, like blood and salt and rot, like blood and salt and rot, like blood and salt and rot, the feeling of terror oozing over the water and into your very soul, there is madness here there is madness here there is madness…
Loam grabs your shoulder, the sharp pain of his touch burning down into your bones, you gasp in pain, for a moment the madness that now clouds you cleared. In his other hand he grips his book, growing red around the edges…
“Coming here was a mistake.”
Casket Land is a bleak occult western RPG game meant to be played with friends in just one session. The game is Powered by the Apocalypse engine and focuses on making difficult decisions as a group. The core rules are FREE to everyone and can be downloaded at Casket-Land.com!
A brutal cross of Southwestern Gothic, the Dust Bowl, Mad Max and Vampire Hunter D, Casket Land centers around a dying town cut off by rows of caskets and vicious monsters unearthed by extreme drought and brutal winds. You are not valiant heroes in Casket Land - you are just trying to survive of the end times.
Casket Land Cruach zine features everything you need to play a Casket Land adventure including 32 pages, stapled with a cardstock cover and filled with thematic character classes, unconventional weapons, brutal monsters, darkly beautiful illustrations, and the pre-written adventure CRUACH (pronounced "Crew-ik").
You can also pickup Casket Land Homestead featuring the original Casket Land one night adventure created for last year's #ZineQuest! Giving your Survivors two nights of difficult decisions and dire consequences in the Casket Land.
Cover art not final.
A mad cultist and the lost he leads to doom, the watcher on the hills ahead of madness, ferrymen meant to cart away the dead on rot-soaked water, the dredgers bringing up things twisted beyond reason...You were told to enter this swamp and stand against Tigernmas' death-cult was to meet death but you've found something so much worse. 
The dark creature, the slaughter incarnate, the one their accursed tongues twist into the perverse pronunciation Crew-ick, he waits, deep and terrible, for new blood so foolish as to wander into his swamps. Cruach seeps into the earth, the air, the water, the minds, of everything in this hell. They told you to turn back but now you are left to wonder - what will be left of you to bury - and will anyone survive long enough to bring those paltry remains home? 
Interior and Cover art not final
Casket Land HOMESTEAD and CRUACH
“And so they clustered around Fergus' cabin, the one armed watcher pleading with them once again - Do not go in, his infected eyes pulsing a dim red light, let them destroy themselves and should the red lichen that mottles their skin, dissolving them away to nothing, take root upon your own, burn it out then. Do not go in here, do not face Tigernmas, do not fall at the shadow of Cruach. Go home and eke out your survival. Forget this place.”
Unsavory survivalists and vicious monsters inhabit Casket Land. Every player will choose a class to represent them during the game, each with its own skill... and weakness.  
CRUACH introduces THE FERRYMAN and THE CULTIST into the world of Casket Land - with more survivalists to be revealed as the campaign progresses...
The Ferryman and The Cultist Classes
Even in times like these, people think only of what they can squeeze out of others. What else is to be gained? What else can be taken?
 STRETCH GOALS.
We survive together, or not at all. Casket Land exists because you want it to. The more souls we convince to tread here, the more options will be made available to us all. Some of our stretch goals are social, some are monetary, some will allow you to add onto your original pledge and bring more Casket Land art to your players, all will help you bring destruction and desolation to the survivalists. 
As campaign goals are met more art will be revealed! My hope is that through continued support, Casket Land can continue to grow over time from a single zine into many tomes, complete with more adventures, monsters, atmospheric illustrations, and character classes. Cruach is truly the start of a more dangerous Casket Land, and I cannot wait to share future terrors with you. 
You were warned.
 SHIPPING WILL BE CHARGED AFTER THE CAMPAIGN ENDS.
All shipping fees will be charged AFTER the campaign ends via BackerKit, just before we ship the zines. By doing it this way we can ensure you are paying the lowest possible cost for shipping worldwide!
 We will ship the zines in bulk to a series of warehouses around the globe. Final surveys will then be sent to each Backer requesting their address and calculating an accurate shipping charge. We're going to do everything we can to keep these rates as low as possible.

updates.update_content: The final piece of art has been finished.

We did it! Thanks to almost 1K of you CASKET LAND - CRUACH is coming and it will be beautiful, bleak, and full of terror!
I want to say more, thank you more, celebrate more but I am tired down to the ichor that drips through my bones, congealing into the black peace of sleep. Soon I’ll lie down for the final time, amongst the wrappings and footprints of those who came before me...
At PAX EAST. Where I’m at booth 8120 slinging casket land homestead and keeping my eye out for peeps. I met a bunch of you (and some new survivors who will be added into the fray) today and it was fantastic, but I’m so tired. But tomorrow? I’ll be bright and ready to draw some horrible bleak stuff before running down to the show floor and celebrating with some of you IRL.

There's not much time - less than 2 days worth of water remains. We've lost 52 people to this place, this damned place. We cry out, our singular voices ripped to shreds by the screech of gore-drenched herons, our bodies maimed by the journey. I see him there, the Void King, the Mad Dredger, the Watcher who saw too much, Tigernmas. Cruach coils around his legs, the soft laugh of the great worm shaking loose infection from my lungs, spreading it to other parts of what's left of my battered form. Everything we did, everything we came here for, it's building to this.

WOW. We did it (again!) and it feels so good! Thank you!
Not only did the project fund (THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU), but in the past week the DREDGER and the KEEPER class stretch goals were... they were just destroyed.

campaign.story:
When you were young, you thought the great walls of Barrow Keep would keep you safe. But now you're coming of age, and you realize how many troubles have been inside these walls all along: duplicitous courtiers, treacherous kin, and puritanical heresy-hunters. How will you protect yourself and your friends?
Barrow Keep is a low-prep, old-school setting driven by playbooks and adaptable, easy-to-run scenarios. You play the young residents of the Keep, coming of age while dealing with mysteries, treacheries, and intrigues.
Inspiration & Compatibility
In summer 2018, my friend Maria Rivera asked why there weren't any old-school style games for a Game of Thrones-style setting. This project owes a lot to Maria's initial question and her commitment as a reader and playtester. The original game we ran with several other friends was deeply inspired by Beyond the Wall from Flatland Games, TSR's Known World Gazeteer series, and Whitehack by Christian Mehrstam.
As the project has continued through several campaigns and one-shots, it's grown past its Ice & Fire roots and been inspired by a wide range of writers of gothic, young adult, historical, and romantic fantasy, including Ellen Kushner, N.K. Jemisin, V.E. Schwab, Lois McMaster Bujold, Tamora Pierce, and Mercedes Lackey.
Barrow Keep is compatible with:
Old School Essentials from Necrotic Gnome 
Sharp Swords & Sinister Spells by Diogo Nogueira 
Thanks to stretch goals, we'll also be releasing materials compatible with:
Best Left Buried (Print, PDF) from SoulMuppet (See Questing Beast's review)
Trophy Gold/Rooted in Trophy (Kickstarter, Twitter) from The Gauntlet 
The Physical Zine
The 32-page zine includes:
Procedures for making your own Barrow Keep, giving each player choices about the Keep's rulers, attendants, and mysteries
GM advice and pointers focused on running the first session
A tour of Barrow Keep's locations, factions, and arcane technologies
A bestiary of the Keep's catacombs and the surrounding woods
OSR-compatible character and magic options
The Barrow Keep: Den of Spies cover by Minerva Fox
Digital Supplements
Along with the zine itself, everyone who backs Barrow Keep will get:
Seven OSR-style playbooks compatible with Old School Essentials and other OSR systems, including The Hostage, The Spy, The Wielder, The Lost Familiar, The Revenant, and The Wolf
Seven playbooks adapted for Sharp Swords & Sinister Spells, 2nd Edition 
Two scenarios set in Barrow Keep: "Treacherous Kin" and "The Changeling Spy," compatible with almost any OSR system
Handouts for players and GMs
Worksheets and a relationship map for creating your own custom version of Barrow Keep
Reserved PDFs, Watchful Advisers, and Knights Errant
We've set aside 25 copies of the PDF zine for $3 for backers who self-identify as students, members of marginalized communities, or experiencing financial hardship. Each backer at the Watchful Adviser or Knight Errant level adds 5 more reserved PDFs available at the discounted rate.
Stretch Goals
At $1,500 (Funded!), cover illustrator Minerva Fox will add four new pieces of art to the zine.
At $2,000 (Funded!), award-winning game designer Sharang Biswas will develop a new digital mini-zine supplement: A mysterious place in the woods where ghostly trains will take seekers to search for answers in the worlds beyond this one... for a price.
At $2,500 (Funded!),game designer David Castro will create a new PDF Playbook for Barrow Keep: the Foretold! Your birth was prophecied, but was it for good or ill?
At $3,000  (Funded!), Barrow Keep instigator and playtester Maria Rivera will create a new digital mini-zine supplement detailing the residents of The Crow's Nest, the home castle of a rival house.
At $3,500 (Funded!), Dave Cox, designer of A Rasp of Sand, will create a new digital mini-zine supplement exploring the strangers, guests, and other visitors who come to Barrow Keep seeking hospitality (and sometimes opportunities to make trouble).
 At $4250 (Funded!), Bill Roundy, aka The Bartoonist, will be creating print-at-home paper minis for Barrow Keep.  Bill's the creator of both Bar Scrawl and Hot Men of the Monster Manual (poster or book), and you can see free PDF versions of his minis for Modrons, Bullywugs, and Kobolds.
Social Media Goal (unlocked) Backers are choosing an additional system third system for Barrow Keep to support from three Creative Commons systems. Find the details and poll link in this backer-only update. The additional materials for system compatibility will be released digitally by December 2020.
At $5000 (funded), cartographer Abigail LaLonde (Patreon, Twitter) will create a Barrow Keep map pack with maps of The Great Hall, the archon's apartments, a lost crypt in the catacombs, and the upper portions of the Eastern Tower. I'll do a write-up of each map.
At 325 total backers (unlocked), I'll adapt the Barrow Keep playbooks for SoulMuppet Publishing's amazing game Best Left Buried, bring the total number of systems we're supporting to 4! These additional playbooks will be released digitally by December 2020.
At $6000 - The Final Stretch Goal!, we'll give everyone on the team a bonus!
Character Playbook & Scenario Pack Previews
Check out this video playlist with previews of five different Barrow Keep playbooks and a one of the scenario packs.
Social Media
Help us get the word out! Share the pinned post from the Barrow Keep Twitter account, or ask the Barrow Keep bot one of the following and share the answer:
Who am I?
Make me a character!
What am I doing?
Builders of the Keep
Richard Ruane (he/him), writing & design. Richard is the creator of Barrow Keep, Dark Designs in Verdigris, Moonlight on Roseville Beach, and Chronicles of the Spacejammer. An RPG editor in a previous life, he created R. Rook Studio in 2019. By day, he is an instructional designer and content developer living in Brooklyn, NY. Find him on Twitter, Itch, and DriveThru RPG.
Liza Cortright, layout & graphics. Liza is a Brooklyn-based graphic designer by day and TTRPG enthusiast by night. You can find examples of her work as a GM, player, and designer at ManaPot Studios.
Minerva Fox (she/her), illustration. You may know Minerva's work from such projects as Hearts of Wulin, Demigods, and her fan web-comic, Heavy Metal Sailor Moon. A lot of her inspiration comes from manga and western comics. She absolutely loves collaborating and bringing ideas to life with both physical and digital media. You can follow her on social media: @blue_troller on Instagram, Twitter, and Twitch!
Fiona Maeve Geist (she/her) & Jarrett Crader (he/him), editing. Jarrett and Fiona (MRC) are a duo of editors and founders of the MoonRat Conspiracy. They have worked on a number of works (collectively and individually) including The Ultraviolet Grasslands, Mothership: Players Survival Guide & Dead Planet, Troika! Numinous Edition, and many others.
Maria Rivera (she/her), rules review, instigation & stretch goal writing. Maria is an aspiring RPG author. She enjoys playing Troika! and other weird indie games. Find her on Twitter and Itch.
Sharang Biswas (he/him), stretch goal writing. Sharang is an NYC-based artist, game designer, and writer, specializing in games and interactive work. He has won an IndieCade award, two IGDN indie-groundbreaker awards, and a Golden Cobra Award. He has exhibited games at numerous art galleries, museums, and festivals, and teaches game design at Fordham University. Sharang is currently working on the anthology Honey & Hot Wax: An Anthology of Erotic Art Games with Co-editor Lucian Kahn (expected 2020, Pelgrane Press). Check out his portfolio and follow him on Twitter and Itch.
David Castro (he/him), stretch goal writing. David is a Latino game designer born and raised in New York City. He's worked on ORUN, Scion 2nd edition, and Chill 3rd edition, among others. You can follow him on Twitter (@theinkedknight) or find more of his work at Patreon.
Dave Cox (he/him), stretch goal writing. Dave is the creator of A Rasp of Sand and other tabletop games. Lover of all things design, aesthetic, and user experience. Find him on Twitter and Itch.

campaign.story:
I want to start by bringing attention to Kickstarter United, a collective of Kickstarter workers who have come together to create a union in their workplace. A vote was recently held to determine whether or not they will be successful, and during this process they are staying off social media, but I would urge you to stay informed by checking out their website and to be prepared to take action if they call for it in the future. 
This zine is made up of three different games. They're all based off the same single-player system, which uses a deck of cards and a six-sided die to generate prompts for the player to expand on. 
cover art from Alone Among the Stars
Alone Among the Stars is a solo adventuring game about exploring strange and fantastic planets and experiencing wondrous sights. I wrote it in the summer of 2018 while I was playing a lot of No Man's Sky really late at night. If you'd like to check it out before backing the zine, it's available for PWYW on my Itch.io page here. 
page 1 of my example playthrough of Alone Among the Stars
cover art from Alone in the Ancient City
Alone in the Ancient City was the first hack of AAtS that I wrote. It's about wandering through an old city with new eyes, and was inspired by trips to cities such as Venice and Montreal. If you'd like to check it out before backing this zine you can find the plaintext version on my Itch.io page here. 
Alone Among the Twisting Trees is a new game I'm writing for inclusion in this zine! It's about getting lost in a mysterious forest and the strange artifacts that you find inside. It was originally conceived through playstorming with Quinn Vega and Avi Margolis as an adaptation of another game I wrote, Alone on the Rocky Beach (not included in this zine).
In addition to these games, there are a ton of other hacks that have been inspired by Alone Among the Stars. If this zine doesn't stick out to you but you're still looking for a cool single-player experience, I'd recommend checking out the rest of these hacks! I've tried to compile all of them in this Itch collection, Alone at the Table. 
I think anyone can make a game, and hacking is a great way to get started. A number of the hacks in the Alone at the Table collection were made by first-time designers, and in order to make hacking the game even easier I'm including a template that you can fill in to make your own hack in the back of the zine, as well as a page or two of useful design tips to get you started. You could even use the journaling pages to start playtesting!
"In Alone in the Ancient City, designer Takuma Okada translates the melancholy, No Man’s Sky-esque galaxy-wide wandering of Alone Among the Stars into a more humble joy, one of discovering a city on your own. Ancient City captures the feeling of traveling through a place with a history and weight belonging to others, but wholly unfamiliar to you. Okada eschews the oft-trod territory of metropolitan tourism and spectacle in the pursuit of a more intimate exploration. This game is Urban Pastel at its finest." - Caro Asercion, designer of i'm sorry did you say street magic 
"Are you playing Alone Among the Stars? And following the Twitter account? Get on it. @among_stars_" - John Harper, designer of Blades in the Dark
Alone On A Journey: a collection of solo adventuring games is a 28 page zine featuring this amazing cover art by Shannon Kao. It will include these three Alone games in a new layout by Quinn, a blank template of an Alone game with some pointers so you can make your own hack, and blank journaling pages in the back of the book so you can start writing right away. 
the cover for the zine!
 The zine is 5.5"x8.5" and will be printed through Mixam. The cover will be color on 110 lb. paper with a matte finish, and the inside pages will be black and white on 80 lb paper. 
In the spirit of Zinequest, I've tried to keep the budget low while paying collaborators fairly. The total comes out to $500 given a 50 print run. 
$225 for printing, shipping, and fulfillment: This should cover a 50 zine print run and shipping related costs for a mix of US and International orders. 
$75 for the cover art by Shannon: The art is already paid for and completed, but this covers the amount that I paid out of pocket for it already.
$150 for layout by Quinn: This is a tentative layout budget for about 20 pages, some blank journaling pages, and a cover.
$50 for fees: This is to cover Kickstarter fees!
As you may have noticed, I haven't really budgeted for paying myself. This is partially because I've already made some money off these games selling them on Itch.io, but it's also because I really want this project to fund and put it out in the world. If it funds over the goal, the first thing I'll be doing is paying myself and upping the print run to 100 copies. Beyond that I've been throwing around some ideas for stretch goals but haven't settled on anything yet, and I don't really want to assume a huge overshoot given the nature of Zinequest. If it looks like we will though, I may announce some extra goals on this page. 
Hi! My name's Takuma Okada, and I'm a Japanese American writer, musician, and game designer. I started making games almost two years ago now, and I'm really excited to finally have the chance to make one of my first games into a physical zine! Some of my other games include Stewpot: Tales From a Fantasy Tavern, Chess: Two Kingdoms, and Etude of the Evening. I love beautiful places and strange objects and try to make them easy to find in my games.
Quinn Vega is a queer game designer, graphic designer, and musician based out of Portland, OR. Her games include For The Honor, Lightning Kissed, and cowriting Songs for the Dusk with Kavita Poduri. When she is not making or playing games she works making microphones and leading her band, The Variants. You can find her on twitter @Mx_quinn and her work at mxquinn.itch.io.
Shannon Kao is an artist from Seattle who works in comics and illustration. She's interested in stories about how places—real & imagined—shape the people in them. You can find more of her work on her website!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I want to lead this off by saying that I've never run a Kickstarter before. However, I've been a stretch goal contributor for several now and have experience meeting those kinds of deadlines. Two of the games are finished, the third is a hack of one I've already written and should come together shortly, the art is finished, and overall most of the game is done except for layout. I've received a lot of advice from people with experience running Kickstarters before and am talking to a lot of other designers doing Zinequest this year and I'm pretty confident in our ability to get this zine into your hands successfully!

campaign.story:
Splat is a zine focused on role-playing games and what it means to play them. It includes contributions from ten talented writers, each of whom are looking to redefine or challenge perspectives on play. Inside, you'll find advice on how to play games for an audience, and on how to resolve interpersonal conflicts at the table. You'll learn about how RPGs are used in therapy and in the classroom. And you'll hear thoughts from designers on agency, flow, and fun. Splat is brought to you by the team behind Skill Points (Zine Quest 2019), and we're excited to be back for Zine Quest 2!
What's Inside
Meg Baker on how to relax and get back to the basic playfulness we all were born possessing
An interview with Jakob Jaskov on designing games for use in schools
Elizabeth and Jared Kilmer on navigating challenging conversations and interpersonal conflicts at the table
Kira Magrann on how to share space when roleplaying
Chris O'Neill on telling complete, compelling stories without the baggage of a "novel length” campaign
Angeli Pineda on what it means to play tabletop games for both yourself and an audience
Dr. Brian Carl Quinones on using games to teach social-emotional learning and skill development
Jay Treat on games, improv, flirting, and the nature of play.
Jabari Weathers on play as learning and agency in play
 STRETCH GOAL: Matthew Gravelyn on how to design RPGs to maximize approachability for new players.
The zine will be approximately 32 pages in total. It will be printed in black and white as a digest-sized, saddle-stitched booklet. The PDF copy will have the same layout as the print version.
Meet the Collaborators
 Meg Baker (@NightSkyGames) co-designed the award-winning ttrpg Apocalypse World and helped launch the Powered by the Apocalypse game design engine. Her work centers on the idea that everyone has a story worth telling, and roleplaying provides a good framework for those stories. When not doing game design, she works in museums, focusing on non-dominant voices in local history and community in western New England. Meg is very fond of tea, rocks, birds, and socks, and can tell you a story about each.
 Jacob Jaskov (@jacobjaskov) is a game designer from Denmark focused on games that tell human stories. His works are based on psychological insights and innovative narrative mechanics. He has also developed a couple of learning games. One of these has been used in 20% of all Danish schools for 10 years. He’s also consulting within innovation, strategy and behavioral design. Recently he designed a novel user interface to library systems that has been rolled out nationally in Denmark.
 Elizabeth and Jared Kilmer (@DoctorsKilmer). Elizabeth D. Kilmer, MS, LPA (clinical psychology doctoral candidate from the University of North Texas) and Jared N. Kilmer, PhD (licensed clinical psychologist) are therapeutic game masters with Game to Grow in Tacoma, Washington. They leverage tabletop role-playing games to promote interpersonal effectiveness, cognitive flexibility, frustration tolerance, and perspective taking skills in children, adolescents, and military veterans. Check out their work with Game to Grow at https://gametogrow.org/.
 Kira Magrann (@Kiranansi) is a tabletop roleplaying game designer, queer nonbinary cyborg, and snake friend living in Columbus, Ohio. The creator of A Cozy Den (about lesbisnakes in winter time) and Something Is Wrong Here (an uncanny emotional love letter to David Lynch's work), Kira also has a Patreon and YouTube vlog that elaborate on game design process. Kira organizes #Aprilttrpgmaker every year and collaborates on the biweekly More Seats at the Table which is a newsletter featuring marginalized game makers. Follow current projects @Kiranansi on twitter.
 Chris O’Neill (@AllHailKingTorg) is a Philadelphia game designer and would-be wizard. The creator of Kobolds Ate My Baby, Polymorph, Mazes and other RPGS - Chris is focused on building the next generation of TTRPGS. He is also running a ZineQuest for more MAZES content, as well as gearing up for a Kickstarter this summer for the full release of the POLYMORPH Role-Playing Game Construction Kit.
 Angeli Pineda (@AngieIKnowYou_) is a Toronto-based writer and video editor. In her free time, she is a cast member of Many Realms, an actual play TTRPG podcast. You can contact her or find some more of her work over at angelipineda.com.
 Dr. Brian Carl Quinones is a licensed counselor that has been working with youth ages 4 to 21 for over 15 years. He focuses on studying game theory and design and how play affects the therapeutic process through socially emotional learning and skill development. Dr. Quinones is a therapist/co-founder of Gaming Approaches Towards Education, LLC located in Edison, New Jersey. You can find him at www.therapyinplay.com, where he writes a weekly blog.
 Jay Treat (@jtreat3) is making games in Philadelphia: board games from Wizkids, Mayday, Daily Magic, and Buttonshy Games; story games and LARPs on DTRPG; and a mobile game from Aconite. He is also involved in improv, volleyball, and inclusive church. Jay believes play can heal a divided world, and creates games meant to  broaden perspectives, illuminate new paths, and create bonds between us.
 Jabari Weathers (@GoblinPrincete) is a Black illustrator, writer, and narrative game designer who works with a gothblin flair from Baltimore, Maryland. They love the strange, unsettling and heavily existential, and often try to provoke these feelings in between moments of beauty in the artifacts they make, and are drawn to these tensions in the media they seek out. To kick off the new decade, they have been hard at work in resolving their first tabletop RPG; an epistolary game with a nasty edge called A Dire Situation. You can find their illustration work at http://jmwillustration.com and their design work at http://lunarveil.press.
Matthew Gravelyn (@mrmatthew) is a game designer, writer, and editor living in the Pacific Northwest. He makes small, narratively-focused games that are approachable to new gamers, offer equitable player agency, and, above all, are fun. His work includes Humblewood, Mall Kids, and a series of how-to guides on creating D&D subclasses. You can find more of his games on his Itch page. When not writing about games, Matthew enjoys being outdoors, making things with his hands, and spending time with his wife and son.
  The zine is co-edited by Sam Hotchkiss (@Hotchmoney) & Jillian Wakarchuk (@OrbWitch). Jesse Gazic (@gazictron) is our logo and cover artist.
Budget
Printing has been donated, so our only expenses are shipping and Kickstarter fees. All profits are being shared among the writers, editors, and artists, so your pledge helps everyone involved! We're asking for $1200 so we can afford to pay all of them a fair rate for their contributions.
Community Copies
As of February 14th, we have added Community Copy tiers at $10 USD and $15 USD. Community Copies are donated digital (PDF) copies of the zine that will be available on https://hotchk.itch.io/ when the zine is finished. These copies will be free for those who cannot afford them.
The $10 tier includes 1 PDF for the backer, and 1 PDF for the community.
The $15 tier includes 1 printed copy and 1 PDF copy for the backer, and 1 PDF for the community.
To add an additional community copy to the pool, Community Copy pledges can be increased by $5 USD/copy (eg. Pledge $20 at the $15 Community Copy tier and the rewards are 1 PDF & 1 print copy for the backer, and 2 community copies. Pledge $25 and that's 3 community copies).
Stretch Goal (UNLOCKED!)
At $1600 Matthew Gravelyn @mrmatthew (of Mall Kids fame) will be joining the writing team! For "Splat", he will be writing an article that gives advice for designing RPGs in a way that is approachable for new players, even those brand new to gaming in general! He will discuss elements like language, game prep, and required materials that make a game easy to pick up and play. Matthew has run two very successful ZineQuests of his own: Mall Kids (2019) and Mall Kids: More Malls, More Kids (2020) -- the rules expansion. We are delighted to have him on the team!

campaign.story:
Slayer. Headsman. Hunter.
Bastard. Murderer. Monster.
You have been called many things-
Your kind are found in every corner of the land yet your numbers are so small, and dwindle with each passing year. Despite this, your kin tend to find one another, banding together and finding solace in the darker corners of the world. 
But with each each hunt and every life lost, a question plagues your every thought: 
"Are the monsters the one you hunt, or perhaps the ones you serve?"
They Cried Monster is a monster-hunting hack for the world’s most popular role-playing game.
Based on stories like Hellboy, The Witcher, or Mushishi, They Cried Monster tasks a group of world-weary Hunters to track monsters, solve mysteries, and face the ethical dilemma of protecting humanity or the monsters they have been hired to slay. Hunters must balance social standing with the settlements and locals, as well as being quick to action facing down the dangerous creatures that lurk in the wilderness.
They Cried Monster contains:
 Steps for creating and playing as a grizzled Hunter, including character creation quirks and an on-the-fly inventory system.
 A guide for generating settlements and NPC's beleaguered by monsters.
 Social Systems for gathering information, placating superstitious locals, and trying to avoid a mob.
 Adventure system based on tracking monsters and discovering clues as to why they are attacking.
 Four unique and DANGEROUS monsters, each with habits, quirks, and reasons for attacking civilization.
 200 Backers - GM's Boon! GM Screen becomes available as a reward tier!
 $2,500 - A New Monster! The illusive Brakkenhorse lures intruders to a watery grave. Who is it that this creature is after?
 $5,000 - Fight/Protect MOTHMAN - The Fearsome MOTHMAN brings cryptic warnings and prophecies of doom!
