campaign.story:
Orchidelirium is a small tabletop RPG for 2 to 6 players (including a Games Master) designed to be played out over a 1-3 hour session.
As a player, you take on the mantle of a grizzled and hardy orchid hunter in 1865, traversing the depths of unchartered territories in search of rare, elusive, and above all, expensive orchids for your shady employer, J. Carmichael & Associates.
As a Games Master, Orchidelirium provides a simple ruleset, an adventure, and improvisation tools to help build an adventure of discovery at the table.
This Zine Quest project is to create a limited print run of physical copies of the game which is set to include:
Rules references for players and GMs
An introduction to the world of orchid hunting
Game rules
Character creation and character sheet
A pre-written adventure
Improvisation and adventure creation tips
Orchidaceæ: Mock up of the "customised" cover. Potentially not final artwork!
Game Play
At the beginning of the session a hand of cards is dealt to each player with six more placed face down on the table.
The player's hand matches up with their character's belongings and it's these that define their orchid hunter. The cards on the table are obstacles that get in the way of their pursuit be it the weather, environment, travel, messages, locals, or their own darned employer.
Characters either risk their belongings or cast dice (with bonuses for adding to their backstory) to test their wits to succeed in overcoming obstacles until they find their quarry or expire in the attempt.
For the Games Master, adventures are driven by the four suits (a treasure to die for, a shocking truth, an uncanny wonder, or a monstrous curse) plus an accompanying faction for each. 
Cards laid out on the table
The game is currently still in playtest but is due to have finalised rules by the end of the month.
 
   Rewards
The A5 printed zine will be a total of 28 pages (including cover) and printed in blue ink on 120gsm silk paper with a 300gsm pink cover with digital rewards to be supplied as a PDF.
Pledge levels are as follows:
 £4 - Bud: A digital copy of the zine as a PDF
 £8 - Orchid: A numbered, physical copy of the zine mailed anywhere in the world, plus a copy of the PDF
 £16 - Orchidacæ: A numbered, physical copy of the zine with gold pen highlights on the cover and rounded corners, plus a copy of the PDF
Worldwide shipping is included in your pledge.
Stretch goals
Wanting to keep the campaign nice and achievable I'm keeping to a couple of digital-only stretch goals, the first of which is:
 £800 - An A4 adventure creation worksheet will be provided for you to print out to help organise your own adventures
£1,600 - A printable A3 illustrated playing mat on which to lay the cards
  Schedule
The plan is to finish up development and writing through March ready for a short open backer playtest/review/proof-read in April (via text-only PDF) followed by some time for any feedback (that will be very gratefully received!) and tweaks.
Once the zines are back from the printers I'll be wrapping up and sending out the envelopes along with the digital rewards. These PDFs will be sent out via DriveThruRPG and itch.io (depending on your preference).
The timelines have been padded slightly in case of any troubles but hopefully it should look a little something like this:
 February - March: Finalise development and writing
 April - May: Open playtest, tweaks, and adjustments
 June: Printing and shipping
Beyond Kickstarter
Digital and print-on-demand copies of this volume will be made available through DriveThruRPG and Itch.io once fulfilment is complete with two further instalments on the drawing board:
 Volume Two: Settings & Adventure Seeds
 Volume Three: Victorian Life & Campaign Rules
These will be released either as print-on-demand and digitally or with a similar limited print run Kickstarter campaigns.
Orchid!
The Author
Over the last 20 years I have been designing and creating websites, newsletters, gig posters, band logos, cigar box ukuleles, pinhole cameras, soap, arrows, picture frames, paintings, terrible poetry, unseen webcomics, and 8 years ago I started to tinker with tabletop board games before falling heavily into the world of RPGs.
With a couple of Dungeon Master screens, a 200 word RPG, and BONGERS!, a very serious game about bouncing pine cones off a trampoline released, Æther Corp was born last Summer and Orchidelirium will (hopefully!) be its first release.

campaign.story:
Quest Squires??
QUEST SQUIRES is an RPG setting zine, presented as a fan-led restoration of a popular 80s fantasy heartbreaker. In reality it's being written by us with suggestions from backers, who "remember" what QUEST SQUIRES was like by sending writing prompts and voting in polls.
Zines in the '80s & '90s had a charmingly dirty DIY aesthetic built from cut & paste collage, amateur art, & grainy photocopy artefacts. They were full of ordinary folks enthusiastically creating for the joy of creating, & to share their interests with each other & anyone whose palms they could press these scrappy little books into.
The 90s was also the era of the fantasy heartbreaker. Heartbreakers were games that started from the basis of the most famous rpg in the industry, & added or removed rules to play their way, or reflect their homebrew setting. These games were before the invention of Kickstarter, & publishing often ended with a loan debt & the creators garage full of copies in mouldy cardboard boxes.
Along with excerpts & tables from QUEST SQUIRES & additional material from GMs of this fake game, the zine will include short articles discussing mechanics & bizarre folk tales surrounding its fictional creator. The look of the final product is intended to be reminiscent of '90s photocopy fan zines, but with more readability. Its main purpose is to amuse, but we dare backers to find a way to adapt & implement the contents in their own games.
(Disclaimer: T.R.R. Quigley Jr. & any other people mentioned in the final product are purely fictional. Any resemblance to actual RPG people is coincidental.)
Rebuilding
QUEST SQUIRES will be written with input from backers! With the original notes lost, the only way we can faithfully restore this extraordinary adventure is by asking people to tell us what was in it. Here's how:
First, backers will be polled on major aspects of the setting and its history, to determine the general direction of QUEST SQUIRES.
Second, backers will get to send us writing prompts. Every backer will get to name something in QUEST SQUIRES, like a person, a creature, a location, a deity, or something else in the world of Dragynrealm. We'll have to work it into the setting in some way. Higher-level backers can send prompts that define larger, potentially world-changing aspects of the setting.
The zine will include a short article about T.R.R. Quigley Jr. and the history of QUEST SQUIRES itself. Prompts and polls can influence that, too!
A few ground rules for prompts:
 Prompts will have word limits. We're not asking you to write for free. We just want prompts to inspire us. Limits are 10 words for names, 20 for everything else.
 Nothing obviously copyrighted. We don't need a repeat of the Expedition to the Galaxy Far Away incident.
 No racism, sexism, transphobia, etc. We reserve the right to reject anything we deem offensive.
 Do NOT mention Cordolian Round Tower-Glaive Shields. The QUEST SQUIRES community can not handle more drama. I'm looking at you, Kevin.
Other than that, write what you want.
Rewards
As a Zine Quest project, QUEST SQUIRES will be printed as a monochromatic, 30-ish-page, A5 booklet. All backers will receive a PDF.
Physical copies will be handled by DriveThruRPG. Please note that you will receive an at-cost print coupon, so you will have to cover the cost of printing (about US$2) and shipping. We lowered the price of the print tier to compensate for print costs. We're doing it this way because letting DriveThruRPG handle printing/shipping is easier for us, and also because most printers in the United States have banned Quigley.
Fulfilled by DriveThruRPG
All backers will get to name one thing in the QUEST SQUIRES setting. (Don’t have an idea for a name? Include yours! Or your pet's! Or a favourite character you made in an RPG! Or an important human in your life, I guess.)
Grand Paladyn backers can also send a more detailed prompt about a special location, important NPC, or whatever else they think is cool. We'll make it work!
Cartogrypher backers can send a prompt for a major detail/location on the map of Dragynrealm, which we'll work into the zine as well.
Arch-knyght backers also send a prompt about a specific character or monster of their design. We'll make a sketch and include it in the book for you!
Pen Dragyn backers get the benefits of the Arch-knyght, and they can describe one of the art pieces that goes in the book.
Finally, all backers will be listed in the credits. Higher-tier backers will get custom fancy titles provided by T.R.R. Quigley.
A giant floating tick-like monster impaling a victim on a spiked tentacle.
Stretch Goals
Everybody loves stretch goals! Stretch goals are a great way to generate excitement about a project as more and more awesome content gets added to a project. They're also a great way to bloat out the scope of a project & cause delays. We know what we have the scope to do in the timeframe we promise.
As such, we don't have any funding-based stretch goals. Anything above the goal helps to finance us creating more awesome projects & keep the wolves away from our doors.
What we do have is a social media stretch goal. If [this tweet] hits 200 retweets by the end of the campaign, every backer will receive PDF codes on Itch for the following:  A Duet of Steel,  The Lands of the Dead Dungeon World Supplement,  The Spellslinger Dungeon World Playbook, & The Sorcerer Dungeon World Playbook.  These codes will be provided for the files on Itch.io once the Kickstarter has completed.
The Squires
Adrian Thoen, Bardbaryan Archivist
An orc in fancy clothes reading a declaration from a scroll
I was introduced to RPGs when I was gifted a ratty old copy of QUEST SQUIRES. Well, the first half of the book. Someone had apparently sliced the 620+ pages tome in half to better carry it places? Without the full book, my friends & I did our best to play QUEST SQUIRES after school & on our weekends. From those days, a love of RPGs and a compulsion to Game Design was instilled within me.
My published works include 3rd party playbooks for Dungeon World, a number of smaller games including I Walk Alone & A Duet of Steel, and the successfully Kickstarted Impulse Drive. Working on restoring the game that started it all for me is a dream come true, & I hope you join me on our campaign to Rebuild Dragynrealm.
I am also the artist for QUEST SQUIRES: Rebuilded. If you'd like to see examples of my art, check them out  HERE 
Spellchatter me on Twitter: 
https://twitter.com/madadric
Peruse my wares on DrivethruRPG & Itch: https://www.drivethrurpg.com/browse.php?x=0&y=0&author=AdrianThoen
https://adrian-thoen.itch.io/
Paul "Ettin" Matijevic, Gyantslayyer
A Two-headed giant standing next to a halfling with a spear.
I'm assisting Adrian with writing on this project. My published works include Breakfast Cult, Retrocausality, and Oh, Dang! Bigfoot Stole My Car With My Friend's Birthday Present Inside. I'm currently working on Hard Wired Island.
I played some of QUEST SQUIRES 2E, particularly the DRAGYNVERSE setting. But really I'm here because Quigley defeated me in battle at GEN CON 2017, and by the ancient law of the Indiana Convention Center I am contractually bound to aid him in one (1) quest.

campaign.story:
Zine cover by Ezra Rose
The Watching Book is an artifact left behind by the oracles of The Singing Plain. It is a testament to their culture, homeland, and history as written by generations of their beloved spiritualists. It is a gateway into a place that is long gone, accessible to us now only through games. 
This Zine is the second Kickstarter set in the Soothsayer world. Much like its predecessor, the contents of this campaign are penned to be diegetic (in-universe) artifacts of a world long gone. This means the Zine is written from the first-person perspective of a variety of characters rather than presented as a module or dissertation. Through this Zine, presented as a “restored” and “translated” version of the original tablets, readers will discover a more in-depth and personal look at a society that worships the Wind.
The Watching Book Zine is a detailed worldbuilding piece intended to provide the DM (or GM or MC…) another tool for their kit when it comes to fleshing out the stage for their games. Although a creative person can use a good tool for anything, this Zine has two primary uses:
As a lore inspiration. The Watching Book provides a system-agnostic setting complimentary to fantasy or low-magic rulesets. The Singing Plain may be a quest location to stop and seek oracular advice, a mysterious rumor on the breeze, or the host of an entire campaign within its borders.
  As an artifact to give to players. The Watching Book contains purely diegetic information, with many old secrets to dredge to the surface. It makes for an ideal addition to a library, a discovery made among ruins, a tome passed on to trusted allies. However it is discovered, careful readers may have a more interesting time encountering its secrets for themselves than being explicitly told.
  In addition to The Watching Book, this campaign includes the one-page game Truth-Tellers. This game can be played in its own right, or as an event within a campaign set within The Singing Plain.
The Watching Book is a printed A5-sized Zine in black and white. It is ~24 pages.
The Watching Book serves as a historical record and cultural touchpoint for The Singing Plain setting. Each section is written from the viewpoint of a different oracle through history. Each oracle brings a different voice, perspective, and interest to bear as they record what was important to them in life. In loose summary, these entries cover the following:
A commemoration of oracles past
A hand-drawn two-page map of The Singing Plain
A deep explanation of the oracles’ religion
A rogue prophecy
How the temple came to be
Encounters with potentially magical creatures
And many other secrets to explore
  Through these triumphs, tragedies, and secrets, a complete setting with a rich history is developed. With this context it is easy for readers to place a story at any point along the existing history or expand into the future.
The Zine is illustrated by Ezra Rose, the same artist behind the visuals of the original Soothsayer board game. Their work embraces the single-color nature of the Zine format to bring alive the textual descriptions of places, rituals, and people. 
Useful herbs, and what rituals they help perform
Truth-Tellers is a GM-less game for 3 or more players that runs in 30 to 45 minutes
Truth-Tellers is a one-page ruleset for a game children would play while living in The Singing Plain. If you are an adult, fear not; the game has been played many times with adults of varying maturity levels. It is exactly as complex or as simple as the players choose to make it for themselves.
In this game you play as children (or adults, if you must) who themselves are pretending to be oracles. During play you will devise a unique mystery and solve it with the very wise authority vested in you by the blanket on your head.
The game requires no specific physical components and can be played anywhere groups of small objects (rocks, dice, raisins) can be found. It pairs well with The Watching Book by giving you a great assortment of lore to draw from, but can be played entirely without the Zine. 
Digital Zine--The Watching Book
This tier contains a digital copy of The Watching Book Zine as a pdf. All non-physical stretch goals are included in this tier. The pdf will be laid out in landscape view and be screenreader accessible.
Physical Zine--The Watching Book
This tier contains one physical copy of The Watching Book Zine and one copy of the pdf. All stretch goals are included in this tier. This tier is currently set to ship to the countries from which I received the most interest in my previous campaign: The United States, Canada, Great Britain, and France. Community Copy

Community Copies are a growing practice in the tabletop role-playing game community wherein generous supporters pay a little extra to make a copy available to those who may not be able to afford it otherwise. Games may not be a bare necessity of life, but they certainly make living a lot more enjoyable.
Commemoration
This tier contains everything from the Everything, Please tier. Additionally, you will have the opportunity to submit a two-sentence epithet to be added to the list of commemorated oracles. This can be a way to honor a player character past, or simply to have a hand in the final product commemorating your involvement.
Yes! Stretch goals were an oft-requested feature of Soothsayer, and have been brought forth for The Watching Book to please the people. Behold:
[UNLOCKED] Funded! Once the campaign reaches $450 The Watching Book and Truth-Tellers become reality.
[UNLOCKED] More Art. Once we raise an additional $200 past the base goal, every Zine will contain additional illustrations by Ezra Rose. This goal covers the cost of Ezra’s hard work and the additional formatting required to make everything fit together nicely. The art itself will include:

These pictographs, in addition to offering quick visual clues on related topics, will break up the text more thoroughly and provide another layer of depth to the lore.
[Final Goal Revealed!]
[$1,200] Audio-Zine. At this goal I will produce an audio rendition of The Watching Book, to be delivered alongside all copies of the zine. This rendition may contain small auditory embellishments, and will arrive up to one month after other rewards are delivered.
I (Sarah Rowan) am a game designer who very much dislikes writing short blurbs about myself. What I do like writing includes tabletop games of all varieties, LGBT representation, buff sword women, and cryptic poetry. I have a degree in Game Design, a black belt in Tae Kwon Do, and an awesome wife who inspires me daily. 
I have the pleasure of working with Ezra Rose again on this project. They are an artist, art educator, small farmer & Jewitch who lives with queer chosen family in Massachusetts. They have a BFA in Illustration from the Rhode Island School of Design and have previously contributed illustration and design work to the games Dream Askew & Dream Apart (Buried Without Ceremony, 2018).

updates.update_content:
And that is the end of that. The final international zines have been shipped, the audio zine is available on itch (you can access it with your existing download link), and The Watching Book has now run its course. I am grateful, tired, and ready to look forward. 
Now is not an especially celebratory time in world history. I hope this zine can provide you each some small amusement as it arrives in the coming days. Stay safe. Support black lives. Support LGBT lives, as we enter Pride month. And thank you one final time for supporting this creation. I hope to see you all again; I intend to keep on kicking, and making many more games.

All United States-bound zines have been sent! Keep your eyes open and your mailbox ready in the coming days; they should be arriving in about a week. International zines are packaged, but need to go through the post office-- a difficult task with the shortened pandemic hours. I hope to have them sent tomorrow, when I have extra time. I
If you have not answered your survey yet, be sure to do so! I have your zines ready, but cannot send them without your addresses.
As always, thank you for visiting The Singing Plain with me. We are nearly done, but only for now!

I have made the decision to go forward with the physical Zine distribution, assuming no new information arises to dissuade me. To that end: the physical Zines have arrived! I have stocked on rigid mailers as well, to keep the Zines as safe as possible as they travel around the world to their new homes. Now all that remains is for those of you who backed at physical tiers to fill out your surveys with your addresses. Check your emails, and if you have any problems with the survey please contact me quickly so I can get your information another way.

The Watching book is now released in its digital form! All backers should currently have a download link awaiting them in their email inboxes. If you are a backer and you do not have your link, please reach out to me through Kickstarter's message system and I will rectify this immediately. 
For any external followers, the zine can be found here: https://sarahrowan.itch.io/the-watching-book. And while you are there, Ezra has many other zines on their own itch store: https://ezrarose.itch.io/

I am returned from my heads-down hiatus working on the zine. This update will be brief, but hopefully welcome: The Watching Book will be released to backers in its pdf form on Monday! In spite of everything, I am proud to place it in your digital hands within the estimated "April" timeframe. 
Over the weekend the zine will be landing in the hands of my close friends and family, for final proofreading. On Monday I intend to send download keys to all backers. The pdf will be hosted through https://itch.io, as the file is too large to easily attach to an email. The site is full of other small zines and indie games if you'd enjoy to peruse them there during these last days of waiting!

updates.update_userinfo: An Update, in relation to Current Events
updates.update_content:
Digital fulfillment is still on track. PDFs will go out next month, as promised. I am deeply joyous to be able to finally publish my first Zine, and land it in the hands of you faithful backers. 
Physical fulfillment is another matter. By now I hope we are all aware of the global pandemic currently ongoing. As some of you may know, I live in New York City. My city is a hotspot for the virus, and currently under lockdown. This is not to concern you for my safety! I am very fortunate and as relatively safe as one can be. However. By the time the Zine is ready for printing and sending, it may well be either impossible or highly immoral to ask mail workers to carry these Zines first into, then out of my city to each of you. If this becomes the case, I will and social isolation is no longer in effect. This is not yet a guarantee! Anything is possible between now and then. But it is looking more likely with each day.

Hello backers! A small update to keep you informed on The Watching Book's progress. 
Today the funds gathered during the campaign were officially delivered to our team by Kickstarter. But even before their arrival, work has been underway to bring the Zine ever-closer to printing. Stretch goal art is underway, the Zine's text is off to editing, and all Commemoration backers should have emails detailing how to get their custom commemorations into the Zine. So far there are no snares; but I am being vigilant, just in case!

The end of this campaign is only the beginning of the next phase. Thank you one and all for accompanying me on this path. 
Ezra and I will soon begin working on stretch goal content and final editing of the zine. Once this is complete, all that is left is to order the prints and have them sent out to their new homes; safely in your hands. Simple as it sounds, I will be sure to update here periodically with milestones and any snares along the way. If you have questions or at all curious about the process, feel free to reach out to me through Kickstarter's messages or in a comment. I am eager to keep this process feeling open.

The final stretch goal has been achieved! This is a time for celebration as we enter the final day of the campaign. 
Thank you, one and all, who have helped The Watching Book come to life. There are no further stretch goals or final-hour surprises; only a gentle coast across the finish line. 
I will update on the post-campaign path to fulfillment tomorrow, once the campaign is well and truly over. For now feel free to join me in laughing and singing and watching for the book's arrival!

campaign.story:
Deep Nightly Fathoms
Deep Nightly Fathoms is a role-playing game about exploring dark, dangerous dreamscapes inspired by the beautiful engravings of XIX century artist Gustave Doré.
In this game player characters will dive into the Kingdom of Night in search of that which they've lost: a missing love, an heirloom, a truth. The Dream Master will portray dark landscapes and the denizens that dwell in its depths.
This zine contains all the rules you need to play, it's up to you to gather your friends, get some dice, pen and paper to dive into these Deep Nightly Fathoms.
Deep Nightly Fathoms is a low prep game for 2+ players designed to take you across hours of exploration.
Layout to pair art with game rules
Inside this black and white zine you will find a full game designed to take you and your fellow players through deep nightly fathoms and a series of random tables to procedurally generate the Kingdom of Night, all illustrated by the striking art of Gustave Doré.
Backers at the Demon of the Deep pledge level will receive a code to redeem the digital version version at DriveThru RPG.
Printed version
Printed version mockup
The zine itself counts with 40 saddle bound pages, 16 high contrast illustrations, plus character and DM sheets.

Backers at the Archetype of the Fathoms pledge level will receive a code to redeem the Print on Demand version of this zine at DriveThru RPG after the PDF version is completed.
This is a game about exploration, discovery and change. The Kingdom of Night is a land of sorrow and mystery, a place that rejects intruders and hungers for their souls. At the center dwells Oblivion, a black hole were everything inevitably comes to fade.
Will you be able to explore these dangerous lands, reach for your Star and return to tell the tale?
Deep Nightly Fathoms is designed for two to three players: one Dream Master and one or two Player Characters, with extra rules to expand to larger groups.
This is a SWORDDREAM point-crawl game inspired by TTRPGs like Miseries & Misfortunes, Apocalypse World and Lacuna Part 1: the Origin of the Mystery and the Girl from Blue City. It blends aspects of old school style games with a modern indie design perspective, while exploring themes of loss and yearning in a safe and open manner.
The core premise is characters charting the mysterious Kingdom of Night in search of their Star, one landmark at the time. Dive ever deeper into its domains, escape the lure of the demons that inhabit it and the call of Oblivion.
The purpose of this campaign is to cover the zine’s production costs. Without the support of a publisher it is almost impossible for marginalized creators to gather the resources to produce a TTRPG, thus the reason I turn to crowdfunding.
With your pledge you will finance:
Licences for art and layout editing apps.
Layout and design.
Text editing and proofreading.
Digital distribution.
Printing costs. 
Reaching over the stretch goals will also fund printing and shipping a physical version of the game.
£ 1000 Landmark Cards:
The first stretch goal would unlock Landmark Cards, a printable set of cards describing various landmarks of the Kingdom of Night, its denizens and its hidden artifacts.
For those short on time to run a session, here’s a deck ready to be drawn and played.
A PDF will be added for all Demon and Archetype pledge level backers.
Landmark cards hold everything you need to draw and play
£ 1160 Editing collaboration with Olivia Hill & free community copies:
Reaching £1160 would let us bring the amazing Olivia Hill to the project as an editor. She’s a game designer and writer with years of experience in the industry and the author of the recently published iHunt: Killing Monsters in the Gig Economy.
Free community copies
In addition the PDF version of this zine will be released with free community copies after the project is completed.
A big focus of this project is to make Deep Nightly Fathoms available to everyone. Money can make the vast majority of games completely inaccessible to marginalized people and we would love this project to be the exception.
We're going to create a pool of free digital copies of the zine that anyone can claim, with no judgment, if for any reason they can’t find room in their budget.
Every backer who pledges for the game will be paying forward one extra community copy to add to the pool.
£1390 Beyond the Gate of Janus:
A sample adventure to walk you through your first delve into the Kingdom of Night. Designed as an introduction to Deep Nightly Fathoms  and formatted for low preparation, open and play.
The adventure PDF will become available after the game is released.
£ 1540 Mobile PDF Version:
At this step I will design a mobile version of the PDF for better readability, dedicated to those Dream Masters who run games on the go.
Mobile PDF mockup

While this is Trinity Knot Studios first official Kickstarter we have experience running campaigns: Al has been involved with Wartorn Games, Spiral Arm Studios and a couple of independent writers who successfully delivered to completion.

Not hitting the funding goal means the project grinds to a halt, no layout, no editing, no book.

In order to keep the project straightforward and minimize risks we've kept the stretch goals intentionally simple; hiring an experienced editor to make sure you get an end product that is concise, well-produced and adding supplementary content after the game release.

We're running distribution via DriveThru for both the physical and digital rewards, which is tried and tested platform with very little room surprises.

ALWAYS SINKING, NEVER SUNK
The Garbage Barge has been slogging up and down the coast for years, putting into port and accepting unwanted things in exchange for gas to keep the tugboats running. It is a towering, leaking wreck, and it’s your home. You are a wizard or a pirate radio operator or a raccoon or a barge worker, or maybe you raise goats in the listing high rise that’s been dumped on the stern. Things grow in the trash. Chemicals are leaching out of rusted barrels, growing legs, and setting off to seek their fortune. Beetles tell you their life stories, raccoons steal your pens. Something in a diving suit disappears into oil-slick bilge water in search of baroque pearls. A forest of rebar sings in the salt wind. Out past the gas lake, there’s a town on fire. It’s been like that as long as anyone can remember. They say that no matter how far into the trash you go, it keeps going.
Most towns will pay just to get the barge to leave. Disposing of objects and people that are too dangerous, embarrassing, or on fire is a bonus. The barge is always hiring, and it’s a great way to get out of town quick. It’s not a great way to make money, but you might find something you never realized you were missing.
YOU GOT A JOB ON THE GARBAGE BARGE is a 30-ish page setting and adventure zine, ready to play with any rules-light osr style system. It includes maps, monsters, 100 kinds of trash and lots of drawings of raccoons.

campaign.story:
In the youth of your elders, seasons were unpredictable. The blistering heat of mid-season and the freezing cold of season’s end were fraught with destructive storms. Wandering bands of folk gathered within the ruins of ancient things and took shelter against the elements. Until one night, every soul witnessed the calming of the storms and in the clear sky, a twin moon had appeared.
The new moon was named Deliverance because prosperity and hope had finally been delivered to the folk. Deliverance did not rise or set. It was a constant presence watching over the Dirt. The seasons became more temperate. The folk no longer huddled in the darkness of ruins. They built shelters and cultivated the fields outside the walls.
You were born to a life of hard work and prosperity. Your family worked the Dirt and owed their good fortune to Deliverance. Ten seasons ago, a piercing scream penetrated the minds of the folk under the watchful gaze of Deliverance. The Dirt shook violently in waves of intensity that rose and fell like the sobbing of a child. The horrific screaming and quaking lasted all night. In the morning, Deliverance was a bloated and jaundiced corpse of its prior self. The dead moon pulsed with a sickly, yellow light. 
Crystals of moisture burned away with the rising sun and everything touched by the light of the Dead Moon was suffocated with crushing humidity. At night, the same light desiccated life with freezing cold. Crops withered in the heat, riverbeds dried, and the bastions of Mahn and The Shield closed their gates - beginning their isolation that continues to this day. 
Each season, there is a long night of dirtquakes and each season you have seen the horrible moon grow. The quakes release unimaginable, ancient malevolence from the past - only rivaled by the equally wondrous riches pushed up from the Deepdirt.
Now, you and the other folk who make a living working outside the walls are stranded and left to fend for yourselves in the Fields of Dirt. The Kingdom of Mahn and The Great Shield hoard food, clothing, and other much-needed resources. Armed trading parties are sent out from the walls to lay claim to the strange detritus you've found in the Dirt. Sometimes they offer desperately needed supplies in exchange for your hard work. More often they take without a thought. 
You have learned to harness the cryptic energies of things you find in the Dirt and listen to the calling of long-dead voices. The relentless dread of the Dead Moon pushes against the Dirt and fills you with a need to escape its oppressive presence. You must discover the secrets of your archaic history, conquer the fell beasts of the Deepdirt, or understand the desires of the Dead Moon - before it’s too late.
Dirt Wizards protect the shrines of the past.
Dirt is a tabletop roleplaying game about survival and discovery in a post-apocalyptic world of what may have once been considered a classic fantasy setting.  Dirt is a stand-alone zine containing all the information you need to play. However, you can also pick and choose elements from the zine to use in other games. 
To create a character each player chooses: a Kin, a Calling, and a Trade.
Each Kin has access to random trait tables you can either roll or choose from to ensure each player will have a unique character.
Play as one of three Kin of the Fields:
 Ruhn: Descendants of those still living inside the Walls. Use your influence and ubiquity to survive.
 Dareur: The result of couplings between Ruhn and stout elemental people from a time before the storms.
 Al-Sache: Secretive ancestors of those who dwell in shadow and the folk of the Walls

Al-Sache caught in the light.
Choose a Calling to guide your path as you explore:
 Reclaimer: Those with the talent to draw cryptic energy from treasures of the past.
 Arbiter: Folk who believe feats of power will make a difference when it comes to surviving the Fields.
 Provider: The makers of pacts with deities both old and new.
 Every Calling uses a specific set of tables to determine the starting abilities of your first discovery known as your Focal Item - The impetus for your journey.
A Reclaimer recycling the essence of an Artifact from the past.
Use the knowledge and skills of your Trade to reap the rewards of the past. Your trade will determine the tools you start with and what resources you gain from encounters.
The Pack holds all your worldly belongings. What you can hold and how much is handled with a revolutionary, and simple, grid-based system. You can easily see what will fit in your pack with the option of rearranging items to make room for more.
At the heart of Dirt is an encounter system divided into three categories: Denizen, Site, and Artifact. Each category of encounter can be successfully overcome using a variety of "stat" and skill combinations. Fighting a Denizen may not garner the best reward and some Sites and Artifacts only reveal their secrets if you can outwit them.
Mechanical resolution is achieved by using a unique D6 system with such features as exploding and locked dice. Many skills, as you gain experience, are linked to dice numbers so particular numbered results will grant abilities exclusive to your Calling.
Dirt is a 32-page,  8.5" x 5.5", two-color brown and black ink, saddle-stitched zine being fulfilled through Mixam Printing. Our goal is to bring you a final design unique to the character of the Dirt setting and push the expectations of what can be done in the zine format.
$2000 - We will add a Denizen, Site, and Artifact Encounter to the PDF.
$2500 - All Three Encounters in print! Each printed as landscape, 8.5 x 11, 6-panel brochures.
$3500 - PDF copies of Dirt will include an 8-page gazetteer of the Fields of Dirt.
$4000 - Gazetteer added to the print copy of Dirt.
Ed Bourelle is an award-winning cartographer, graphic designer, illustrator, and art director. He has worked with the best and brightest in the tabletop gaming industry for the last two decades including eight years as creative director of Privateer Press. Freelance clients featuring Ed’s cartography, illustration, and writing include Fantasy Flight Games, Onyx Path, Steamforged Games, Malhavoc Press, and many others. Ed is the creative force behind SkeletonKey Games, which he formed in 2001. skeletonkeygames.com
Simeon Cogswell is a ten year veteran in the table top gaming industry. Their works include Delta Green:The Role Playing Game, RuneQuest Glorantha, and GeneFunk 2090. In their rare moments of free time they paint miniatures, build Gunpla, and play board games. They live in Seattle, WA with their partner and two cats. simeoncogswelll.com
Tony Konichek is a Seattle-based artist. You can see more of his dark art designs at archfiendart.com
Lars White is a writer and sometimes artist in the Pacific Northwest interested in all things strange. You can see some of their recent work here: Crypto0321@tumblr.com

campaign.story:
Our story begins....
The New Tales of Oz is an RPG set in the peculiar land of Oz. You take on the role of a new generation of familiar archetypes, exploring the many bizarre things in Oz. The New Tales of Oz will be published as a 32-page, saddle-stitched zine and a digital PDF, brought to life by the illustrations from the first-edition printings of the Oz series of books.

Oz is a land filled with magic and wonder, but also dangers. Over the course of the nineteen book series penned by L Frank Baum, Oz and its neighboring countries were developed into a rich and chaotic world that was a delight to explore. The New Tales of Oz will bring that spirit to life at your table, allowing you to create brand new stories within the world of the originals.
The New Tales of Oz uses a playing-card system that is lightweight and easy to learn, using materials that are easy to find. This card-based system creates the same flow as found in the books, where characters shift from victory to failure, find themselves in escalating trouble, and rely on each other to ultimately triumph.
The archetype system allows for players to create characters in familiar molds: the metal person, the talking animal, the American, and more. Players are then able to further customize their character’s traits to create their own unique expression of the archetype, each of which brings a different dynamic to the flow of play!
Setting
Through their charming characters and terrifying threats, the land of Oz has enchanted people of all ages since the initial publication of the books in the early 1900s.
The characters of Oz remain favorites even to this day, with Dorothy and her companions being a part of many childhood memories. Oz offers up even more fantastical beings though, like Tik-Tok the mechanical man or the Highly-Magnified and Thoroughly-Educated Woggle-Bug! Any of the characters from the books can be used as inspiration for your own character.
And of course, the villains are just as memorable, ranging from the Wicked Witch to the more subtly menacing Nome King. These individuals are backed up by a veritable army of nasties like the nightmarish Wheelers and mechanical giants. You’ll also have to deal with storms, earthquakes, and raging rivers during your perilous journey.
Changes have come to the land of Oz over the last century, though. The age of Queens and Kings is coming to an end, and the new Emerald City Republic is rising. The old royalty remain behind to advise and offer their magical prowess to the newly elected Mayor Jinjur, who needs all the help she can get dealing with the surge of threats, new and old, that Oz is facing.
Mechanics
To play The New Tales of Oz, a group needs two decks of cards. One of these decks is divvied up amongst the players according to their archetype. Different suits relate to different traits being called on, like diamonds being played when the character acts towards their personal goal, or hearts when they help another character. The different balance of cards in the decks of the archetypes makes each character feel and play differently!
You can create characters in the following archetypes:
The American: Like Dorothy or her cousin Zeb, the American is fresh to the land and its wonders, but eager to see new sights, even if they just want to return to their family.
The Pet: Like Toto or Billina the chicken, the Pet is an animal from outside of Oz who came over with the American and is always happy to help out.
The Metal Person: Like the Tin Man or Tik-Tok, the Metal Person has great strength but hides a soft soul beneath a hard exterior.
The Fabric Person: Like the Scarecrow or Jack Pumpkinhead, the Fabric Person may not always be the best constructed, but is capable of excelling in all sorts of circumstances thanks to being a Jack of all trades.
The Talking Animal: Like the Cowardly Lion or the Woggle-Bug, the Talking Animal is defined by their seeming weakness, but their caring heart shines through.
The Good Witch: Like Glinda or Queen Ozma, the Good Witch has the magical power to overcome most circumstances, but has to be careful, otherwise they might find that power missing when they need it most.
The other deck is used by the GM, who uses it to generate threats, consequences, and wonders that might be found on the road to adventure. Will the party discover a Nome Army or a raging river? Will they wind up exhausted or lost or captured in the aftermath? Or will their triumph reveal some previously-hidden magical power or item? Only the cards can say!
What's this down here?

Stretch Goals
2.5k: 10 Cents a Word: At this goal, the kickstarter will be able to provide a rate of 10 cents per word to the writer.
5k: Expanded Art: More art will be included from the later books in the Oz series.
10k: Continuing Adventures: A whole new set of encounters will be included in the book, allowing for twice as many adventures!

updates.update_content: The final touches have just been put onto the PDF version of The New Tales of Oz! While it will take some more time to get the physical copies distributed, I hope to send out the digital versions as quickly as possible!

Sorry for the lack of update in April! I was dealing with some personal health stuff that made keeping up to date more difficult than it would otherwise be.

I'm happy to announce that the manuscript is out of editing! I'm moving onto layout now, which hopefully I'll be able to manage smoothly!

The text is currently in the process of editing! I want to make sure that everything is done as correctly as possible to make sure that you get the highest quality product possible. It is still in process and hopefully will be done sooner rather than later, but editing is absolutely a "done when done" step of this project.

I appreciate everyone's patience!

I have just completed the first draft of the text of the game! It's clocking in at roughly 7000 words, so you can expect a book that is at least 36 pages in length.

As for what's next, I'm going to be spending approximately a month in editing, art design, and layout, so you can expect the digital copies sometime around mid-March. Following from that, I'm hoping to have the physical copies sent out in a month from there, but that's dependent on a lot of factors that are still in the air.

So, no progress has been made this time, because I got COVID myself which has dramatically reduced my workflow. That said, I'm just about on the mends now and I'm confident that some progress will be made by the end of February!

I would like to apologize for the lack of updates on this project. This year has been a difficult and trying one for me, and I've not found the ability to get into the right head space to work on this project. I don't want to infuse the darkness of 2020 into this game. That said, I've also been reluctant to update you all until I had some good news, and that has been profoundly unfair of me. You all deserve to know how things are going, even if they are not going well.
I'm hoping to resume work sooner rather than later, at this point. There is a light at the end of the tunnel now. In addition, , even if there is nothing to report.

Hey everyone! I just wanted to let everyone know that the project is still ongoing! As might be expected, the current situation has slowed things down a bit. I'm at this point uncertain how many further delays will effect the printing schedules, but I am sad to announce that I will be unable to make my May 2020 deadline for the pdfs.
As soon as the pdfs are ready to go, they will be sent out!

Thanks to all of your support, we've funded!
As for what happens next, I will be sending out surveys soon and then I will keep everyone updating as we move through the writing and publishing process. We might be going quiet for a bit while we get the work done, but we will be getting that work done.

I want to talk a bit about how an encounter in The New Tales of Oz plays from a player's perspective.
The adventure starts when the GM pulls a card from the encounter deck and describes what it represents and how it stops the group from making progress. The group then decides on the best course of action (guided by what cards each player has available).
Once that's done, the lead player plays a card related to their aspect that they're using. Depending on the value of the card, you get anywhere from 1-4 points. Encounters are rated on a difficulty of 1-3, with most being 1 or 2. One other player can then choose to help by adding a Heart card and its points.

campaign.story:
The Bone Age is an old-school RPG of neolithic-era tribes struggling against the sudden arrival of bug-eyed aliens. You play a Tuzanian, a tribe of jungle-dwelling, vine-swinging, pterodactyl-riding, bone-wielding savages. Radiation leaked from the Invaders' crashed flying saucers spreads on winds of purple, blue, and white, mutating the land and its inhabitants. Meanwhile, a race of turtle-apes and ape-turtles sleeping in stasis beneath the surface awoke...1,000,000 years later than planned. And they were not impressed by the native population – or the alien Invaders.
 The Bone Age will be a 48+ page saddled stitched book with illustrations by the incomparable Jack Woiak.
The Bone Age isn't based on a specific OSR system, but comparisons can be drawn to Swords & Wizardry, Labyrinth Lord, Lamentations of the Flame Princess, and Dungeon Crawl Classics. The base mechanic uses a d20 where higher rolls are better than low rolls, and works in a similar fashion to the way saving throws and attacks work in Labyrinth Lord. Thus, an ability might be expressed as 12+, meaning you want to roll a 12 or higher on a d20. Placing the target number in the hands of the players means they get the thrill of shouting "My attack hits!" or the agony of lamenting "I failed my mutation roll," as opposed to the Game Master setting a secret Difficulty Class.
The Bone Age uses a class & level system, with levels maxing out at 10. The classes you can play are:
 Beast Stalker: hunters of beasts great and small, and the first to encounter the Invaders.
 Marrow Warrior: sentries placed around the perimeter of the Zangatur Jungle, known for their use of the Cleaver, a weapon of serrated bone.
 Mutant: tribe members who developed bizarre mutations after being caught in the radiation winds.
 Untouchable: men and women who tried – and failed – to challenge their chieftain for rulership of the tribe. They are outcasts, surviving on their own in the deadly jungles.
 Wing Rider: riders of massive flying beasts, whether reptilian, avian, or insectoid in nature.
While most of game mechanics in The Bone Age will seem familiar, there are some things that stand out in contrast to many other games. The most important is the concept of Attunement. The land of The Bone Age – called Kalsentia – is itself a living entity, and the creatures that inhabit it can develop a spiritual connection to various geographic regions. These regions are represented by hexes on a map. If you are attuned to a hex, you function more effectively in it. You can attempt to attune to new regions, but you risk the wrath of the land if you offend it – rock slides, earthquakes, and floods are just some of the signs that you have angered Kalsentia.
A map of Kalsentia, the Fevered Continent
 I don't want to give away all its secrets, but here is a taste of some of the things you will discover in The Bone Age:
The land is brutally hot. The north is dry, the south is humid. Many regions see rain only once per solar cycle.
With the exception of the PCs and NPCs, The Bone Age harbors no terran life forms; no horses, no dogs, no bumblebees, no bats, no platypuses.
 The methods necessary to create metal have not been discovered.
The bones of ancient creatures litter the landscape. Bone is thus a resource used for a variety of tools, including weapons.
Three alien ships crashed on the planet one solar cycle ago. Radiation leaks from those ships continues to be carried by the wind, infecting the land and its inhabitants with horrible mutations. The aliens are collectively called the Invaders. 
Advanced technology has been pilfered from Invader ships and Invader dead. Wise men and women have attempted to understand the strange items, to varying degrees of success. Player-characters will discover Invader tech in various states of repair. The use of these items can be unpredictable, wondrous, and dangerous.
 But of course! 
Yep!

campaign.story:
A compact and digestible zine of high quality material you can sit down and read through in the span of time it takes to drink a cup of coffee and be ready to run an exciting session for your players.
Introducing 5 Room Dungeon Zine, a premium new RPG zine that gives you low-prep adventures, complete with story and twists, that you can run as clever one-shots or campaign adventures.
This is a passion project I've been wanting to do for avid game masters and fans of RoleplayingTips.com for years. And this year's #zinequest is the perfect event to drive development and get this GM resource into your hands and campaigns:
 Done-For-You. Pre-built flexible short adventures you can run quickly and easily.
 Segue Adventures. Use the 5 Room Dungeons to organically transition between campaign milestones.
 Drop-In Adventures. Use a 5 Room dungeon when you need something fast because players should've made a left at Albuquerque.
 Raid For Parts. Sometimes you need ideas to help build out your epic plots. Steal the new monsters, magic items, locations, maps, and NPCs from your 5 Room Dungeon zine.
What Are 5 Room Dungeons?
Every issue of the zine will contain a complete 5 Room Dungeon (get my free guide via that link) for you to use as standalone adventures, side quests, one-shots, or campaign linchpins.
A 5 Room Dungeon is an efficient and fun adventure template that generates a complete adventure for a game session. It combines The Hero's Journey literary story structure with RPG game design best practices.
Despite the name, 5 Room Dungeons can be used for roleplaying, combat, wilderness, city, and underground.
For example, there will be one pure NPC roleplay 5 Room Dungeon in the first six issues to demonstrate to you the awesomeness and flexibility of the 5 Room Dungeon format.
The Zine
Every 5 Room Dungeon Zine issue will contain brand new, custom content to surprise your players with.
Saddle-stitched on good paper
Color cover and black & white interior
About 24 pages
A custom map for GM and a player-friendly version
A tricky new monster
A detailed new magic item with lore
An exciting new adventuring location
At least one new NPC for roleplay
In addition, I'm developing each 5 Room Dungeon to have at least one unexpected hook or clever twist to drive interesting new gameplay with your friends.
Finally, I'll be adding Designer Notes in each zine edition with tips, advice, and ideas on how to run that issue's 5 Room Dungeon for maximum game table impact. Getting into the designer's head goes a long way to helping you run great adventures.
About #zinequest
Now in its second year, and inspired by classic zines like Judges Guild and Alarums & Excursions, Kickstarter invites creators to launch their own RPG-inspired zines in February 2020.
I'm taking this opportunity to launch a brand new premium zine that features an original 5 Room Dungeon each issue.
I'm asking for backing on the project to pay for the zine's initial fixed costs for cover design and page layout, plus fund the first six issues' art and editing.
The final product for you will be six books (one per zine issue), approximately 24 pages each, with each issue focused on a brand new 5 Room Dungeon with custom designed game elements.
5RDZ #1: The Sunken Tower of Angry Shadows
Is this secret worth dying twice for?
The first issue of the 5 Room Dungeons Zine features an ancient tower with a dark secret in its cellar, below the foundation.
Built to guard this secret, the tower seemed impregnable with its thick stone walls, cadre of skilled guards, and deadly defenses.
But stealthy assassins struck one dreadful night. Bloody battles and screams echoed throughout the tower until the killers dispatched the final guard.
The surviving murderers succumbed to the last wicked trap, however, and failed to penetrate the cellar's secret.
Because of this near miss, the Powers That Be decided to bury the tower and hide its existence. Rumours became legends, and legends faded to dust as 1,000 years passed.
A recent flash flood has exposed the tower top to sunlight once again, offering up the secret to the first souls brave enough to plunder the dark, water-filled levels haunted by grim horrors and deadly traps.
Can your players navigate the layered dangers of the Sunken Tower of Angry Shadows and discover its ancient mysteries?
What's Inside 5 Room Dungeons Issue #1
The sunken tower offers you a unique adventure location. Each level is flooded with water.
Smart players might figure out how to drain the tower on level three.
Meantime, this is a fantastic opportunity for your group to master the swimming and underwater rules through fun gameplay.
This 5 Room Dungeon also contains layered threats. Characters must first face the dutiful spirits of assassinated guards bent on protecting the secret even after death.
Then your players must deal with the murderous souls of slain assassins who still seek what's hidden beneath the cellar.
Defeating these creatures will require teamwork and skill as the undead are well-suited to the close-quarter, inky dark halls, and flooded chambers of this dreadful place.
Long-time readers of the Roleplaying Tips Newsletter for GMs will know I always like to offer players two paths.
The first path, Combat, is sure to challenge even experienced players. Battling incorporeal foes in small spaces while trying not to drown is no light task!
The second path, Roleplay, allows clever players to negotiate their way past guards and assassins if they can piece together the clues to understand what the tower dwellers want and would accept in exchange for letting the characters pass.
And then there's the secret in the basement. What riches await those strong and clever enough to bypass the tower's deadly traps and defenses?
POD & PDF Supplied By DriveThuRPG
Both PDF and Print on Demand version of 5 Room Dungeons Zine will be fulfilled by DTRPG.
If you back a Print Tier, you will just pay for printing and shipping.
Here are the estimated shipping costs.
And estimated cost for a saddle stitched book is $3-$4.
I will send you a DTRPG Coupon to redeem for the POD version when ready.

campaign.story:
The best stories told by Niloshis the Whisperer here at the Dented Helm tavern seem to always involve a theft. That old half-elf sorcerer has got a never-ending supply of wild tales. The Lair of the Battle Mage, for example… it’s one of my favorites and the one that’s been asked for tonight. Yes, a detail or two will sometimes change, but the heart of the story? That’s always consistent. Here – have a seat. It looks like he’s beginning his tale… 
Tavern Tales #1: Lair of the Battle Mage is a complete 32-page mini-adventure delivered in the format of the classic gaming zine (5.5" x 8" size) -- hand sketched art, graph paper map, faux typewriter-style storyline and plot details, and fun props for the players to hold and examine. All this is wrapped up in a folded and stapled traditional fanzine that will deliver some nostalgia to old-school fantasy RPG players and a fun way for new players to experience the joys of the early days of fantasy RPG gaming. 
I have fond memories of reading through gaming zines when I was younger, and I even made some of my own. These were typically done during class, on notebook paper, and in pencil. (And I'd pay handsomely if I found one that survived middle school!) Low budget, for sure, but so fun to make and share with my gaming friends.
To honor the fun and uniqueness and rarity of the handmade, old school fanzines that have survived from the 70s and 80s, no more than 300 physical copies of Tavern Tales #1: Lair of the Battle Mage will be printed and mailed to backers. I'm going old school -- I'll  be printing them, folding them, stapling them, and mailing them. I've created the 300 limit because I can only print, assemble and ship so many in the month of October. (Yes, more of Niloshis' tales may make an appearance in future zines, but not this one. Read it, play it, and then tuck it away for someone to discover in a few decades or more.)
 For Tavern Tales #1, the story revolves around an infamous battle mage who is feeble and dying... and has been dying for over 50 years. His lair is rumored to be filled with treasure and magic items from his years of dungeon delving, but most of the eager and extremely impatient adventurers who have gone in for a look (and maybe a quick bit of looting) have not come out. Those who did make it out have verified that the battle mage is even more feeble. And still dying. Maybe now is the time for a brave party to enter the lair of the battle mage and see what wonders await?
NOTE: The adventure is for characters of level 1-5. A separate PDF will be made available that offers suggestions to the GM for modifying the adventure to suit specific levels and customizing the difficulty of encounters.
  There are only two pledge levels. Backers may choose between a PDF only option ($8 and no shipping costs) and a Print & PDF Bundle which provides a printed copy of the zine as well as a digital PDF copy ($15 - international backers add $5 for shipping). 
- $8 PDF Only: You’ll receive a digital PDF version of Tavern Tales #1 along with any unlocked stretch goals.
- $15 PDF & Print Bundle: You’ll receive a Print and digital PDF version of Tavern Tales #1 along with any unlocked stretch goals and upgrades. Shipping in the USA is included. International backers please add $5.  


  The following are stretch goals that will provide additional upgrades or material for the zine. 
•  DONE! $1,500: CARD STOCK COVER & SPECIAL ART! The Battle Mage Heist has been FUNDED... and NOW the 32-page zine will be produced with a single color card stock cover that features a commissioned piece of art. No additional postage required.
•  $2,000: A BONUS MINI-ZINE INSERT! An additional encounter or two PLUS more paper props for you to cut out (or photocopy) and provide to the players! This will be provided as a mini-zine that is smaller in size and inserted into the larger zine. No additional postage required.
•  $3,000: POSTCARD PAPER MINIS! A postcard with paper minis of major characters and creatures from the adventure. No additional postage required.
Additional stretch goals may be added...  
My name is James Floyd Kelly, and I am a full-time gaming writer in Atlanta, Georgia. In a previous tech writing career, I had over 35 books published. I have a reputation with my publishers for delivering my work on time, too. Now I publish the monthly Bexim's Bazaar: RPG and Wargaming Magazine, and I've delivered 14 straight monthly issues on time (always released on the 1st of each month). I'm the author of two Fifth Edition Fantasy adventures published by Goodman Games - Mystery Under the Monastery and The Fallen Temple.  I also currently serve as the Creative Director for JetPack7, a publisher of 5e fantasy RPG resource books, and I produce terrain crafting videos over at The Tabletop Engineer YouTube channel. I'm also the DM on Wednesday nights for a regular Fifth Edition RPG game. I do try to stay busy.
Since I began playing and GMing RPGs in 1980, I've been a huge fan of magazines and the smaller, fan-published zines that supported our hobby back when there just weren't a lot of 3rd party resources. I've ALWAYS wanted to create a zine (and my Bexim's Bazaar magazine has provided me the tools and knowledge to do it right!) and make it look like the old school zines -- photocopied cover and pages, typewritten text, visible tape where corrections and additions were added in, and the hand drawn art and handwritten corrections that were common. The trick in creating a fun zine is to make it look old school while still providing a rock-solid adventure. I have the experience both in writing adventures and publishing gaming content, so I have no doubts I can deliver your zine on time and that it will be something you enjoy reading and (hopefully) playing!

Hey, backers. Sorry for the delay in getting you an update a few weeks back. My mom (in her 70s) had a health scare a few weeks back and I was back and forth traveling and let work get behind. But the good news is all is on schedule.

Just as I've got backers waiting on my zine, I also backed a small number of zines... and they are starting to be delivered! It makes me all that more excited to get mine done and in the hands of backers.
This won't be a lengthy update, but I can tell you that the adventure is 80-90% completed and below is what I will be doing over the next few months:
- Have the adventure maps hand-drawn by my map artist friend, Daniel Walthall

I have a number of books on writing RPG adventures, and just about every one of them offers different advice. Not a big surprise, though... for every adventure writer out there, there's a style and voice that is unique to that writer and it most likely makes it into the book, even with a good editor. I've done work on both sides -- writer and editor, and as an editor I can tell you that trying to smooth out writing from two or more writers and make it sound the same is very difficult. Many of the larger publishers of RPG adventures will, for this reason, put out a standards document that outlines how an adventure should be formatted. Some will specify coin amounts as 10gp while another will say 10 gp (that space is required) and yet another will say . It gets even crazier when you start looking at stat blocks and new spells and magic items. (Yes, there's a WotC standards doc and it is insanely detailed.)

I believe I've mentioned before that one of the challenges of making an adventure that is both system agnostic AND for all levels is tricky. If I haven't... let me say it again. TRICKY.
First, anyone who has ever played more than one version of D&D or Pathfinder can tell you that there are rule differences. When it comes to designing an adventure, game mechanics come in two options: ALL or NOTHING. Why is this? Because if you pick and choose different mechanics from different games (ex: D&D 4.0 and Pathfinder 2.0), you're going to end up with a GM that is extremely irate. You just cannot do it. You either pick a game and choose to use its mechanics ONLY... or you decide that you have to leave them all behind. And that's where I find myself. It's not hard to leave mechanics at the door, however... trust me there. It's just that as a designer, you have to come up with other means for helping a GM to decide when they need to reach for a certain mechanic or method. Difficulty checks are a perfect example... depending on the game you play, they can be calculated differently, and even the values a GM assigns can vary from game to game. What is average difficulty in one game is difficult in another.

This update isn't so much about Tavern Tales, but more about how I plan on changing some of my methods when GMing. As I write this adventure and tune it towards any fantasy RPG game, I've been having to go over many of the 5e mechanics because D&D is the game I typically play. (So this update may or may not be relatable to you, but then again... it's never a good idea to stop improving your GM game, right?)
There are so many things I love about a fantasy RPG... and things I don't. And these are personal, so what I describe below is not meant to start a fight/argument or imply that anyone's game is wrong. This is just a discussion of what I (as the GM) want to get out of a game. Yes, that may sound shocking to some, but as GM, I want to enjoy the game as much as the players. And that means helping tell a story that everyone will talk about the next day.

campaign.story:
The Game
Vanquisher is a tabletop role-playing game about bold heroes, cunning adventurers, glory, and death. The game consists of a tiny set of rules, several settings, and ideas for incorporating these rules into other published material.
No pens or paper are required to play Vanquisher -- there's no need for character sheets or bookkeeping! This makes Vanquisher a great game to play on a car trip, in a coffee shop, or on a bus. Other than people, the game only requires two six-sided dice (2d6) or a digital equivalent.
The Rules
Vanquisher is built around a single challenge mechanic which encompasses daring exploits, bold feats, and desperate gambits. A player may invoke their character's heroic destiny to gain short-term advantages at the cost of hubris which will eventually lead to their downfall.
Every challenge represents the possibility of victory, defeat, or even death. In the "classic" tradition, Vanquisher focuses its rules on resolving these dire encounters. Rolling two dice (2d6), a player learns their character's fate with a single roll.
In addition to explaining the challenge mechanic itself, the rules contain:
principles for running Vanquisher
advice on achieving particular effects using challenges
a setting guide to accommodate different themes and styles of play
how to run preexisting adventure modules using Vanquisher
appendices with optional rules and variant suggestions
Only the player who chooses to act as Storyteller (i.e. GM) will need to read the entire rule book -- other players will be able to pick the rules up as they go.
The Zine
In addition to the rules, the Vanquisher zine will feature black and white artwork by Nate Treme. I expect to be emailing backers the PDF rules before the physical zine is printed. Additionally, I will work to make the PDF accessible to players with screen readers and other assistive technologies and will offer PDF updates to correct typos, errata, and formatting issues that interfere with legibility.
The plain text of Vanquisher (without formatting or artwork) will be freely available on the internet.
Zine mock up (subject to change)
The Inspiration
Vanquisher was inspired by a forum post about a PbtA hack with an "old-school" feel that could easily be played by blind or visually-impaired players. I got interested in boiling an RPG system down to the simplest one that could still tell thrilling stories, reward crafty play, and provide unexpected victory or untimely death.
Addendum: I support the workers at Kickstarter United who are organizing to form a union with OPEIU Local 153 and particularly their right to organize a union.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my first Kickstarter, although I have pressed and sold music through mail-order so I'm not new to following through on these kind of commitments. I've intentionally kept the project simple and avoided stretch goals that could make it more difficult to complete. I've also limited the number of physical zines I'll need to print to ensure it stays manageable.

The rules to the game are already developed, and much of the prose is already written. The majority of the work to be done is editing, layout, and more playtesting. I'm planning to provide early versions of the PDF to get feedback about the layout and text, especially from those who use accessibility devices to read.

Nate Treme (of the Highland Paranormal Society) is providing the illustrations. He's an experienced illustrator with a track record of releasing great games, so I'm confident the art will not pose a problem.

updates.update_userinfo: Tragic update for a tragic game
updates.update_content:
First, my sincerest apologies on the lack of communication about Vanquisher. I'm sad to be sending you all this message.
Since COVID-19 happened, I've been unable to make progress on the zine. Between work, childcare, and other factors I've had very little time to work on it, and haven't been able to use the time I did have effectively. I thought I was close to finishing when I ran the campaign but at this point it's not clear what realistic timeline I can give you, or what useful update exists.
In particular: the guilt and anxiety I feel about the current state of the Vanquisher zine is making it impossible for me to finish. Whenever I think about working on the zine I immediately start thinking about how overdue it is, how overdue a status update is, and how little I have to say about it.

Hello friends,
(I'm sorry for the lateness of this post. Things have slipped and despite a lack of concrete details at this point it seems better to just give you all an update on how things are going.)
The good news is that I and my family are healthy and safe and I still have a job that I can do remotely. We are doing as well as can be expected.

This one is coming a few days late. Sorry!
 One major piece of news is that in addition to providing illustrations for the zine, Nate Treme has also agreed to help with the layout. This is a huge relief for me -- I had been planning to dust off my ancient LaTeX skills to do the page layout and formatting. I'm continuing to plow my free time into getting a complete rough draft finished, although I haven't done as much as I had hoped to. We're not behind schedule yet but we will be if I don't get a move on!

My free time this week has involved childcare and compulsively reading about US politics and the Coronavirus. But I've also managed to spend some time on Vanquisher, in particular on
examples of play to help demonstrate the game
some rough outlining and notes for the game settings
writing, editing, and rewriting the text

At 300% of the original goal, I can safely say that the campaign has been a huge success! Thank you again to everyone who has backed the project.
Now down to the nuts and bolts of this update: what can you expect?
First, I'm planning to do weekly updates on progress. Some weeks there may not be much to report but I'll make sure to check in to keep you all in the loop. I'll also make sure to respond to any new comments on the project page (if I haven't already done so) since I may not be checking for comments every day.

Vanquisher is funded! Hurrah!
Thanks to everyone who's backed the project so far. I'm blown away by the interest folks have shown in this game, and I will work hard to make the best zine that I can.
Since there aren't any stretch goals to reach, I likely won't post too many more updates on the project until the funding period is over. But I will be watching this space closely, so feel free to ask questions or leave comments here.

campaign.story:
The villagers of Edmund Valley work tirelessly as the overbearing sun scorches the drought-dried land. Though the drought has made things difficult for the people, they have hope, because they know that when the sun reaches its peak on the hottest day of the year, they arrive, and they bring miracles with them.
Procession is a game about monsters and miracles. It is a game about imagining a village, and then making it better through unconventional means. It is a game about empathizing with bizarre beings. You do not play any single character, but embody the town of Edmund Valley as a whole and the bizarre creatures that pass through it.
Procession is a short single-player game, and is inspired by both Avery Alder's The Quiet Year and Takuma Okada's Alone series. The only thing required to play the game is a deck of cards, but I would recommend using paper and pencil as well to record your thoughts. The game is 8 pages long including the front and back cover, and features Wendel Dietterlin's Renaissance art, Procession of Monstrous Figures.
Due to differences in available printers, US versions of the zine will be printed on letter-sized paper and UK versions of the zine will be printed on A4 paper. If you do not live in either the US or the UK, the PDF reward will come with printing instructions if you want to print your own copy!
Stretch Goals!
Procession is now getting stretch goals! These stretch goals will unlock new PDFs to add more variety to the game! Backers at any level will receive all unlocked stretch goal content! Stretch goal rewards will be delivered at a later date.
Stretch Goal 1 ($600): Procession Expanded
Procession Expanded doubles the number of events that can happen during the Procession, with new rules to allow you to play with two suits of cards or stick with a single suit and choose one of two options each time you draw.
Stretch Goal 2 ($750): Four Suit Procession
Four Suit Procession adds new events that can happen during the Procession, allowing you to play with a full deck of cards instead of just one suit!
The People Behind Procession
Tyler Magruder is a nonbinary tabletop game designer and writer. The guiding principle behind their game design is finding a way to make the gameplay resonate with the themes and stories being told. Also they just really like monsters. You can find their work on itchio and Patreon, and their thoughts on Twitter.
Chloe Montgomery will be handling UK printing and shipping!
Wendel Dietterlin the Younger was a German artist who worked in the 17th Century. No portrait of him exists to my knowledge so I had to use his art to represent him instead.

campaign.story:
Love is choice. Maybe not the magic that's wrapped up in feeling, but every bit of the doing, however impulsive, is picking a thing. Deciding. Stepping down one road and not any other. 
Hello! I'm Nora Jury-Last, a writer/accessibility coordinator/freelance logistics femme and the author of small, cozy games like Sunbeam, MOON'S HAUNTED and the forthcoming Thyme Heist - a game you play by snacking with friends. I'm excited by the power of games to shape our behavior in The Real World™ and by the ways that our gaming materials shape our experiences of the games we play. Which brings us here, to something a little different.
Ever in Her Sights is a game for one to five players, using a Rider-Waite style tarot deck + a series of questions to map the story of fae knights claiming glory and love for their High Queen. You'll decide what's worth holding on to, and what you'll give up to win a prize for someone you love more than your own heart. 
The game itself is setting agnostic - very few things are innately true about this world. There's magic and there are fae, but it's up to you and your sworn band to decide how much, and what form it takes. Inspired by the profusion of evocative tarot decks available, each game is shaped as much by the deck you choose to play with as the game rules. The full game text is available for free via itch.io if you'd like to try it on for size. 
The Details: 
This Kickstarter covers the cost of polishing up the final text, layout, and printing a limited run of zines. The expanded PDFs will include a write up of some tarot decks I love personally, as well as alternate resources for interpreting the cards and a version laid out for large-type reading/print & play. The physical zine is eight pages and pocket-sized (approximately 2"x3"), printed in black & white 10 pt font. Any excess copies will be for sale via itch.io and at conventions but, while the PDFs will be available indefinitely, I won't be ordering a second print run if this sells out.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I work behind the scenes at Posthuman Studios, managing both product ordering and fulfillment for their web store. So, this isn't my first rodeo!

The zine is written and in final layout (photos of assembled zine to come!) and will be fulfilled via USPS First Class Mail to manage postage costs. The tiers are simple and we'll be tackling all printing and zine assembling in house, so the fulfillment timeline doesn't have many (any) external moving parts. The second print run of MOON'S HAUNTED has already been ordered so, barring a postal strike, I'm confident that copies will be in your grubby mitts by mid-March.

While I don't anticipate it, it's also possible that we'll sell out of physical copies! I've decided to print a limited one-off run for a reason: it's important to me to balance keeping this game accessible with what I know I can produce and deliver in a reasonable timeline. For me, that means limiting the number of copies that I'll be printing, folding, and mailing out.

The good news is that everyone who backs at $7 or above will have access to all the files, which means print & play copies for as long as your storage media shall last. If we do run out of physical copies in the reward tiers, I'll set up a separate backer level for the print & play files + all unlocked content rewards.
