campaign.story:
In Mage Against The Machine you take on the roll of time-travelling wizards attempting to stop the robot apocalypse.  You will travel back to the moments in your lives you have the most connection to in the hopes of finding the events that set in motion the destruction of civilization. But meddling with reality comes at a cost. Each time you use your magic to alter the world you generate anomalies, push too hard and the things you care about most may no longer exist in the present.
Players will create their character by giving them a defining memory they are able to travel back to. Unlike many other games, Mage Against The Machine doesn't use a GM. Instead the player whose moment it is fills in all the details; this player is also unable to take any direct action to alter the timeline or risk catastrophic destruction. Each player will get a chance to take on the role of answering the other players' questions as you visit that moment.
All the players are still responsible for keeping the game interesting. There are two big ways the game encourages this. First, when a player rolls a failure any player can jump in and explain why the plan didn't work. Additionally, as players generate anomalies by messing with time they can be spent to alter any detail provided by the player answering questions about their moment.
After the players have visited each moment and stopped the moments that lead to the machine uprising comes the resolution phase. Each player rolls multiple dice based on how many anomalies were caused in their moment to determine if and how exactly the thing they cared about most has been warped in the present. Mage Against The Machine is a game about risking it all, delving into memories, and coping with loss.
There are two ways you can get your hands on a copy of the game. You can receive a PDF copy of the game for $5 or you can receive both a PDF and a physical Zine for $9. The game is already playtested, edited, and full of art so we're ready to start delivering as soon as the campaign ends. Support us now by backing this project and get ready to save the world!
Now offering a mint tin edition of the game for convenient pocket-sized travel! The mint tin edition has the same rules as the original, but with a twist. The players use prompt cards to determine how the robot apocalypse started instead of drafting up note cards, great for jumping straight into a game.

campaign.story:
YOU ARE IN A TAVERN is a fast-paced  GMless role-playing game for 3-5 players with narrative mechanics to encourage roleplay and interaction between the players.
Une description en français est disponible ici.
The tavern (or the inn) is literally a commonplace in a fantasy  medieval setting. This is where heroes meet. It is there that a more or  less mysterious sponsor give them their quest. It's here than the  adventure begins, before the dungeon, its traps, its monsters and its  treasures.
 AND IF... what was happening at the tavern was the REAL adventure? 
No prep, just play
Gather your friends and become a group of adventurers looking for work in a shady tavern or fancy establishment
Fast-paced character and setting creation
Engage your fellow players and build the story together - it can be humourous, horrific or epic
The game aims at creating satisfying 2-hour sessions (campaign options will be made available)
Can I have an early peek at the game?
Yes, you can! The early version of the game is available on itch.io for free. This kickstarter aims at completing the game in a zine format (so please remember that it is a demo version, not the final game).
You can also listen to an actual play on the French podcast "La Rolisterie" (in French, of course).
The game will be available in French and in English.
Preliminary layout - not definitive
You are in a tavern is part of the Zine Quest initiative.
> 900$ - Tavern Generator - 300 ideas to feed your imagination // UNLOCKED!
YOU ARE IN A TAVERN is based on the inventiveness and improvisation skills of the players. To facilitate the spontaneous creation process, I will create an idea generator - for decor elements, secondary characters and quests.
300 ideas to feed your games, presented in two digital formats to print: random tables and playing cards.
The idea generator will be added free to supporters of level Heroic Adventurer and above.
  A printed version is currently being considered as an "add-on".

> 1200$ - MORE SETTINGS / VIKINGS AND STEAMPUNK  // UNLOCKED!
The game focuses on classic med-fan tropes, but you can decide to explore other settings. A few pages will be added to guide you to specifically create a game with a viking or steampunk theme.
 > 1500$ - SESSION ZERO / TOOLS AND TIPS TO MOVE FROM THE TAVERN TO THE BIG GAME  // UNLOCKED!
YOU ARE IN A TAVERN aims to create short one-shot sessions filled with interactions. You can also use the game as session zero for your campaigns, a kind of structured brainstorm where you will shape your heroes, the setting and the tone of your future adventures.
I will create a short guide to give you tools and tips to transform a game of YOU ARE IN A TAVERN in a session zero for your campaign - specific rules/tools will be compatible with Dungeons & Dragons, Blades in the dark and FATE.

campaign.story:
Generations ago, humanity sowed the seeds of its own demise by exploiting the land and trying to control the powers of nature. Some tried to stop it, but not enough did. The earth’s systems broke down. The sun turned cities into kilns and the sea crept steadily inland. Millions of fish washed ashore, birds fell from the sky, and blight wiped out trees. Towering floods and withering droughts led to displacement and social collapse. Those who did the least to cause it suffered the most.
We only got one try — and we failed. 
Lost Roads is a fantasy role playing game that follows migrants on their journey through a harsh, unforgiving world. Humans, once rich with magic and resources, exploited nature beyond its means. Modern society collapsed, falling to a pre-medieval level of technology. Pockets of civilization now huddle within barren and twisted landscapes, connected by the Lost Roads—defunct, reclaimed pathways.
The player characters, driven out by climate disaster, travel the Lost Roads together in search of a place to call home. Each character has a role and an elemental domain—earth, fire, water, or air. They can use their magic to enhance or pervert nature to reach their goal; but harming the environment empowers a malevolent, supernatural Storm.
If you survive the Lost Roads and reach the Borderlands, journey’s end, you bring new hope. If you fail, humanity dries up and blows away like so much parched grain. You survive not just for yourself and those around you, but those who will come after. For without you, there are no roots from which a new society can flourish.
The game is designed for 2-5 players including a GM, and is inspired by The Road, A Quiet Place, Annihilation, Fast Color, and similar stories. It can be run as a one shot or a short campaign lasting 2-5 sessions.  
Lost Roads offers a new system to tell a unique tale of environmental trauma in a bygone, fantasy setting. This game is rooted in story-games of a similar tone, such as The Quiet Year, Versus Nature, Legacy Life Among the Ruins, and Downfall. Players can revel in rich, sensory narrative about their relationships, themselves, and the perilous world around them. But Lost Roads also draws inspiration from the stress and grit of mechanics that reward player ingenuity, character competency, and managing time and resources.
The system was built from the ground up to be highly modular. Play cycles fluidly through several phases with a push and pull between survival, sheltering, and moving on to new places.
Lost Roads uses an elegant D6 die pool system with varying degrees of success and failure, designed for exploring tense survival stories of eco-migrants and supernatural climate fiction. If you roll well, your Motif—a magic symbol inspired by nature—reveals hidden secrets.
 Download: A preview of how to make Survival Rolls.
When characters take refuge, simple scene-by-turn rules allows them to steal a moment to share a meal, a story, a dream. Then go forth once more to see if you can edge closer towards finding a home. 
The characters you play are the Tarnished—eco-migrants on a dangerous journey after society’s collapse. This marginalized group shares the gift of magic as it fades away. “Tarnished” is the image your detractors see: the wear and tear on your body and clothing, viewing your capabilities negatively rather than cherishing them.            
You gather hope to use magic.
Each character has a Role—a character’s walk of life. Each Role honors three vows, and fulfilling any of them increases Hope—what characters need to use magic, to stand firm against the Storm, and increase the community's prosperity. The four roles are: 
HEART. You devote yourself to the survival of those who need it most. Defend the vulnerable. Heal the injured. Deliver goods. 
KEEPER. The wilds guide your spirit, you must let both flourish. Defend wild places. Clean polluted spaces. Find and restore carbon sinks. 
RECLAIMER. You discover hope amidst fallen ruins and discarded scrap. Scavenge wreck and ruin. Shore up structures. Find and mark renewable resources. 
SEEKER. You seek paths like a meandering river. Branching, flexible, determined. Overcome obstacles. Blaze a trail for others to follow. Find and mark hideaways. 
A practitioner of earth magic.
Each character also chooses a Domain, a source of primeval magic which is fading from the world. Your domain influences what your magic does and how it manifests.
EARTH. A duality of trembling and unyielding. You have power to phase through solid barriers and form protective fields.
FIRE. An apparition of igniting and searing. You have power to emit a gush of flame or pass through fire unharmed.
WATER. A source tidal and unfathomable. You have power to raise waves of water or summon water spirits.
AIR. A shield, gusty and windswept. You have power to slash with wisps of wind or discharge electricity.    
Download: A preview of the Character Sheet, Seeker Role, and Earth Domain. 
Humanity is on a collision course with nature.
The Long Storm is a malevolent force of awesome, destructive power. A trembling vortex of metaphysical energy and dying magic. It embodies the decay of human society. You cannot defeat it. At best, you can only hide or escape from it.
Mistaken—creatures of eco-horror—are spawned in the eye of the Storm. These are chimeric horrors adapted to survive in extreme environments, hunting human prey.   
A complete game features five core phases:
In Worldbuilding, create a fantastic world together with flow and balance between human and natural communities, science, and nature. You create four Landmarks that stand the test of time, and draw them on a map. Then, you choose the Decay—a negative human trait such as ambition, greed, or wastefulness, that leads to environmental collapse.   
A map of the arctic tundra from our session with Emily Care Boss and Dane Fogdall.
Throughout a Traversal (scenario), you play in the wreckage that comes from balance lost, moving from one waypoint to the next by fulfilling the vows of your character. You weather the Storm and find help and hope in those around you, to seek possibilities of working with the world and each other, and risk losing it all.
When you Face Your Fears, you confront the Storm on an epic scale. These are gripping scenes of bravery and tragedy, as the landscape and entire community struggles against the elements. If characters spend enough Hope, they can withstand the destruction, or rebuild afterwards.
During the Hole Up phase you reach a landmark and the season draws to an end. Soak in community activity, human connection, relationships, and tending to the hurts of others. Let out the pain and grief people are bottling up—the antidote to feeling powerless.    
Play thematic scenes together at various landmark locations.
At this point, you can end the game if you’re playing a one-shot. Or, when you’re ready, begin a new Traversal and keep playing until you complete four seasons.
Finally, you reach Journey’s End to determine the epilogue. The outcome depends on your community's prosperity. Rejoice and reflect upon your year of travel together, or witness the final lash of the Long Storm. 
The zine will be a 60-page, 8 ½ x 5 ½ saddle-stitched booklet with a stunning sepia-colored cover image spanning both sides and interior pages printed in black ink. Illustrations will be done using traditional media.        
Cover art depicts the journey ahead and the hardships left behind.
Your pledge includes complete rules for building a post-fall world, creating Tarnished characters, playing through phases, and running the game using custom Traversals or creating your own.
Along with your pledge you will receive a PDF of the rules and a supplemental PDF including play aids, character sheets, Roles, Domains, a sample Traversal, and pre-generated characters to take your first steps. 
This short campaign lasts only 2 weeks — please help spread the word to launch the zine!    
Domestic shipping within the US is covered in the cost of the pledge. International shipping is charged separately (expected $4 USD). 
Session 0: Listen to Emily, Dane, and Ary as they create a post-fall society set in an arctic tundra and create characters. Preview the journey ahead on their map.
Session 1: Listen as they try to survive an unforgiving arctic landscape and regroup at an  ancient landmark made of dragon bones.
“Lost Roads is a love letter to a world on the brink of ruin, bound up with hope and horror. Play to see what heroism looks like on the other side of disaster.” —Emily Care Boss
“Lost Roads is a poignant game that manages to make a weighty topic both approachable and engaging. Characters can be powerful forces of hope and leadership, but the game asks you to make real choices and sacrifices to do so.” —Dane Fogdall
“Lost Roads has been such a relevant experience for me. Playing the game helped me to combine my worries about the state of the world (global inequalities, climate crisis) with my enthusiasm of telling stories of hope, friendship, and trust.” —Gerrit Reininghaus
“Lost Roads captures the fraught feelings of migrating away from home and allows players to share in the hope and adversity of the road. It allows us to reflect on what parts of home we take with us and which we leave by the wayside.” —Kyle Thompson
"I had a great time playing this game. I am someone who really enjoys games that draw clear inspiration from modern day issues, and this is the first game that I feel draws inspiration from subject matter related to climate change in a thoughtful manner. I want more games like this!" —Mikael Tysvær

campaign.story:
In 1983, suburbia lost its collective minds after finding their children slaying kobolds and painting miniatures. Dungeons and Dragons was a gateway to Satanism, claimed news reports. Preachers shouted that the game taught the ways of the occult and ensnared the souls of the innocent. 
They were right. 
For years, we have waited. Mothers and fathers no longer fear the clatter of bones in the basement. The children of the Satanic Panic have grown and have children of their own. Their books have been passed down, and new generations conjure the magic of warlocks and wizards. The time has come. 
The Dark Lord slumbers. Let us call him forth with snacks and cola. 
The Dark Lord's Spellbook contains all the incantations, rituals, ingredients, forbidden knowledge, and arcane secrets you will need to unlock the full potential of your favorite fantasy tabletop roleplaying games. Sell your soul to empower your dice. Learn to cast Fireball... for real. Conjure gibbering horrors from beyond the edge of the cosmos and unleash them on your unsuspecting neighbors. 
What is it, really? 
Part satire, part idea book, part rules resource. Enjoy new ways to infuse a little silly participation into your games. Help foster discussions on consent and content. Get ideas for your next adventure and tips on running witches and warlocks and all manner of occultists in your campaign. Generate demons, devils, and cults to drag and drop into your world, either to guide your character or torment your players. Create more interesting familiars. Find new ways to conjure nightmares. Customize potions. Use black magic to overthrow the government and seize the means of production.
The Dark Lord's Spellbook is presented in print with the doodles and margin notes of the wizards and warlocks that came before. It is printed in black and white with red accents. The red ink may or may not be enchanted. 
There is magic in the dungeon, and the tiny little dice we use to explore it. This pocket tome hopes to help you unleash it.

updates.update_content:
Greetings, bile-filled effigies of futile humanity!
WE DID IT! 
Or, rather, I did it. I summoned Kharm, the Dust Lord of Bastard Goats, to trick twenty poor souls in three days. With forbidden witchcraft. Which I shall now teach you via the zine you just purchased!
In all seriousness, thanks everyone. I'm excited to share with you a little bit of blasphemy, blood rites, and friendship. Mostly friendship. And also demonic possession.

Well, with just about two days left, it looks as if there's a strong chance we're going to fall short of our goal. I just wanted to thank everyone who has supported the campaign at any and all pledge levels and invite you to continue to follow on Kickstarter and on Twitter here so you can get word when projects will be available down the road. 
I also wanted to thank those of you that privately offered constructive criticism and advice. This was my first attempted Kickstarter, and most of what I knew coming in was just from checking out other campaigns. I have a little more practical knowledge now, which will help in the next attempt... coming in a few months, I hope.

Hail, pathetic fleshlings!
Backers have been finding us at a slow but steady clip. We are on a good pace to this point, but I would like to help move the needle a bit. 
If we can make our funding goal, I will be running some one-shot ”Actual Play” sessions open to all backers who want a chance to see the Spellbook in action. If you back the Spellbook in pdf or print form, you get a seat at the table for one of these sessions.

Greetings, backers! (and everyone else)
There's a subreddit I like called "Witches vs. Patriarchy". If you browse reddit, you can find it here. The premise of the subreddit is to embrace tropes and themes that were vilified by patriarchal communities and religious groups for hundreds of years, since the first colonial settlers came to what would later become America. Even as far back as the Dark Ages, mysticism and the occult were yoked to women as a cruel means of coercion, manipulation, and superstition, often with violent or deadly results. The folks who like to post in Witches vs. Patriarchy share memes, jokes, tweets, and photos fully adopting the aesthetics, philosophies, and pop culture cornerstones of witchcraft and the occult.
